1_3-2_3_conjecture.name: 1/3‚Äì2/3 conjecture
1_3-2_3_conjecture.rephrased: In any partially ordered set that isn't fully sorted, there exists at least one pair of elements where the number of ways to fully sort the set (linear extensions) has them in one order (x before y) no more than twice as often as the other order (y before x).
1_3-2_3_conjecture.implication_form: If a finite partially ordered set is not totally ordered, then there exists a pair of elements x and y such that in the linear extensions, x appears before y in at least 1/3 and at most 2/3 of the extensions.
1_3-2_3_conjecture.explained: The 1/3‚Äì2/3 conjecture is a statement in order theory. It posits that for any finite partially ordered set (poset) that is not already totally ordered (i.e., it has multiple linear extensions), there exists at least one pair of elements (x, y) such that, in the set of all possible linear extensions (total orders consistent with the partial order), the proportion of extensions where x precedes y is strictly between 1/3 and 2/3. In other words, no single element pair has a 'decisive' ordering across nearly all linear extensions; there is always some pair whose relative order is unresolved by the partial order in a balanced way (between 1/3 and 2/3 of the possibilities). This property is significant in comparison models for sorting, as it guarantees the existence of a comparison that significantly reduces the number of possible sorted outcomes (linear extensions).
subjects: Theoretical Computer Science (specifically sorting algorithms and comparison models)

3-sphere.name: 3-sphere
3-sphere.rephrased: The 3-sphere is defined as the set of all points in 4-dimensional space that are equidistant from a central point, forming a 3-dimensional surface.
3-sphere.explained: The 3-sphere is defined as the set of all points in 4-dimensional Euclidean space (R^4) that are at a fixed Euclidean distance, known as the radius, from a given central point (typically the origin). Mathematically, it can be expressed as the set {(x, y, z, w) ‚àà R^4 | x¬≤ + y¬≤ + z¬≤ + w¬≤ = r¬≤}, where r is the radius.

Abelian_extension.name: Abelian extension
Abelian_extension.rephrased: An abelian extension is a type of field extension that is Galois (meaning it is a normal and separable extension) and has an abelian group of symmetries (the Galois group).
Abelian_extension.implication_form: If a field extension is Galois and its Galois group is abelian, then it is an abelian extension.
Abelian_extension.explained: An abelian extension is a Galois extension where the Galois group is abelian. A cyclic extension is a specific type of abelian extension where the Galois group is cyclic. Solvable extensions are Galois extensions with a solvable Galois group, which includes all abelian extensions (since abelian groups are solvable) but is a broader category.

Abundance_conjecture.name: Abundance conjecture
Abundance_conjecture.rephrased: If a projective variety with Kawamata log terminal singularities has a nef canonical bundle, then some sufficiently large multiple of that bundle is base-point free.
Abundance_conjecture.implication_form: If a projective variety X with Kawamata log terminal singularities has a nef canonical bundle, then the canonical bundle is semi-ample.
Abundance_conjecture.solved_by: No one fully solved it yet, but Caucher Birkar has established important cases

Agrawal's_conjecture.name: Agrawal's conjecture
Agrawal's_conjecture.rephrased: Agrawal's conjecture states that for any two coprime positive integers n and r, if n is prime then n¬≤ ‚â° 1 (mod r) whenever the polynomial congruence (X-1)^n ‚â° X^n - 1 (mod n, X^r - 1) holds.
Agrawal's_conjecture.explained: Agrawal's conjecture states that for any two coprime positive integers n and r, if the polynomial congruence (X-1)^n ‚â° X^n - 1 holds modulo n and the polynomial X^r - 1, then either n is prime or n^2 ‚â° 1 (mod r).
related_conjectures: Generalized Riemann Hypothesis (related to efficient primality testing)

Ahlfors_measure_conjecture.name: Ahlfors measure conjecture
Ahlfors_measure_conjecture.rephrased: The limit set of a finitely generated Kleinian group is either 'small' (measure zero) or covers the entire complex plane.
Ahlfors_measure_conjecture.implication_form: If a Kleinian group has a finite-sided fundamental domain, then its limit set has measure 0 or is the whole Riemann sphere.
Ahlfors_measure_conjecture.solved_by: Richard Canary, Ian Agol, Danny Calegari, David Gabai
Ahlfors_measure_conjecture.explained: The Ahlfors Measure Conjecture, now a theorem, states that for any finitely generated Kleinian group, the limit set (the set of accumulation points of the orbit of any point under the group action) has either measure zero with respect to the spherical Lebesgue measure or is the entire Riemann sphere. Lars Ahlfors proved this for the specific case where the fundamental domain has a finite number of sides. The general proof relies on the connection between topological tameness and geometric tameness established by Marden's Tameness Conjecture, with the final step provided by independent proofs from Agol, Calegari & Gabai.

Albertson_conjecture.name: Albertson conjecture
Albertson_conjecture.rephrased: Among all graphs requiring n colors, the complete graph K_n has the highest crossing number.
Albertson_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph has chromatic number less than n, then it can be drawn with fewer crossings than the complete graph K_n.
Albertson_conjecture.explained: The Albertson conjecture states that for any integer n, the complete graph K_n has the maximum crossing number among all graphs with chromatic number n. In other words, any graph requiring n colors must have a crossing number at least equal to that of K_n. This implies that K_n minimizes the crossing number for graphs with chromatic number n.

Alon-Saks-Seymour_conjecture.name: Alon‚ÄìSaks‚ÄìSeymour conjecture
Alon-Saks-Seymour_conjecture.rephrased: A graph with chromatic number k+1 requires at least k complete bipartite subgraphs in any edge-partition.
Alon-Saks-Seymour_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph has chromatic number k+1, then it requires at least k complete bipartite subgraphs to cover its edges (in any edge-partition).
Alon-Saks-Seymour_conjecture.posed_by: Noga Alon, Michael Saks, Paul Seymour

Alspach's_conjecture.name: Alspach's conjecture
Alspach's_conjecture.rephrased: Every complete graph with n vertices and a set of cycle lengths summing to n has a disjoint cycle cover consisting exactly of cycles of those specified lengths.
Alspach's_conjecture.implication_form: If a complete graph K_n has a multiset of cycle lengths C_1, C_2, ..., C_k such that C_1 + C_2 + ... + C_k = n, then K_n has a disjoint cycle cover consisting of cycles of lengths C_1, C_2, ..., C_k.
Alspach's_conjecture.solved_by: Darryn Bryant, Daniel Horsley, and William Pettersson
Alspach's_conjecture.explained: Alspach's conjecture states that for any complete graph K_n (where n is the number of vertices), and any partition of the integers from 1 to n-1 into parts each of which is the length of a cycle (or a set of cycles) that satisfy certain conditions, there exists a decomposition of the edges of K_n into edge-disjoint cycles whose lengths correspond exactly to the parts of the partition.
related_conjectures: Existence of cycle decompositions in graph theory

Andrews-Curtis_conjecture.name: Andrews‚ÄìCurtis conjecture
Andrews-Curtis_conjecture.rephrased: The Andrews‚ÄìCurtis conjecture states that any way of writing the 'empty product' (trivial group) using an equal number of starting symbols (generators) and equations (relations) can be transformed into a presentation showing no relations by applying a series of specific operations (Nielsen transformations on generators and relations, plus conjugating relations).
Andrews-Curtis_conjecture.implication_form: If a balanced presentation represents the trivial group, then it can be transformed into a trivial presentation (one with no relations) using a series of Nielsen transformations and conjugations.
Andrews-Curtis_conjecture.posed_by: James J. Andrews and Morton L. Curtis
Andrews-Curtis_conjecture.explained: The Andrews‚ÄìCurtis conjecture states that any balanced presentation (i.e., a presentation with the same number of generators and relations) of the trivial group (the group with a single identity element) is an 'Andrews‚ÄìCurtis trivial presentation'. This means it can be transformed into the presentation with no generators and no relations (the trivial presentation) by a series of operations known as Nielsen transformations applied to the generators and relators, and by conjugating the relators.

Andr√©-Oort_conjecture.name: Andr√©‚ÄìOort conjecture
Andr√©-Oort_conjecture.rephrased: The Zariski closure of any set of special points in a Shimura variety is itself a special subvariety.
Andr√©-Oort_conjecture.implication_form: If a subset of special points in a Shimura variety is sufficiently large or satisfies certain arithmetic conditions, then its Zariski closure is a special subvariety.

Ap√©ry's_constant.name: Ap√©ry's constant
Ap√©ry's_constant.rephrased: Ap√©ry's constant, denoted Œ∂(3), is defined as the sum of the reciprocals of the cubes of all positive integers.

Arnold-Givental_conjecture.name: Arnold‚ÄìGivental conjecture
Arnold-Givental_conjecture.rephrased: A Hamiltonian diffeomorphism on a closed symplectic manifold must have at least as many fixed points as the minimum number of critical points a smooth function on that same manifold can have.
Arnold-Givental_conjecture.implication_form: If a Hamiltonian diffeomorphism exists on a closed symplectic manifold, then it must have at least the minimal number of critical points of a smooth function on that manifold.

Arthur's_conjectures.name: Arthur's conjectures
Arthur's_conjectures.rephrased: The conjectures map representations of reductive groups over local fields to automorphic representations via the Langlands program.
Arthur's_conjectures.implication_form: If the conjectures hold, then the unitary representations predicted by the Langlands dual group exist and relate to automorphic forms.
Arthur's_conjectures.explained: Arthur's conjectures, formulated for reductive groups over global and local fields, propose a precise description of the automorphic representations contributing to the spectral decomposition of the relative trace formula derived from the Arthur-Selberg trace formula. They predict that these representations are deeply controlled by the Langlands dual group and its conjugacy classes, providing a framework to relate automorphic representations to Galois representations and vice versa, thereby extending the global Langlands program.
related_conjectures: Fundamental Lemma (proved by Ng√¥ Bao Ch√¢u)

Artin's_conjecture_on_primitive_roots.name: Artin's conjecture on primitive roots
Artin's_conjecture_on_primitive_roots.rephrased: Certain integers (those that aren't perfect squares or -1) are primitive roots modulo infinitely many prime numbers.
Artin's_conjecture_on_primitive_roots.implication_form: If the Artin conjecture is true for a given integer a, then a is a primitive root modulo infinitely many primes.
Artin's_conjecture_on_primitive_roots.explained: Artin's conjecture on primitive roots states that if a is an integer that is neither a perfect square nor equal to ‚àí1, then a is a primitive root modulo infinitely many primes p. Furthermore, the conjecture assigns an asymptotic density, or Dirichlet density, to the set of such primes. This density is conjectured to be equal to Artin's constant, which is defined as the product over all primes q of (1 - 1/q^2) divided by the product over all prime ideals in the maximal unramified abelian extension of Q containing a, evaluated at s=1, but simplified in terms of the prime q-splitting behavior related to a.
related_conjectures: Riemann Hypothesis (often assumed for the conjecture to hold in full generality)
Conjecture on the density of primes for which 2 is a primitive root
Conjecture on the density of primes for which -1 is a primitive root

Atiyah_conjecture.name: Atiyah conjecture
Atiyah_conjecture.rephrased: Are the l¬≤-Betti numbers, defined as von Neumann dimensions of l¬≤-cohomology groups for spaces with a discrete countable group's free co-compact action, always rational numbers?
Atiyah_conjecture.solved_by: Unsolved in general (though solved in many specific cases)
Atiyah_conjecture.explained: The Atiyah conjecture concerns the rationality of l¬≤-Betti numbers, which are invariants defined using l¬≤-cohomology. It posits that for a compact manifold with a free, co-compact action by a discrete countable group, the l¬≤-Betti numbers of the universal cover are rational numbers. Equivalently, it asks whether these invariants, defined via von Neumann dimensions, are always rational in this context.

Atiyah_conjecture_on_configurations.name: Atiyah conjecture on configurations
Atiyah_conjecture_on_configurations.rephrased: A specific matrix constructed from n points in three-dimensional space is always invertible, regardless of the points' positions.
Atiyah_conjecture_on_configurations.implication_form: If there are n points in R¬≥, then the matrix defined by the conjecture is non-singular.
Atiyah_conjecture_on_configurations.explained: The Atiyah conjecture on configurations states that for any set of n distinct points in three-dimensional Euclidean space (R¬≥), a specific n by n matrix constructed from these points is always non-singular (invertible). However, the exact form of the matrix is not fully specified in the provided summary. The conjecture claims that regardless of the configuration of the points, this particular matrix remains invertible.

Babai's_problem.name: Babai's problem
Babai's_problem.explained: Babai's problem in graph theory conjectures that in any 3-connected graph where the longest cycles have length c, any two longest cycles must share at least f(c) vertices. Here, f(c) is a function that grows without bound as c increases (i.e., f(c) ‚Üí ‚àû as c ‚Üí ‚àû). This means that longer graphs cannot have arbitrarily short intersections between their longest cycles.

Banach_space.name: Banach space
Banach_space.rephrased: A Banach space is a vector space equipped with a norm where every Cauchy sequence converges to a point within the space.
Banach_space.implication_form: If a vector space is normed and complete (i.e., every Cauchy sequence converges within the space), then it is a Banach space.
Banach_space.posed_by: Stefan Banach (though the concept builds on earlier work by others like Fr√©chet; the term 'Banach space' was coined by Banach)
Banach_space.solved_by: Unsolved (as it is a foundational concept rather than a specific conjecture to be solved)
Banach_space.explained: A Banach space is a complete normed vector space. This means it is a vector space equipped with a norm (a function that assigns a strictly positive length or size to each vector) and is complete under the metric induced by the norm. Completeness here means that every Cauchy sequence (a sequence where the elements become arbitrarily close to each other as the sequence progresses) in the space converges to a limit that is also within the space. This property ensures the space has no 'holes' and is fundamental for many areas of mathematical analysis.

Barnette's_conjecture.name: Barnette's conjecture
Barnette's_conjecture.rephrased: A Hamiltonian cycle exists in any graph that is cubic (each vertex has degree 3), 3-connected, bipartite, and planar.
Barnette's_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph is cubic, 3-connected, bipartite, and planar, then it is Hamiltonian.

Bass-Quillen_conjecture.name: Bass‚ÄìQuillen conjecture
Bass-Quillen_conjecture.rephrased: A finitely generated vector bundle on a polynomial space over a regular base ring can be extended from the base ring.
Bass-Quillen_conjecture.implication_form: If R is a regular Noetherian ring and P is a finitely generated projective R[T‚ÇÅ,...,T‚Çô]-module, then P is extended from R.

Bass_conjecture.name: Bass conjecture
Bass_conjecture.rephrased: For smooth, finite-type schemes over a finite field, the algebraic K-theory groups are finitely generated.
Bass_conjecture.implication_form: If X is a smooth, finite-type scheme over a finite field, then for each n ‚â• 0, K_n(X) is finitely generated.

Baum-Connes_conjecture.name: Baum‚ÄìConnes conjecture
Baum-Connes_conjecture.rephrased: The topological K-theory of a group's classifying space is isomorphic to the K-theory of its reduced C*-algebra via a specific map called the assembly map.
Baum-Connes_conjecture.implication_form: Not applicable (the conjecture is an equality/isomorphism itself)
Baum-Connes_conjecture.posed_by: H. Blumberg and G. Connes (or H. Baum and G. Connes)
Baum-Connes_conjecture.explained: The Baum‚ÄìConnes conjecture states that for any discrete group Œì, the assembly map \( \mu_Œì \colon \underset{\underline{E}Œì}{K}^*(BŒì) \to \mathrm{K}\text{\textunderscore{as}}^*(C^*_\mathrm{red}(Œì)) \) is an isomorphism of abelian groups. Here, \( \underset{\underline{E}Œì}{K}^*(BŒì) \) denotes the topological K-theory of the classifying space \( BŒì \) (the space representing the classifying bundle for principal Œì-bundles), \( C^*_\mathrm{red}(Œì) \) is the reduced group C*-algebra associated with Œì, and \( \mathrm{K}\text{\textunderscore{as}}^* \) is the analytic K-theory (the K-theory of the C*-algebra). The assembly map is a fundamental map that connects the topological and analytic aspects of the group.

Bellman's_lost-in-a-forest_problem.name: Bellman's lost-in-a-forest problem
Bellman's_lost-in-a-forest_problem.rephrased: Given a region of a known shape, find a path that minimizes the maximum distance you must travel to escape, assuming you start at any unknown point inside the region and face any unknown direction.
Bellman's_lost-in-a-forest_problem.implication_form: If there exists a region of a given shape, then there exists a path such that no matter the starting point within the region or the starting direction, the maximum distance required to escape is minimized.
Bellman's_lost-in-a-forest_problem.explained: The Bellman 'lost in a forest' problem is an unsolved minimax geometric optimization problem. It requires finding, for a given known-shaped planar region (the 'forest'), a path (a function from time and angle to position) that guarantees escape (exiting the region) starting from any unknown point inside the region and facing any unknown direction. The 'best' path is defined as the one that minimizes the maximum distance traveled to escape in the worst-case scenario. This worst-case escape distance depends on the starting point and initial direction. The goal is to find a path that minimizes this maximum escape distance over all possible starting positions and orientations within the region. While optimal strategies exist for simple shapes like circles and squares, the problem remains open for more complex regions.
terms: Voronoi diagram (related concept for escape regions)

Berge_knot.name: Berge knot
Berge_knot.rephrased: A Berge knot is a specific type of knot in the 3-sphere where performing a non-trivial Dehn surgery results in a lens space, and it can be described as a simple closed curve on a genus-2 Heegaard surface primitive in both handlebodies.
Berge_knot.implication_form: If a knot is doubly primitive, then it is a Berge knot.

Bernoulli_number.name: Bernoulli number
Bernoulli_number.rephrased: Bernoulli numbers are a sequence of rational numbers where those with odd indices (except B‚ÇÅ) are zero, and those with even indices alternate in sign.
Bernoulli_number.implication_form: If n is an odd integer greater than 1, then B_n = 0. If n is an even integer, then B_n alternates in sign starting with B‚ÇÇ being positive.

Berry-Robbins_problem.name: Berry‚ÄìRobbins problem
Berry-Robbins_problem.rephrased: Does a continuous map exist from the configuration space of n distinct points in 3D space to the flag manifold U(n)/T^n that is invariant under the symmetries of the configuration space?
Berry-Robbins_problem.implication_form: If a continuous map respecting the symmetries exists between these spaces, then it satisfies certain properties (but the core question is the existence itself, not a conditional statement).

Bing-Borsuk_conjecture.name: Bing‚ÄìBorsuk conjecture
Bing-Borsuk_conjecture.rephrased: A space is a topological n-manifold if it is homogeneous and an absolute neighborhood retract (ANR) of dimension n.
Bing-Borsuk_conjecture.implication_form: If a space is n-dimensional, homogeneous, and an absolute neighborhood retract (ANR), then it is a topological n-manifold.
Bing-Borsuk_conjecture.explained: The Bing‚ÄìBorsuk conjecture states that every n-dimensional homogeneous absolute neighborhood retract (ANR) is a topological n-manifold.

Birch-Tate_conjecture.name: Birch‚ÄìTate conjecture
Birch-Tate_conjecture.rephrased: The size (order) of the K2 group for a totally real number field's ring of integers is mathematically linked to the value of its Dedekind zeta function at s=-1.
Birch-Tate_conjecture.implication_form: If the absolute value of the Dedekind zeta function Œ∂_F(-1) (adjusted by a power of 2) equals the order of the K2 group K‚ÇÇ(O_F), then the Birch‚ÄìTate conjecture holds.
Birch-Tate_conjecture.explained: The Birch‚ÄìTate conjecture, formulated for a totally real number field F, proposes that the order (the number of elements) of the algebraic K-group K‚ÇÇ(ùí™_F) (where ùí±_F is the ring of integers of F) is equal in absolute value to the value of the Dedekind zeta function Œ∂_F(s) evaluated at s = -1, adjusted by a power of two. This conjecture remains unproven in general but has been confirmed for specific cases.

Birch_and_Swinnerton-Dyer_conjecture.name: Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture
Birch_and_Swinnerton-Dyer_conjecture.rephrased: The conjecture states that the depth to which an elliptic curve's L-function dips to zero at the central point s=1 determines how many 'directions' exist for finding rational solutions on the curve.
Birch_and_Swinnerton-Dyer_conjecture.implication_form: If the L-function of an elliptic curve has a zero of order r at s=1, then the curve has a rank of r (i.e., r independent rational solutions).

Bloch-Kato_conjecture.name: Bloch‚ÄìKato conjecture
Bloch-Kato_conjecture.rephrased: The Bloch‚ÄìKato conjecture predicts that the rate at which an L-function vanishes at a specific point (its order of vanishing) directly reflects the size of a related arithmetic object called the Bloch‚ÄìKato Selmer group, measured by its rank.
Bloch-Kato_conjecture.implication_form: If an L-function satisfies certain conditions (like being associated to a pure geometric p-adic Galois representation), then the order of vanishing of the L-function at a specific point is equal to the rank of the corresponding Bloch‚ÄìKato Selmer group.

Bogomolov_conjecture.name: Bogomolov conjecture
Bogomolov_conjecture.rephrased: Points with very small 'height' (a measure of complexity) on certain subvarieties of abelian varieties are rare; only specific 'special' subvarieties, like those defined by rational equations or containing torsion points, can host infinitely many such points in a 'dense' way.
Bogomolov_conjecture.implication_form: If a subvariety of an abelian variety contains a Zariski-dense set of points with canonical height zero, then it must be a special (or torsion) subvariety.
Bogomolov_conjecture.solved_by: Unsolved in general, but proven in many special cases (e.g., by M. Raynaud, D. Cantor, G. Faltings, J. Harris, R. Lange, M. Hindry, J. Bost, J. Loir, etc.)

Bombieri-Lang_conjecture.name: Bombieri‚ÄìLang conjecture
Bombieri-Lang_conjecture.rephrased: Faltings's theorem proves that curves of general type have finitely many rational points. The Bombieri‚ÄìLang conjecture extends this to higher-dimensional varieties, stating that any positive-dimensional projective variety of general type defined over a number field should have rational points that are not Zariski-dense (i.e., they lie on a proper subvariety).
Bombieri-Lang_conjecture.implication_form: If X is a positive-dimensional projective variety defined over a number field K and X is of general type, then the set of K-rational points on X is not Zariski-dense.
Bombieri-Lang_conjecture.posed_by: Enrico Bombieri and David W. Lang

Boolean_Pythagorean_triples_problem.name: Boolean Pythagorean triples problem
Boolean_Pythagorean_triples_problem.rephrased: Can the set of natural numbers be colored using two colors such that no Pythagorean triple (a¬≤ + b¬≤ = c¬≤) has all three numbers the same color?
Boolean_Pythagorean_triples_problem.implication_form: If the set of positive integers is two-colored, then there exists a Pythagorean triple where all three numbers are the same color.
Boolean_Pythagorean_triples_problem.posed_by: Not specified in the provided text.
Boolean_Pythagorean_triples_problem.solved_by: Proven impossible by a team including Marijn Heule (and independently by another team) using a 200-terabyte proof verified by specialized algorithms.
Boolean_Pythagorean_triples_problem.year_originated: At least 60 years old (estimate based on the context of the 2016 solution).
Boolean_Pythagorean_triples_problem.explained: The Boolean Pythagorean triples problem is a conjecture that asks whether the set of positive integers can be partitioned into two subsets (or equivalently, colored with two colors) such that no Pythagorean triple (a set of three integers satisfying a¬≤ + b¬≤ = c¬≤) is entirely contained within one subset or has all three elements the same color. This conjecture, which was proven to be false in 2016, established that such a two-coloring is impossible for sufficiently large integers, specifically beyond a certain finite threshold.

Borel_conjecture.name: Borel conjecture
Borel_conjecture.rephrased: The fundamental group determines the topology of a closed aspherical manifold.
Borel_conjecture.implication_form: If two closed aspherical manifolds have isomorphic fundamental groups, then they are homeomorphic.
Borel_conjecture.explained: The Bore, essentially claiming that the fundamental group determines the homeomorphism type for closed aspherical manifolds.
related_conjectures: Rigidity conjectures in other contexts (e.g., Mostow rigidity theorem)

Borromean_rings.name: Borromean rings
Borromean_rings.rephrased: Three rings are interlocked such that removing any one causes the others to separate.
Borromean_rings.implication_form: If three rings are interlocked in the Borromean configuration, then removing any one ring will cause the entire structure to fall apart.
Borromean_rings.explained: Borromean rings are defined as a specific configuration of three unlinked rings that are interlocked such that the removal of any one ring causes the entire structure to fall apart. This configuration demonstrates a unique form of interdependence where the rings are linked, yet pairwise unlinked. The rings are typically depicted as oval-shaped and arranged symmetrically. Borromean rings are a prime example of a Brunnian link of rank three.
related_conjectures: Conjectures on the properties of Borromean rings in higher dimensions

Brennan_conjecture.name: Brennan conjecture
Brennan_conjecture.rephrased: A simply connected region in the complex plane can be mapped bijectively onto the unit disk via a conformal map, and the integral of the absolute value of the map's derivative raised to any power p (between 4/3 and 4) remains finite.
Brennan_conjecture.implication_form: If a simply connected open subset W of the complex plane (with at least two boundary points) admits a conformal map onto the unit disk, then the integral of |f'(z)|^p over W is finite for all p in (4/3, 4).
Brennan_conjecture.explained: The Brennan conjecture concerns the integrability of the derivative of conformal maps. It states that for any simply connected open subset W of the complex plane with at least two boundary points, and for any conformal map f mapping W onto the open unit disk \(\mathbb{D}\), the integral \(\int_{W} |f'(z)|^p  dA(z)\) is finite for all \(p\) satisfying \(\frac{4}{3} < p < 4\), where dA(z) denotes the area element. While J. G. Brennan proved the conjecture holds for \(\frac{4}{3} < p < 3 + \delta\) for some \(\delta > 0\), the general case \(\frac{4}{.} < p < 4\) remains unproven.

Brocard's_conjecture.name: Brocard's conjecture
Brocard's_conjecture.rephrased: Between the squares of consecutive prime numbers, there are at least four prime numbers.
Brocard's_conjecture.implication_form: If n is at least 2, then there are at least four primes between the squares of the nth and (n+1)th prime.
Brocard's_conjecture.explained: Brocard's conjecture states that for any integer n ‚â• 2, where pn is the n-th prime number, there are at least four prime numbers strictly between the squares of pn and the square of the next prime, pn+1.

Brocard's_problem.name: Brocard's problem
Brocard's_problem.explained: Brocard's problem is an unsolved conjecture in number theory that asks for all pairs of positive integers (n, m) such that n! + 1 is a perfect square (m¬≤). It was formulated by Henri Brocard in 1876 and later considered by Srinivasa Ramanujan in 1913. The known solutions are (n, m) = (4, 5), (5, 11), and (7, 71).
related_conjectures: Wilson's Theorem (related concept involving factorials and primes)
Brown Numbers (related to Wilson's Theorem and factorial being one less than a square)

Brouwer's_conjecture.name: Brouwer's conjecture
Brouwer's_conjecture.rephrased: For any finite simple graph, the sum of its k largest Laplacian eigenvalues is bounded above by the number of edges plus the number of edges in a complete graph on k vertices.
Brouwer's_conjecture.implication_form: If G is a finite simple graph with n vertices, m edges, and Laplacian eigenvalues Œª‚ÇÅ ‚â• Œª‚ÇÇ ‚â• ‚Ä¶ ‚â• Œª‚Çô, then for any k between 1 and n, the sum of the k largest eigenvalues (Œª‚ÇÅ + Œª‚ÇÇ + ‚Ä¶ + Œª‚Çñ) is less than or equal to m + C(k+1, 2), where C denotes the binomial coefficient.
Brouwer's_conjecture.explained: Brouwer's conjecture is an open problem in spectral graph theory. It proposes an upper bound for the sum of the k largest eigenvalues of the Laplacian matrix of a finite simple graph. The conjecture states that for a graph G with n vertices and m edges, the sum of its k largest Laplacian eigenvalues (Œª‚ÇÅ ‚â• Œª‚ÇÇ ‚â• ‚Ä¶ ‚â• Œª‚Çô) is at most m + \binom{k+1}{2} for all k in the range 1 ‚â§ k ‚â§ n. This conjecture has been verified for specific classes of graphs like trees and certain planar graphs but remains unproven in general.

Brumer-Stark_conjecture.name: Brumer‚ÄìStark conjecture
Brumer-Stark_conjecture.rephrased: The conjecture links the special values of certain L-functions to the structure of the ideal class group in an abelian extension, specifically stating that a specific element (the Stickelberger element) annihilates the class group.
Brumer-Stark_conjecture.implication_form: If H/F is a finite abelian extension of number fields with F totally real, H a CM field, and S, T are disjoint finite sets of places satisfying standard conditions, then the Stickelberger element Œò_{H/F,S,T} annihilates the relevant class group.
Brumer-Stark_conjecture.explained: The Brumer‚ÄìStark conjecture pertains to finite abelian extensions H/F of number fields where F is totally real and H is a CM field. It involves two disjoint finite sets of places S and T of F, containing all infinite places and all finite places that are ramified in H/F. The conjecture asserts that the Stickel (or Stark) element Œò_{H/F,S,T}, which resides in the rational group ring Q[Gal(H/F)], annihilates the class group Cl_F(S) of F with respect to the set S.

Bunyakovsky_conjecture.name: Bunyakovsky conjecture
Bunyakovsky_conjecture.rephrased: A certain type of polynomial (one that is irreducible, has positive leading coefficient, and doesn't share a common factor greater than 1 with all its integer outputs) will always produce an infinite number of prime numbers when evaluated at positive integers.
Bunyakovsky_conjecture.implication_form: If a non-constant polynomial with integer coefficients is irreducible over the integers, has a positive leading coefficient, and the values it takes at positive integers have no common prime divisor, then it takes on infinitely many prime values.
Bunyakovsky_conjecture.explained: The Bunyakovsky conjecture is a hypothesis in number theory proposing that a non-constant polynomial with integer coefficients will produce infinitely many prime numbers if it satisfies three conditions: its leading coefficient is positive, it is irreducible over the integers (cannot be factored into non-constant polynomials with integer coefficients), and the greatest common divisor of all its integer values is 1.

Burnside_problem.name: Burnside problem
Burnside_problem.rephrased: Is every finitely generated group with elements of finite order necessarily finite?
Burnside_problem.implication_form: If a group is finitely generated and every element has finite order, then it is finite.
Burnside_problem.explained: The Burnside problem is a foundational question in group theory that asks: If a group is finitely generated and every element in the group has finite order (i.e., for each element g, there exists some positive integer n such that g^n = e, the identity element), then must the group itself be finite? This problem was originally posed by William Burnside in 1902. The general case (where no specific bound is imposed on the orders of elements) was answered negatively in 1964 by a counterexample constructed by Efim Golod and Igor Shafarevich. However, the problem remains highly active and complex, with the restricted Burnside problem (where the orders of all elements divide a fixed positive integer n) still being a major open question in the field.
related_conjectures: Odd Order Theorem (Classification of Finite Simple Groups)
Bounding the orders of elements in finite groups

Burr-Erd≈ës_conjecture.name: Burr‚ÄìErd≈ës conjecture
Burr-Erd≈ës_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph is d-degenerate, then its Ramsey number is linear in its number of vertices.

B√ºchi's_problem.name: B√ºchi's problem
B√ºchi's_problem.rephrased: A sequence of squares with constant second difference 2 must consist of consecutive squares.
B√ºchi's_problem.implication_form: If a sequence of squares has a constant second difference of 2 and has length greater than or equal to M, then it consists of consecutive squares.

CW_complex.name: CW complex
CW_complex.rephrased: A CW complex is a topological space constructed by attaching cells of various dimensions together in a step-by-step manner, with a topology defined to make these attachments continuous.
CW_complex.explained: A CW complex is a type of topological space constructed by gluing together cells (of various dimensions) in a specific inductive way. It is defined by attaching cells of increasing dimension, starting from a discrete set of points (0-cells), and gluing n-cells along their boundaries to existing parts of the complex (the (n-1)-skeleton). The topology of a CW complex is the weak topology, meaning it is the smallest topology that makes all the characteristic maps (used in the gluing process) continuous. CW complexes are fundamental objects in algebraic topology and are particularly well-suited for homotopy theory because their construction allows for inductive analysis and the study of homotopy types.
related_conjectures: Kodaira conjecture (related to complex manifolds, sometimes modeled by CW complexes)

Cameron-Erd≈ës_conjecture.name: Cameron‚ÄìErd≈ës conjecture
Cameron-Erd≈ës_conjecture.rephrased: The total number of subsets of the integers from 1 to n that do not contain any three elements x, y, z (not necessarily distinct) with x + y = z grows asymptotically as a constant times 2 raised to the power of n/2.
Cameron-Erd≈ës_conjecture.implication_form: If a subset of {1,2,...,n} is sum-free, then the number of such subsets is asymptotically equal to c * 2^(n/2) for some constant c depending on n.
Cameron-Erd≈ës_conjecture.explained: The Cameron‚ÄìErd≈ës conjecture addresses the asymptotic growth rate of the maximum number of sum-free subsets of the set {1, 2, ..., n}. A set S ‚äÜ {1, 2, ..., n} is sum-free if no two elements in S can be summed to give another element in S (i.e., there do not exist x, y, z ‚àà S such that x + y = z). The conjecture, proposed by Cameron and Erd≈ës in 1988, states that the maximum number of sum-free subsets is asymptotically equivalent to c * 2^(n/2) for some constant c (which depends on the parity of n). This means that, in the limit as n becomes very large, the maximum number of sum-free subsets grows like 2 raised to the power of n/2, multiplied by a constant. This conjecture was proven independently by Ben Green and Alexander Sapozhenko in 2003.

Carath√©odory_conjecture.name: Carath√©odory conjecture
Carath√©odory_conjecture.rephrased: A sufficiently smooth, closed, and convex surface in three-dimensional space must have at least two points where the principal curvatures are equal (umbilic points).
Carath√©odory_conjecture.implication_form: If a surface is closed, convex, and sufficiently smooth, then it must have at least two umbilic points.
Carath√©odory_conjecture.explained: The Carath√©odory conjecture states that any smooth, closed, and convex surface embedded in three-dimensional Euclidean space must have at least two points known as umbilic points. An umbilic point is a location on the surface where the two principal curvatures are equal, meaning the surface curves equally in all directions at that point.
related_conjectures: Problem of umbilic points on surfaces of revolution
Conjectures related to the topology and curvature distribution on convex surfaces

Carlitz-Wan_conjecture.name: Carlitz‚ÄìWan conjecture
Carlitz-Wan_conjecture.rephrased: A polynomial cannot be a permutation polynomial (which rearranges the elements of a finite field) of degree d over a finite field with q elements if the greatest common divisor of d and q-1 is greater than 1.
Carlitz-Wan_conjecture.implication_form: If a polynomial has degree d over a finite field with q elements and the greatest common divisor of d and q-1 is greater than 1, then it cannot be a permutation polynomial.

Carmichael's_totient_function_conjecture.name: Carmichael's totient function conjecture
Carmichael's_totient_function_conjecture.rephrased: No value of Euler's totient function is unique to a single integer.
Carmichael's_totient_function_conjecture.implication_form: If n is a positive integer, then there exists an integer m ‚â† n such that œÜ(m) = œÜ(n).

Carpenter's_rule_problem.name: Carpenter's rule problem
Carpenter's_rule_problem.rephrased: Given a polygonal linkage (a collection of rigid rods connected by hinges), is it possible to fold it into a straight line segment of a specified length without the rods intersecting?
Carpenter's_rule_problem.implication_form: If a polygonal linkage can be folded into a straight line segment of a given length without self-intersection, then the folding problem for that linkage is solved.
Carpenter's_rule_problem.posed_by: Attributed to carpenters and early mechanical engineers working with hinges and folding structures (exact originators not precisely identified)
Carpenter's_rule_problem.solved_by: Robert Connelly, Uli Hakerim, and G√ºnter Rote (for the complexity aspect and key results)
Carpenter's_rule_problem.explained: The Carpenter's Rule problem, specifically its 'folding' aspect, is a conjecture (now a theorem for simple polygons but a conjecture for general linkages) concerning the computational complexity of determining the minimum length into which a given linkage (a collection of rigid edges connected by hinged vertices) can be folded without self-intersection. It is conjectured that this problem is NP-complete for linkages with more than a fixed number of hinges (typically 4 or 5). This means that finding the shortest possible configuration is likely computationally very difficult, as the time required grows faster than any polynomial function of the input size (the description of the linkage).

Cartan-Hadamard_conjecture.name: Cartan‚ÄìHadamard conjecture
Cartan-Hadamard_conjecture.rephrased: On certain curved spaces with no positive curvature, the largest volume for a given shape is no bigger than in a flat space, and the shape must be round like a ball.
Cartan-Hadamard_conjecture.implication_form: If a domain in a Cartan-Hadamard manifold satisfies the isoperimetric inequality with the Euclidean optimal constant, then it must be isometric to a Euclidean ball.
Cartan-Hadamard_conjecture.explained: The Cartan‚ÄìHadamard conjecture, now a theorem proven by Joel Spruck and Mohammad Ghomi in 2019, addresses the isoperimetric inequality in Cartan-Hadamard manifolds. It states that for any domain Œ© in an n-dimensional Cartan-Hadamard manifold (a complete, simply connected Riemannian manifold with nonpositive sectional curvature), the isoperimetric inequality holds with the same Euclidean optimal constant as in Euclidean space. Furthermore, equality in this inequality is achieved if and only if Œ© is isometric to a Euclidean ball of the same dimension.
related_conjectures: The isoperimetric conjecture for Riemannian manifolds with nonnegative Ricci curvature.
The Soul theorem (characterizes noncompact manifolds with nonnegative sectional curvature).
Finiteness conjectures (concerning the number of ends or the fundamental group in nonpositive curvature).

Casas-Alvero_conjecture.name: Casas-Alvero conjecture
Casas-Alvero_conjecture.rephrased: If a polynomial and all its derivatives up to the (d-1)-th derivative share a common root, then the polynomial must have only one distinct root (i.e., it is a power of a linear polynomial).
Casas-Alvero_conjecture.implication_form: If a univariate polynomial of degree d has a common root with each of its first d-1 derivatives, then it has only one distinct root.

Catalan's_Mersenne_conjecture.name: Catalan's Mersenne conjecture
Catalan's_Mersenne_conjecture.rephrased: Catalan-Mersenne numbers are defined recursively as M‚ÇÅ = 2, M_{n+1} = 2^{M_n} + 1. The conjecture states that all terms M‚ÇÅ, M‚ÇÇ, ..., M‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ‚Çá are prime, but M‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ‚Çà is composite.
Catalan's_Mersenne_conjecture.implication_form: If a Catalan-Mersenne number is defined as the sequence starting from 2 with each term being 2 raised to the power of the previous term plus 1, then all terms up to the 127th are prime, but the 128th is composite.

Catalan's_constant.name: Catalan's constant
Catalan's_constant.rephrased: Catalan's constant is the sum of the alternating series 1 - 1/3¬≤ + 1/5¬≤ - 1/7¬≤ + ...
Catalan's_constant.implication_form: Not applicable (this is a definition, not a conjecture to be proven)

Cereceda's_conjecture.name: Cereceda's conjecture
Cereceda's_conjecture.rephrased: With sufficiently many colors (at least d+2), any two proper colorings of a d-degenerate graph can be transformed into each other by changing one vertex's color at a time, and this transformation requires at most a number of steps proportional to the square of the graph's size.
Cereceda's_conjecture.implication_form: If G is a d-degenerate graph with n vertices and Œ± and Œ≤ are two proper vertex colorings of G using at most d+2 colors, then there exists a sequence of proper colorings transforming Œ± to Œ≤ where each step changes the color of a single vertex, and the length of this sequence is O(n¬≤).
Cereceda's_conjecture.explained: Cereceda's conjecture asserts that for any d-degenerate graph with n vertices, and any two proper vertex colorings using at most k = d+2 colors, it is possible to transform one coloring into the other by a sequence of recolorings where only one vertex is changed at a time. The total number of such recoloring steps required is bounded by a quadratic function of n, specifically O(n¬≤).

Chern's_conjecture_(affine_geometry).name: Chern's conjecture (affine geometry)
Chern's_conjecture_(affine_geometry).rephrased: A compact affine manifold has Euler characteristic zero.
Chern's_conjecture_(affine_geometry).implication_form: If a manifold is compact and has an affine structure, then its Euler characteristic is zero.
Chern's_conjecture_(affine_geometry).explained: Chern's conjecture (affine geometry) is an unsolved problem in mathematics, proposed by Shiing-Shen Chern in 1955. It states that any compact affine manifold must have an Euler characteristic of zero. A compact affine manifold is a compact differentiable manifold equipped with a flat affine connection (i.e., an affine structure where the curvature vanishes). The conjecture claims that the topological invariant, the Euler characteristic, vanishes for such manifolds. While the conjecture remains unproven in its general form, it has been established for specific classes of compact affine manifolds, such as those that are complete (i.e., affine equivalent to \(\mathbb{R}^n\)).
related_conjectures: Flatness conditions in other geometric structures

Chern's_conjecture_for_hypersurfaces_in_.name: Chern's conjecture for hypersurfaces in spheres
Chern's_conjecture_for_hypersurfaces_in_.explained: Chern's conjecture for hypersurfaces in spheres states that any compact, minimal hypersurface embedded in a sphere with constant scalar curvature must be isoparametric. This means that such a hypersurface must have constant principal curvatures and satisfy specific conditions related to its shape and curvature properties.

terms.Compact hypersurface: A hypersurface that is compact (finite in extent) and without boundary.
terms.Minimal hypersurface: A hypersurface with zero mean curvature everywhere, meaning it is a critical point for the volume functional.
terms.Embedded: The hypersurface is smoothly and injectively immersed in the sphere.
terms.Sphere: A hypersurface itself in a higher-dimensional space, typically denoted as S^{n} for n-dimensional hypersurfaces.
terms.Scalar curvature: A measure of the curvature at a point on the hypersurface, derived from the Ricci curvature tensor.
terms.Constant scalar curvature: The scalar curvature is the same at every point on the hypersurface.
terms.Isoparametric hypersurface: A hypersurface in a sphere characterized by having constant mean curvature and constant principal curvatures (or a specific number of distinct principal curvatures with constant multiplicity). These hypersurfaces are highly symmetric and well-studied.
terms.Principal curvatures: The eigenvalues of the shape operator (second fundamental form) of the hypersurface.
terms.Second fundamental form: A tensor that measures how the hypersurface bends within the ambient sphere.

related_conjectures: Isoparametric conjecture for hypersurfaces in spheres (which is often considered equivalent or very closely related to Chern's conjecture).
Rigidity conjectures for minimal hypersurfaces with constant mean curvature or other curvature conditions in spheres.
Isoperimetric conjecture (related to minimizing boundary volume).

Chess.name: Chess
Chess.rephrased: Chess is a complex game between two players with no hidden information.
Chess.implication_form: If the game tree is fully explored, then the optimal move can be determined.
Chess.explained: The provided text defines chess as a finite, two-player, zero-sum game of perfect information within combinatorial game theory. It characterizes chess by its 8x8 grid, piece movement rules, the vastness of its game tree, and the immense number of possible positions (far exceeding the number of atoms in the observable universe). This is a mathematical characterization or definition of chess rather than a traditional conjecture seeking to prove or disprove a specific statement.

Class_number_problem.name: Class number problem
Class_number_problem.rephrased: Identify all imaginary quadratic fields with a specific class number.
Class_number_problem.explained: The original formulation of the Class number problem, often referred to as Gauss's class number problem, is not a single conjecture but a challenge in number theory. It historically asked for an effective algorithm to determine all imaginary quadratic number fields (i.e., fields of the form \(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})\) with \(d < 0\)) with a specific, given class number. The class number measures the failure of unique factorization in the ring of integers of the field. While this specific problem (finding all fields *with a given class number*) was completely solved for imaginary quadratic fields in 1985, the core problem‚Äîcharacterizing imaginary quadratic fields based on their class number‚Äîremains effectively solved due to the known list. However, the analogous, much harder problem for *real* quadratic fields (positive discriminant) remains completely open. There is no single, formal conjecture statement provided here, but the problem revolves around the distribution and properties of class numbers across number fields, particularly imaginary and real quadratic fields.

Cobordism_hypothesis.name: Cobordism hypothesis
Cobordism_hypothesis.rephrased: A fully extended TQFT on framed n-manifolds is equivalent to the free symmetric monoidal n-category with duals.
Cobordism_hypothesis.implication_form: If a fully extended TQFT is defined on framed n-manifolds, then it is equivalent to the free symmetric monoidal n-category with duals.
Cobordism_hypothesis.explained: The Cobordism Hypothesis (proven by Jacob Lurie) states that a fully extended C-valued topological quantum field theory (TQFT) defined on n-dimensional framed manifolds and all their lower-dimensional cobordisms (i.e., a symmetric monoidal (‚àû,n)-functor from the framed bordism category to a symmetric monoidal (‚àû,n)-category C with duals) is completely determined by its value on a single point (a point in the base space). This means that the entire algebraic data of the TQFT is encoded by how it assigns data to that single point. The hypothesis establishes an equivalence between the category of such TQFTs and the free symmetric monoidal (‚àû,n)-category with duals on a point.
related_conjectures: Classification of TQFTs in Lower Dimensions
Kervaire Invariant Conjecture (historically related via cobordism theory, but distinct)
Cobordism Conjecture (more generally about classifying manifolds via cobordisms, related but not identical)

Congruent_number.name: Congruent number
Congruent_number.rephrased: A congruent number is a positive integer that can be expressed as the area of a right-angled triangle with three rational number sides.
Congruent_number.implication_form: If a positive integer n can be expressed as the area of a rational-sided right-angled triangle, then n is a congruent number.
Congruent_number.posed_by: Euler (popularized, though the problem is ancient)
Congruent_number.explained: A positive integer n is congruent if and only if there exists a right-angled triangle with rational side lengths whose area is equal to n.

Connelly‚Äôs_blooming_conjecture.name: Connelly‚Äôs blooming conjecture
Connelly‚Äôs_blooming_conjecture.rephrased: Every convex polyhedron has at least one net that can be bloomed (folded without overlap) into the polyhedron.
Connelly‚Äôs_blooming_conjecture.implication_form: If a polyhedron is convex, then there exists a net that can be bloomed into the polyhedron.
Connelly‚Äôs_blooming_conjecture.explained: Connelly's blooming conjecture states that every net of a convex polyhedron admits a blooming. A net is a connected plane polygon (possibly with holes) obtained by cutting along edges of the polyhedron and unfolding it. A blooming is a continuous, one-to-one mapping from the net to a convex polyhedron that maps edges to edges, faces to faces, and vertices to vertices, and whose image is the entire polyhedron. The conjecture asserts that for any net of a convex polyhedron, there exists a way to fold it continuously into a convex polyhedron without self-intersection, forming a proper embedding.
terms: Net: A connected plane polygon obtained by cutting along edges of a polyhedron and unfolding it.
Blooming: A continuous, one-to-one mapping from a net to a polyhedron that maps edges to edges, faces to faces, and vertices to vertices, with the image being the entire polyhedron.
Convex Polyhedron: A polyhedron where all dihedral angles are less than 180 degrees and the surface is locally convex.
Proper Embedding: The resulting polyhedron from blooming is non-degenerate and matches the original polyhedron's combinatorial and metric properties.
related_conjectures: Bellows Conjecture: States that any flexible polyhedron with a spherical surface is rigid in terms of its combinatorial structure and cannot flex while maintaining its face shapes.
Net Enumeration Problem: The problem of counting the number of distinct nets for a given polyhedron.
Steinitz's Theorem: Relates the combinatorial structure of polyhedra to their geometric realization in 3D space.

Connes_embedding_problem.name: Connes embedding problem
Connes_embedding_problem.rephrased: Can complex infinite-dimensional systems (tracial von Neumann algebras) be faithfully mimicked by simpler finite systems (finite-dimensional matrices)?
Connes_embedding_problem.implication_form: If a tracial von Neumann algebra exists, then it can be approximated by finite-dimensional matrices.
Connes_embedding_problem.solved_by: The Connes Embedding Problem was shown to have a negative solution (i.e., not all tracial von Neumann algebras can be approximated by finite-dimensional matrices) as a corollary of the MIP*=RE result in 2020.
Connes_embedding_problem.explained: The Connes Embedding Problem (CEP) is a fundamental question in operator algebras. It asks whether every tracial von Neumann algebra can be approximated in the sense of being embeddable or approximable by finite-dimensional matrix algebras (or their ultraproducts). In simpler terms, it questioned if the complex structure of infinite-dimensional tracial von Neumann algebras could be faithfully captured by simpler, finite-dimensional systems. This conjecture remained open for decades until it was resolved negatively in 2020 as a consequence of the groundbreaking result that MIP* = RE.
related_conjectures: QWEP (Quantization of the word problem for groups) problem
MIP* = RE (the result itself resolved CEP)

Conway's_99-graph_problem.name: Conway's 99-graph problem
Conway's_99-graph_problem.rephrased: A graph with 99 vertices exists where: adjacent vertices share exactly one common neighbor, and non-adjacent vertices share exactly two common neighbors.
Conway's_99-graph_problem.implication_form: If a graph with 99 vertices exists where every pair of adjacent vertices has exactly one common neighbor, then every pair of non-adjacent vertices has exactly two common neighbors.
Conway's_99-graph_problem.explained: Conway's 99-graph problem is an unsolved existence question in graph theory. It asks whether there exists a graph with precisely 99 vertices satisfying two conditions: 1) For any two vertices that are adjacent (connected by an edge), they have exactly one common neighbor vertex. 2) For any two vertices that are not adjacent, they have exactly two common neighbor vertices.
related_conjectures: Existence of other strongly regular graphs with specific parameters
Problems concerning unique local structures in graphs
Conway's own explorations and related problems in combinatorial design

Conway's_thrackle_conjecture.name: Conway's thrackle conjecture
Conway's_thrackle_conjecture.rephrased: In any thrackle drawing (where edges meet exactly once at vertices or cross properly), the number of edges cannot exceed the number of vertices.
Conway's_thrackle_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph can be drawn as a thrackle, then it must have at most as many edges as vertices.
Conway's_thrackle_conjecture.explained: Conway's thrackle conjecture states that any graph which has a thrackle drawing (a drawing in the plane where every pair of edges meets exactly once, either at a common endpoint or at a proper crossing) must satisfy the condition that the number of edges is at most the number of vertices. In other words, a thrackleable graph (one that admits a thrackle drawing) can have no more edges than vertices.

Conway_knot.name: Conway knot
Conway_knot.rephrased: The Conway knot, a specific 11-crossing mathematical knot, is not slice, meaning it cannot be the boundary of a disk in four-dimensional space.
Conway_knot.explained: A Conway knot is an 11-crossing mathematical knot that was once considered a major challenge in knot theory. Despite being a well-defined knot and fooling numerous mathematical invariants that should have detected it as non-slice (meaning it cannot be the boundary of a disk in four-dimensional space), for decades mathematicians believed it might be slice. The conjecture surrounding the Conway knot specifically concerned whether it was a slice knot or not, with the initial confusion arising because it evaded all known methods to prove its non-slice nature.

Crouzeix's_conjecture.name: Crouzeix's conjecture
Crouzeix's_conjecture.rephrased: For any square complex matrix A and any complex polynomial p, the operator norm of p(A) is bounded by twice the maximum value that |p(z)| takes on the numerical range W(A) of A.
Crouzeix's_conjecture.implication_form: If A is a square complex matrix and p is a complex polynomial, then ||p(A)|| ‚â§ 2 * sup_{z‚ààW(A)} |p(z)|.
Crouzeix's_conjecture.explained: Crouze's conjecture states that for any square complex matrix \(A\) and any complex polynomial \(p\), the matrix norm of \(p(A)\) is bounded by twice the maximum value of \(|p(z)|\) for \(z\) in the numerical range \(W(A)\) of \(A\). This is expressed as \(\|p(A)\| \leq 2 \sup_{z \in W(A)} |p(z)|\). This inequality is conjectured to hold for all square complex matrices \(A\) and all complex polynomials \(p\), although it remains unproven.

terms.name: Matrix Norm
terms.definition: A function assigning a scalar to a matrix that quantifies its size; common examples include the operator norm and the Frobenius norm.

terms.name: Polynomial on Matrices
terms.definition: The evaluation of a polynomial at a matrix, defined recursively by \(p(A) = c_0 I + c_1 A + c_2 A^2 + \dots + c_n A^n\) for a polynomial \(p(z) = c_0 + c_1 z + \dots + c_n z^n\).

terms.name: Numerical Range
terms.definition: The set \(W(A) = \{ \langle Ax, x \rangle \mid \|x\| = 1 \}\), where \(\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle\) denotes the standard complex inner product and \(\|\cdot\|\) the associated norm. Also known as the field of values.

related_conjectures: The 4/3 conjecture (by Bhatia and Mondal), which proposes \(\|p(A)\| \leq \frac{4}{3} \sup_{z \in W(A)} |p(z)|\) and is weaker than Crouzeix's conjecture.
Bounds on the numerical radius and operator norms involving polynomials evaluated on matrices.

Dade's_conjecture.name: Dade's conjecture
Dade's_conjecture.rephrased: When a finite group has a trivial p-core, the number of irreducible characters in a p-block with positive defect can be counted using characters from blocks of its p-local subgroups.
Dade's_conjecture.implication_form: If a finite group G has trivial p-core and B is a p-block of G with positive defect, then the number of irreducible characters in B is less than or equal to the sum over certain p-local subgroups H of the number of irreducible characters in blocks of H that are 'Dade correspondent' to B.

Danzer_set.name: Danzer set
Danzer_set.rephrased: A Danzer set is a discrete collection of points such that every convex shape with a volume of one must contain at least one point from the set.
Danzer_set.implication_form: It is not straightforward to express this conjecture in the form 'If P, then Q' because the original statement defines the Danzer set property, and the core question is about the existence of a set satisfying this property.
Danzer_set.explained: A Danzer set is a set of points in n-dimensional Euclidean space such that every convex body with a volume of one intersects the set. This means that for any convex region (e.g., a hypercube, simplex, or ellipsoid) that has a volume of one, there is at least one point from the Danzer set lying within it. The trivial example is the entire space. The central open question posed by Ludwig Danzer is whether there exists a discrete Danzer set, i.e., a set with only a finite number of points in any bounded region (finite density), that satisfies this intersection property.

De_Bruijn-Newman_constant.name: De Bruijn‚ÄìNewman constant
De_Bruijn-Newman_constant.rephrased: The De Bruijn‚ÄìNewman constant is the largest number Œª such that all zeros of the function H(Œª, z) are real.
De_Bruijn-Newman_constant.implication_form: If the De Bruijn‚ÄìNewman constant is less than or equal to zero, then the Riemann hypothesis holds.
De_Bruijn-Newman_constant.posed_by: N.G. de Bruijn and Carl Newman
De_Bruijn-Newman_constant.explained: The De Bruijn‚ÄìNewman constant, denoted by \(\Lambda\), is a conjectured real number that characterizes the behavior of the function \(H(\lambda, z)\), defined as \(H(\lambda, z) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} e^{it\ z}  \Phi(\lambda, t)  dt\), where \(\Phi(\lambda, t)\) is an entire function. This function \(H(\lambda, z)\) is closely related to the Riemann zeta function. The conjecture states that \(\Lambda\) is the smallest real number such that all zeros of \(H(\lambda, z)\) are real for \(\lambda \geq \Lambda\). For \(\lambda < \Lambda\), some zeros are complex. A major implication is that the Riemann hypothesis, which posits that all non-trivial zeros of the Riemann zeta function are real, is equivalent to \(\Lambda \leq 0\).

Dedekind_number.name: Dedekind number
Dedekind_number.rephrased: Dedekind numbers are a sequence of integers that count the number of ways to color the corners of an n-dimensional cube with two colors (white and red) such that no white corner is above a red one, or equivalently, the number of monotone Boolean functions of n variables.

Dedekind_zeta_function.name: Dedekind zeta function
Dedekind_zeta_function.rephrased: The Dedekind zeta function is a complex function attached to an algebraic number field, constructed from a sum over the norms of its ideals. The conjecture states that this function can be continued analytically to the entire complex plane and possesses a simple pole only at s=1.
Dedekind_zeta_function.implication_form: If an algebraic number field is given, then its associated Dedekind zeta function can be analytically continued to the complex plane and has a simple pole only at s=1.
Dedekind_zeta_function.explained: The Dedekind zeta function is **defined** for a given algebraic number field K. It is a complex function Œ∂_K(s) that can be expressed as a Dirichlet series: Œ∂_K(s) = ‚àë_{I ‚äÇ O_K} N(I)^{-s}, where the sum runs over all non-zero integral ideals I of the ring of integers O_K, and N(I) denotes the norm of the ideal I. Crucially, this function can be meromorphically continued to the entire complex plane and satisfies a functional equation relating Œ∂_K(s) and Œ∂_K(1-s). It is not itself a conjecture but a fundamental object in algebraic number theory. Conjectures often arise concerning its properties, such as the location of its zeros (a generalization of the Riemann Hypothesis) or its connection to arithmetic invariants of the field.
related_conjectures: Riemann Hypothesis (generalized to Dedekind zeta functions)
Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer Conjecture (relating L-functions to arithmetic)
Artin Conjecture (for L-functions associated to representations)
Langlands Program (relating automorphic forms to L-functions including Dedekind zeta functions)

Degree_diameter_problem.name: Degree diameter problem
Degree_diameter_problem.rephrased: What's the maximum number of nodes in a graph where each node has at most 'd' connections and the farthest any two nodes are is 'k' steps?
Degree_diameter_problem.implication_form: If a graph has maximum degree d and diameter k, then it has at most n vertices (for specific d, k, and n).

Dehn_invariant.name: Dehn invariant
Dehn_invariant.rephrased: A polyhedron has a Dehn invariant, a value calculated from its edge lengths and dihedral angles. Two polyhedra can be cut apart and reassembled into each other (scissors-congruent) only if they have the same volume and the same Dehn invariant.
Dehn_invariant.implication_form: If two polyhedra have the same volume and the same Dehn invariant, then they can be dissected into each other.
Dehn_invariant.explained: The Dehn invariant is a value defined for a polyhedron, combining information about its edge lengths and the angles between its faces (dihedral angles). Formally, for a polyhedron, it is defined as the set { l * cot(Œ∏) } where the set includes one term for each edge, 'l' being the length of the edge and 'Œ∏' being the internal dihedral angle of the polyhedron at that edge. Two convex polyhedra are scissors-congruent (can be dissected into each other by cutting along faces and reassembling the pieces) if and only if they have the same volume and the same Dehn invariant. Although named a 'conjecture' in the prompt, Dehn's theorem proves this statement, showing it is a characterization (a theorem), not an open conjecture.
related_conjectures: Hilbert's third problem (which Dehn's theorem resolved)
subjects: Group theory (aspects of combining lengths and angles)

Deligne's_conjecture_on_Hochschild_cohom.name: Deligne's conjecture on Hochschild cohomology
Deligne's_conjecture_on_Hochschild_cohom.rephrased: The Hochschild cochain complex of an associative algebra is an algebra over the little disks operad.
Deligne's_conjecture_on_Hochschild_cohom.implication_form: If A is an associative algebra, then its Hochschild cochain complex is an algebra over the little disks operad.

Deligne_conjecture.name: Deligne conjecture
Deligne_conjecture.rephrased: The conjecture, now a theorem, states that the special value of an L-function associated with a motive, when evaluated at a specific 'critical' integer, is equal to the determinant of the period matrix of that motive.
Deligne_conjecture.implication_form: If a motive exists and its L-function is evaluated at a critical integer, then the value of the L-function equals the determinant of the motive's period matrix.
Deligne_conjecture.solved_by: The conjecture was proven by mathematicians (various proofs exist for the different formulations, e.g., related to the Kashiwara-Schapira work for the operad part and others for the L-function part).
Deligne_conjecture.explained: Deligne's conjecture primarily addresses two interconnected aspects. First, it proposes a formula relating the absolute value of an L-function associated with a motive (a fundamental object in arithmetic geometry) at a positive integer (the 'special value') to an invariant derived from the Hodge structure (period matrix) of that motive. This relates to the broader conjectures about special values of L-functions. Second, it states that the Hochschild cochain complex of an associative algebra naturally carries the structure of a dg-algebra over the operad of chains of the little disks operad. This second part has been proven, while the first part concerning L-functions is more deeply rooted in the theory of motives and Hodge structures.

Demazure_conjecture.name: Demazure conjecture
Demazure_conjecture.rephrased: The conjecture states that the Demazure character formula, which describes characters of certain representations, holds generally for representations of algebraic groups over fields of characteristic zero, allowing extensions beyond complex representations.
Demazure_conjecture.implication_form: If the representation is of an algebraic group over a field of characteristic zero, then the Demazure character formula applies.
Demazure_conjecture.explained: The Demazure conjecture, now a proven theorem, asserts that the Demazure character formula holds for representations of complex semisimple algebraic groups (or their associated flag varieties) over any field of characteristic zero. More precisely, it states that the character of a certain representation (constructed via Demazure operators) coincides with the character given by a specific formula involving the root system and the Weyl group, and this formula remains valid regardless of the specific field (e.g., complex numbers, p-adic fields, etc.) as long as the characteristic is zero.
related_conjectures: Conjectures related to extending the results to positive characteristic (though this is generally more difficult and not fully achieved in all cases), conjectures concerning integral forms or representations over the integers
Conjectures about generalizations to Kac-Moody algebras or affine groups (e.g., in the context of geometric crystals or the affine Demazure conjecture)
Conjectures related to the BGG resolution or Koszul duality

Determinant.name: Determinant
Determinant.rephrased: The determinant is a scalar value from a square matrix that represents the scaling factor of the linear transformation it describes. A determinant of zero indicates the matrix is singular and not invertible.
Determinant.implication_form: If the determinant of a square matrix is zero, then the matrix is singular.
Determinant.explained: A determinant is a scalar value that can be calculated from the entries of a square matrix. It represents the scaling factor by which areas (in two dimensions) or volumes (in higher dimensions) are transformed under the linear transformation represented by the matrix. A determinant of zero indicates that the matrix is singular, meaning it does not have an inverse and does not represent a volume-preserving transformation (the vectors are linearly dependent). The determinant also carries information about the orientation of the transformation (positive for preserving orientation, negative for reversing it). It is defined recursively for 1x1 matrices and extended via methods like cofactor expansion or the Leibniz formula for larger matrices. Determinants are fundamental in various areas of mathematics and its applications, such as solving systems of linear equations via Cramer's rule, computing eigenvalues, and characterizing invertible matrices.

Determinantal_conjecture.name: Determinantal conjecture
Determinantal_conjecture.rephrased: The determinant of the sum of two n by n normal complex matrices is itself a combination of the eigenvalues from each matrix, specifically one from A and one from B, arranged in every possible order, and this value must lie within the set of all such possible combinations.
Determinantal_conjecture.implication_form: If A and B are two n√ón normal complex matrices, then the determinant of their sum is contained within the convex hull formed by all products of eigenvalues from A and B taken in every possible permutation.
Determinantal_conjecture.posed_by: Ralph Philip Boas, Jr., Marvin Marcus, and Henryk Micha≈Çek (originally stated by Boas; named after Marcus and de Oliveira)
Determinantal_conjecture.explained: The Determinantal conjecture (Marcus-de Oliveira conjecture) states that for two normal complex matrices A and B of size n√ón, with eigenvalues œÉ(A) = {a‚ÇÅ, ‚Ä¶, a‚Çô} and œÉ(B) = {b‚ÇÅ, ‚Ä¶, b‚Çô}, the determinant of their sum, det(A+B), lies in the convex hull of the set of points {‚àè_{k=1}^{n} (a_{œÉ(k)} b_{œÑ(k)}) for all permutations œÉ, œÑ of {1,2,‚Ä¶,n}. This conjecture concerns the determinant of the sum of two normal matrices and its relation to the eigenvalues.

related_conjectures.name: B√∂ttcher-Westwick conjecture
related_conjectures.description: A related conjecture that addresses the determinant of the sum of two Hermitian matrices, proposing a similar convex hull condition.

Dickson's_conjecture.name: Dickson's conjecture
Dickson's_conjecture.rephrased: If a finite set of linear forms (like n+b1, n+b2, etc.) doesn't have any 'local obstacle' (such as divisibility issues by small primes) that always prevents them from all being prime for some n, then there are infinitely many integers n where all forms evaluate to prime numbers.
Dickson's_conjecture.implication_form: If a finite set of linear forms (ai*n + bi) has no congruence condition preventing all forms from being simultaneously prime for some integer n, then there are infinitely many integers n for which all forms evaluate to prime numbers.

Diophantine_equation.name: Diophantine equation
Diophantine_equation.rephrased: A Diophantine equation is a polynomial equation with integer coefficients that is solved over the integers.
Diophantine_equation.implication_form: If a polynomial equation has integer coefficients and we seek integer solutions, then it is a Diophantine equation.
Diophantine_equation.posed_by: Ancient Greek mathematicians (e.g., Diophantus of Alexandria)
Diophantine_equation.solved_by: Many specific cases have been solved; general solution methods remain an active area of research. Some famous conjectures (like Fermat's Last Theorem) were proven.
Diophantine_equation.explained: A Diophantine equation is a polynomial equation with integer coefficients, typically involving one or more variables, for which integer solutions (or sometimes rational solutions) are sought. The term 'Diophantine equation' is named after the ancient Greek mathematician Diophantus of Alexandria. These equations are fundamental in number theory and involve finding solutions in integers (or rationals) to algebraic equations with integer coefficients. The general form is: P(x‚ÇÅ, x‚ÇÇ, ..., xn) = 0, where P is a polynomial with integer coefficients, and we seek integer tuples (a‚ÇÅ, a‚ÇÇ, ..., an) satisfying the equation.
related_conjectures: Fermat's Last Theorem (Historically central, now proven)
Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer Conjecture (Relates to the number of rational solutions for elliptic curves)
ABC Conjecture (A deep conjecture with implications for many Diophantine problems)
Mordell-Lang Conjecture (Now a theorem, related to rational points on varieties)

Dirichlet_L-function.name: Dirichlet L-function
Dirichlet_L-function.rephrased: The Dirichlet L-function is a complex function that generalizes the Riemann zeta function and is used to study the distribution of prime numbers in arithmetic progressions defined by a Dirichlet character.
Dirichlet_L-function.implication_form: If the Dirichlet L-function does not vanish at s=1, then there are infinitely many primes in the arithmetic progression defined by the character.
Dirichlet_L-function.solved_by: Peter Gustav Dirichlet (for the Dirichlet theorem on arithmetic progressions)
Dirichlet_L-function.explained: A Dirichlet L-function is defined for a Dirichlet character œá modulo q as the analytic continuation of the L-series ‚àë_{n=1}^‚àû œá(n)/n^s, where s is a complex variable with real part œÉ > 1. This function, denoted by L(s, œá), is a meromorphic function on the complex plane and generalizes the Riemann zeta function Œ∂(s) (which corresponds to the principal Dirichlet character modulo 1 or modulo q for q prime). It plays a crucial role in number theory, particularly in the Dirichlet density theorem, which states that any arithmetic progression containing infinitely many primes has a density (related to the Dirichlet density) proportional to 1/œÜ(q), and this density can be expressed using the values of L(s, œá) at s=1.
related_conjectures: Euler's conjecture (on the order of vanishing at s=1)

Dissection_into_orthoschemes.name: Dissection into orthoschemes
Dissection_into_orthoschemes.implication_form: If a simplex exists, then it can be dissected into orthoschemes
Dissection_into_orthoschemes.explained: An orthoscheme is a simplex characterized by having right dihedral angles along all edges connecting two specific vertices, typically referred to as the apex and the base. The dissection into orthoschemes conjecture posits that any given simplex (a generalization of a tetrahedron to higher dimensions) can be completely dissected, or decomposed, into a finite number of such orthoschemes. This dissection involves cutting the simplex along its faces and edges to form these specific right-angled tetrahedral (or higher-dimensional) pieces.
related_conjectures: Dissection of polyhedra into equal volume pieces

Dittert_conjecture.name: Dittert conjecture
Dittert_conjecture.rephrased: For an n x n matrix with non-negative entries summing to n, the function œÜ(X) = (product of row sums) + (product of column sums) - permanent(X) is maximized only when all entries are equal to 1/n.
Dittert_conjecture.implication_form: If X is an n x n matrix with non-negative entries summing to n, then œÜ(X) is maximized only if X is the matrix J_n with all entries 1/n.
Dittert_conjecture.explained: The Dittert conjecture, also known as the Dittert‚ÄìHajek conjecture, is a hypothesis in combinatorics. It states that for any n x n matrix X with non-negative entries summing to n, the function œÜ(X) defined as the product of all row sums (‚àè_{i=1}^n r_i) plus the product of all column sums (‚àè_{j=1}^n c_j) minus the permanent of X (per(X)), achieves its unique maximum value when X is the matrix J_n, where every entry is 1/n.
related_conjectures: van der Waerden conjecture (for doubly stochastic matrices)

Dixmier_conjecture.name: Dixmier conjecture
Dixmier_conjecture.rephrased: Every endomorphism of the first Weyl algebra is invertible (an automorphism).
Dixmier_conjecture.implication_form: If a map is an algebra endomorphism, then it is an algebra automorphism.

Dodecahedral_conjecture.name: Dodecahedral conjecture
Dodecahedral_conjecture.rephrased: In any packing of identical spheres, the volume of the space surrounding a single sphere is minimized when the shape of that space is a regular dodecahedron.
Dodecahedral_conjecture.implication_form: If there exists a packing of unit spheres in three-dimensional Euclidean space, then the volume of the Voronoi cell associated with any sphere is at least the volume of a regular dodecahedron with inradius one.
Dodecahedral_conjecture.explained: The Dodecahedral Conjecture states that in any packing of congruent unit spheres in three-dimensional Euclidean space, the volume of the Voronoi cell associated with each sphere is at least the volume of a regular dodecahedron with an inradius of one.

Donaldson-Thomas_theory.name: Donaldson‚ÄìThomas theory
Donaldson-Thomas_theory.rephrased: Mathematicians can count certain geometric objects in special spaces called Calabi-Yau threefolds using special counting methods.
Donaldson-Thomas_theory.implication_form: If there is a compact moduli space of stable sheaves (or other objects) in a Calabi-Yau 3-fold, then invariants can be defined to count them.
Donaldson-Thomas_theory.explained: Donaldson‚ÄìThomas theory provides a mathematical framework for defining enumerative invariants for Calabi‚ÄìYau threefolds. It defines invariants, known as Donaldson‚ÄìThomas invariants, which count the number of stable sheaves (or other objects like complexes) on a Calabi‚ÄìYau threefold, using a 'virtual fundamental class' or 'virtual cycle' on the moduli space of these objects. The core conjecture or definition involves constructing this virtual cycle, which allows for a consistent and stable count even when the moduli space is not smooth or has singularities. The existence of a compact moduli space of stable sheaves is a crucial prerequisite for this construction, but the conjecture itself primarily concerns the definition and properties of the DT invariants derived from the virtual count.
