related_conjectures: Connection to string theory (e.g., via M-theory)
Peyre's conjecture (related to counting lattice points, sometimes used in DT contexts)

Double_bubble_conjecture.name: Double bubble conjecture
Double_bubble_conjecture.rephrased: The Double Bubble Conjecture states that the minimal surface area configuration for enclosing two separate volumes in 3D space is a double bubble shape consisting of three spherical caps meeting along a shared circle at 120-degree angles.
Double_bubble_conjecture.implication_form: If two volumes are enclosed by a surface in 3D space, then the configuration with the minimal surface area is the standard double bubble shape.
Double_bubble_conjecture.posed_by: The conjecture refers to the widely believed minimal surface configuration, but specific attribution to original proposers is unclear; it emerged from the study of soap films and minimal surfaces.
Double_bubble_conjecture.solved_by: Michael Hutchings, Frank Morgan, Manuel Ritor√©, and Antonio Ros (proven in 2000)

Duffin-Schaeffer_theorem.name: Duffin‚ÄìSchaeffer theorem
Duffin-Schaeffer_theorem.rephrased: A function f(q) allows almost all real numbers to be well approximated by rationals a/q (with gcd(a,q)=1) infinitely often if the series ‚àë œÜ(q)f(q)/q diverges.
Duffin-Schaeffer_theorem.implication_form: If the series ‚àë_{q=1}^{‚àû} œÜ(q)f(q)/q diverges, then for almost all real numbers x, there are infinitely many integers q and a (with gcd(a,q)=1) such that |x - a/q| < f(q).
Duffin-Schaeffer_theorem.posed_by: R. J. Duffin and A. C. Schaeffer

Earth-Moon_problem.name: Earth‚ÄìMoon problem
Earth-Moon_problem.rephrased: Find the minimum number of colors needed to color all regions in two overlapping maps (like Earth and Moon) such that: (1) Each region in the first map has a unique corresponding region in the second map; (2) Corresponding regions must share the same color; (3) Adjacent regions within either map must have different colors.
Earth-Moon_problem.implication_form: If two regions are adjacent (share a border) on either map, then they must be colored differently.
Earth-Moon_problem.posed_by: Originator not definitively identified, associated with research on planar graph coloring (e.g., related to the four-color theorem)
Earth-Moon_problem.explained: The Earth‚ÄìMoon problem is a conjecture in graph theory concerning the chromatic number of a specific type of graph called a biplanar graph. It asks for the minimum number of colors required to color a map consisting of regions on both the Earth and the Moon, where each Earth region has a corresponding colony on the Moon. The coloring must ensure that each region and its colony share the same color, and any two regions (on Earth or the Moon) that share a border must have different colors.

Eden's_conjecture.name: Eden's conjecture
Eden's_conjecture.rephrased: The limiting shape of the Eden growth model is a Euclidean ball.
Eden's_conjecture.implication_form: If the growth process follows the Eden model, then the limit shape is a Euclidean ball.
Eden's_conjecture.explained: Eden's conjecture, proposed by Alp Eden in 1987, addresses the Eden growth model, a stochastic process modeling the expansion of bacterial colonies or tumors. The core conjecture states that, regardless of the specific random sequence driving the growth process, the shape of the aggregate (the set of occupied sites) approaches a Euclidean ball (a sphere in n-dimensional space) as the process continues indefinitely, provided the growth occurs in two or three dimensions. This limit shape is assumed to be isotropic (uniform in all directions). While the conjecture appears plausible and holds empirically in low-dimensional settings (like two dimensions), it has been rigorously disproven for dimensions greater than 22.
related_conjectures: Limit shape conjectures for other random growth models (e.g., Ballistic Deposition, Surface Growth models)
Conformal invariance conjectures in two-dimensional critical systems
Shape theorem conjectures for various lattice models

Ehrenpreis_conjecture.name: Ehrenpreis conjecture
Ehrenpreis_conjecture.rephrased: Any two closed surfaces with genus at least 2 have finite covers that are geometrically very similar, differing only slightly in distortion.
Ehrenpreis_conjecture.implication_form: If S and T are any two closed Riemann surfaces of genus at least 2, then there exist finite-degree covers of S and T and a diffeomorphism between these covers with small distortion.
Ehrenpreis_conjecture.posed_by: Ehrenpreis (attributed to him, exact proposer not specified in the query)
Ehrenpreis_conjecture.year_originated: around 60 years ago (estimated based on context)
Ehrenpreis_conjecture.explained: The Ehrenpreis conjecture states that any two closed Riemann surfaces of genus at least 2 admit finite-degree covers that are geometrically close. Geometrically close means there exists a diffeomorphism between them with bounded distortion (small stretching). This conjecture was proven by Jeremy Kahn and Vladimir Markovic in 2012, making it a theorem. The theorem establishes a strong connection between any two such surfaces by showing their finite covers can be made arbitrarily close in their geometric properties.

Ehrhart's_volume_conjecture.name: Ehrhart's volume conjecture
Ehrhart's_volume_conjecture.rephrased: If a convex body has its center of mass at the origin and contains no other lattice points inside, then its volume must be at most \((n+1)^n / n!\).
Ehrhart's_volume_conjecture.implication_form: If a convex body has its barycenter at the origin and contains only the origin as an interior lattice point, then its volume is less than or equal to \((n+1)^n / n!\).
Ehrhart's_volume_conjecture.explained: Ehrhart's volume conjecture states that for an n-dimensional convex body K ‚äÇ ‚Ñù‚Åø with its barycenter at the origin, if K contains no other lattice points besides the origin in its interior, then the volume of K must satisfy vol(K) ‚â§ (n+1)‚Åø / n!. This conjecture provides an upper bound on the volume under the specified conditions.

Eilenberg-Ganea_conjecture.name: Eilenberg‚ÄìGanea conjecture
Eilenberg-Ganea_conjecture.rephrased: If a group has cohomological dimension 2, then it can be represented by a 2-dimensional Eilenberg-MacLane space.
Eilenberg-Ganea_conjecture.implication_form: If a group has cohomological dimension 2, then it has geometric dimension 2.
Eilenberg-Ganea_conjecture.explained: The Eilenberg‚ÄìGanea conjecture states that if a group G has cohomological dimension 2 (cd(G) = 2), then it also has geometric dimension 2. Geometric dimension 2 means that G admits a 2-dimensional Eilenberg‚ÄìMacLane space (aspherical CW complex).

Eilenberg-MacLane_space.name: Eilenberg‚ÄìMacLane space
Eilenberg-MacLane_space.explained: An Eilenberg-MacLane space is a connected topological space in algebraic topology that has only one nontrivial homotopy group. For a given group \(G\) and a positive integer \(n\), an Eilenberg-MacLane space of type \((G, n)\) is a space whose \(n\)-th homotopy group is isomorphic to \(G\) and all other homotopy groups are trivial. These spaces are fundamental in algebraic topology for classifying spaces up to homotopy equivalence, defining cohomology groups, and serving as 'building blocks' for more complex spaces.

Einstein_problem.name: Einstein problem
Einstein_problem.rephrased: Prove that there exists a single shape (an 'einstein') that can tile the plane without forming a periodic pattern.
Einstein_problem.implication_form: If a shape is an einstein, then it can tile the plane aperiodically.
Einstein_problem.explained: The Einstein problem refers to the mathematical conjecture (or open problem) of finding a single aperiodic tile, known as an 'einstein', which can tile the plane (i.e., fill the plane without gaps or overlaps) but does so without creating a periodic (repeating) tiling pattern. An einstein tile would be a shape that admits an aperiodic tiling by itself, making it the minimal such tile. This problem remains unsolved; no such single tile has been found yet.
terms: The Einstein riddle (as a separate logic puzzle, despite the name misattribution)
related_conjectures: The original problem of finding a single aperiodic tile (Wang tiles)
The problem of finding a smaller set of tiles that form an aperiodic tiling (e.g., Penrose tiles)

Elliott-Halberstam_conjecture.name: Elliott‚ÄìHalberstam conjecture
Elliott-Halberstam_conjecture.rephrased: Primes are distributed evenly in arithmetic progressions with the same density as predicted by the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis.
Elliott-Halberstam_conjecture.implication_form: If the primes are distributed with error bounded as in the Elliott‚ÄìHalberstam conjecture, then there are infinitely many twin primes.
Elliott-Halberstam_conjecture.explained: The Elliott‚ÄìHalberstam conjecture pertains to the distribution of prime numbers within arithmetic progressions. Specifically, it concerns the error term in the prime-counting function for primes up to x that are congruent to a fixed residue class modulo q, as x tends to infinity. The conjecture states that for any fixed A > 0, the sum over residue classes a modulo q (coprime to q) of the square of the error term (the difference between the number of primes up to x in that class and the expected number based on the prime number theorem for arithmetic progressions) is bounded by x^2 / (log x)^A, provided that q is bounded by x^Œµ for any Œµ > 0. In simpler terms, it asserts that primes are unusually evenly distributed across arithmetic progressions with coprime moduli, significantly better than what can be guaranteed by methods not relying on the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis (GRH).
terms: Prime number theorem for arithmetic progressions
related_conjectures: Bounded gaps conjecture (now a theorem due to Zhang et al.)

Ending_lamination_theorem.name: Ending lamination theorem
Ending_lamination_theorem.rephrased: A complete hyperbolic 3-manifold is uniquely determined by its topological type and the geometric structures (conformal at finite ends or ending laminations at infinite ends) of its ends.
Ending_lamination_theorem.implication_form: If two complete hyperbolic 3-manifolds are topologically equivalent and have identical end invariants (conformal structures for finite ends or ending laminations for infinite ends), then they are isometric (geometrically identical).
Ending_lamination_theorem.explained: The Ending Lamination Theorem is a fundamental theorem in the study of hyperbolic 3-manifolds. It states that if two complete, orientable hyperbolic 3-manifolds are homeomorphic, then they are isometric if and only if they have the same ending invariants. For a geometrically infinite end, the ending invariant is a geodesic lamination (called the ending lamination) on the corresponding punctured torus boundary. For a geometrically finite end, the ending invariant is the conformal structure at infinity. The theorem uniquely determines the hyperbolic structure of the manifold from its topology and these ending invariants.

Erd≈ës-Faber-Lov√°sz_conjecture.name: Erd≈ës‚ÄìFaber‚ÄìLov√°sz conjecture
Erd≈ës-Faber-Lov√°sz_conjecture.rephrased: If a graph is formed by overlapping complete graphs (cliques) of size n, with each clique containing n vertices and any two cliques sharing at most one vertex, then the entire graph can be colored using only n colors.
Erd≈ës-Faber-Lov√°sz_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph is the union of n complete subgraphs, each having exactly n vertices, and every pair of these complete subgraphs shares at most one common vertex, then the chromatic number of the graph is at most n.
Erd≈ës-Faber-Lov√°sz_conjecture.posed_by: Paul Erd≈ës, Zdenƒõk Faber, and √Ågnes Szendrei (commonly known as Lov√°sz)
Erd≈ës-Faber-Lov√°sz_conjecture.explained: The Erd≈ës‚ÄìFaber‚ÄìLov√°sz conjecture states that if a graph G is the union of n complete subgraphs (cliques), each containing exactly n vertices, and any two of these cliques share at most one vertex, then the chromatic number œá(G) is at most n.
related_conjectures: Conjectures on the chromatic index of linear hypergraphs

Erd≈ës-Graham_problem.name: Erd≈ës‚ÄìGraham problem
Erd≈ës-Graham_problem.rephrased: If all integers greater than one are colored with a finite number of colors, then at least one color class contains a finite set of numbers whose reciprocals sum to 1.
Erd≈ës-Graham_problem.implication_form: If the integers greater than one are partitioned into k subsets, then at least one subset contains a finite subset with reciprocals summing to 1.
Erd≈ës-Graham_problem.solved_by: The original coloring conjecture was proven by Erich S. Croot; the density version remains unsolved.
Erd≈ës-Graham_problem.explained: The Erd≈ës‚ÄìGraham problem concerns the coloring of integers greater than one with a finite number of colors. The conjecture states that in any such coloring, at least one color class must contain a finite subset of integers whose reciprocals sum to 1. This original coloring version of the conjecture has been proven true. The density version, which states that any set of integers with positive asymptotic density must contain such a subset, remains an open problem.

Erd≈ës-Gy√°rf√°s_conjecture.name: Erd≈ës‚ÄìGy√°rf√°s conjecture
Erd≈ës-Gy√°rf√°s_conjecture.explained: The Erd≈ës‚ÄìGy√°rf√°s conjecture states that every finite graph with a minimum degree of at least three (Œ¥(G) ‚â• 3) must contain a cycle whose length is a power of two (i.e., a cycle of length 2·µè for some integer k ‚â• 0). In logical terms, the conjecture can be restated as: If a graph has minimum degree at least three, then it contains a cycle of length a power of two.
related_conjectures: Erd≈ës‚ÄìGallai theorem (a different conjecture in graph theory)
Existence of Hamiltonian cycles (cycles visiting every vertex)

Erd≈ës-Hajnal_conjecture.name: Erd≈ës‚ÄìHajnal conjecture
Erd≈ës-Hajnal_conjecture.explained: The Erd≈ës‚ÄìHajnal conjecture states that for any graph H, there exists a constant c > 0 such that every graph G that does not contain H as an induced subgraph has either a clique (complete subgraph) or an independent set (stable set) of size at least |V(G)|^c. This means that forbidding a specific graph pattern as an induced subgraph guarantees the existence of a very large clique or independent set, exhibiting polynomial growth in the size of the graph. The conjecture has been proven for specific graphs H, such as the 5-cycle.
related_conjectures: The existence of large cliques or independent sets in graphs with forbidden subgraphs

Erd≈ës-Menger_conjecture.name: Erd≈ës‚ÄìMenger conjecture
Erd≈ës-Menger_conjecture.rephrased: In any infinite graph, if there are two distinct sets of vertices, there exist infinitely many vertex-disjoint paths connecting them, and a way to 'separate' these paths by selecting one vertex from each path.
Erd≈ës-Menger_conjecture.implication_form: If G is an infinite graph and A, B are two distinct vertex sets in G, then there exist infinitely many vertex-disjoint A-B paths, and there exists a set of vertices (one from each path) that separates these paths.
Erd≈ës-Menger_conjecture.explained: The Erd≈ës‚ÄìMenger conjecture states: For any infinite graph G and any two distinct vertices or vertex sets A and B in G, there exists a collection of vertex-disjoint paths connecting A to B, and there also exists a corresponding set of vertices (called an A-B separator) that intersects each of these paths exactly once. This conjecture provided a profound extension of Menger's theorem from finite to infinite graphs and was later proven to be true, becoming the Erd≈ës‚ÄìMenger theorem.
related_conjectures: Theorems on vertex connectivity and edge connectivity

Erd≈ës-Moser_equation.name: Erd≈ës‚ÄìMoser equation
Erd≈ës-Moser_equation.explained: The Erd≈ës‚ÄìMoser conjecture states that the Diophantine equation \(\sum_{i=1}^{m-1} i^k = m^k\) has no positive integer solutions for \(k \geq 2\). The only known integer solution is \((k, m) = (1, 3)\), which satisfies \(1^1 + 2^1 = 3^1\).

Erd≈ës-Straus_conjecture.name: Erd≈ës‚ÄìStraus conjecture
Erd≈ës-Straus_conjecture.rephrased: For every integer n greater than or equal to 2, the fraction 4/n can be written as the sum of three unit fractions.
Erd≈ës-Straus_conjecture.implication_form: If n is an integer greater than or equal to 2, then there exist positive integers x, y, and z such that 4/n = 1/x + 1/y + 1/z.
Erd≈ës-Straus_conjecture.posed_by: Paul Erd≈ës and Ronald M. Straus

Erd≈ës-Tur√°n_conjecture_on_additive_bas.name: Erd≈ës‚ÄìTur√°n conjecture on additive bases
Erd≈ës-Tur√°n_conjecture_on_additive_bas.rephrased: A set of integers that covers all sufficiently large numbers as sums of two of its elements must have some numbers represented as such sums in arbitrarily many ways.
Erd≈ës-Tur√°n_conjecture_on_additive_bas.implication_form: If a set A of non-negative integers is an asymptotic additive basis of order 2, then the number of ways to represent integers as sums of two elements from A must be unbounded.
Erd≈ës-Tur√°n_conjecture_on_additive_bas.explained: The Erd≈ës‚ÄìTur√°n conjecture on additive bases states that if a set A of non-negative integers is an asymptotic additive basis of order 2 (meaning every sufficiently large integer can be expressed as the sum of two elements from A), then the number of ways to represent sufficiently large integers as the sum of two elements from A must be unbounded. In other words, there exist integers that can be written as a sum of two elements from A in arbitrarily many ways.

Erd≈ës-Ulam_problem.name: Erd≈ës‚ÄìUlam problem
Erd≈ës-Ulam_problem.rephrased: Is there a set of points densely filling the plane where the distance between any two points is rational?
Erd≈ës-Ulam_problem.implication_form: If the Bombieri‚ÄìLang conjecture is true, then there is no dense set in the plane with all rational distances.

Erd≈ës_conjecture_on_arithmetic_progress.name: Erd≈ës conjecture on arithmetic progressions
Erd≈ës_conjecture_on_arithmetic_progress.rephrased: A set of positive integers containing arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions has a divergent sum of reciprocals.
Erd≈ës_conjecture_on_arithmetic_progress.implication_form: If the sum of the reciprocals of the elements of a set of positive integers diverges, then the set contains arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions.
Erd≈ës_conjecture_on_arithmetic_progress.explained: The Erd≈ës conjecture on arithmetic progressions states that any subset of the positive integers that contains an infinite number of terms (i.e., the sum of the reciprocals of its elements diverges) must contain arithmetic progressions of arbitrary length (progressions of any finite length).

Erd≈ës_discrepancy_problem.name: Erd≈ës discrepancy problem
Erd≈ës_discrepancy_problem.rephrased: Every infinite sequence of +1s and -1s has a homogeneous arithmetic progression with arbitrarily large discrepancy.
Erd≈ës_discrepancy_problem.implication_form: If the sequence is infinite (+1/-1), then for every constant C, there exists a homogeneous arithmetic progression with discrepancy greater than C.
Erd≈ës_discrepancy_problem.explained: The Erd≈ës discrepancy problem concerns infinite sequences consisting of +1 and -1. It states that for any such sequence and any positive constant C, there exists a homogeneous arithmetic progression (a subsequence where the indices form an arithmetic progression with common difference d, and the terms are taken at those indices) whose sum (discrepancy) exceeds C. In other words, the partial sums over these progressions can be made arbitrarily large in absolute value.
related_conjectures: Discrepancy theory conjectures (e.g., regarding other combinatorial structures)
Theorems related to subsequences in additive combinatorics
Problems involving bounded discrepancy in other contexts

Erd≈ës_distinct_distances_problem.name: Erd≈ës distinct distances problem
Erd≈ës_distinct_distances_problem.rephrased: What is the minimum number of distinct distances that must be present in any set of n points arranged in the plane?
Erd≈ës_distinct_distances_problem.implication_form: If a set P contains n points in the Euclidean plane, then the number of distinct distances determined by P is believed to be at least c * n / log n for some constant c and sufficiently large n.
Erd≈ës_distinct_distances_problem.explained: The Erd≈ës distinct distances problem has two main aspects. First, it asks for the minimum number of distinct distances determined by a set of n points in the Euclidean plane, specifically for sets that are optimally arranged to minimize this number. Second, it asks for the minimum number of distinct distances guaranteed by any set of n points in the plane. For large n, the minimum number for optimally arranged points is Œ©(n / log n), and the minimum guaranteed number is Œ©(n^{1/2}), though the exact asymptotic bounds for both remain partially unresolved. The widely accepted answer for the plane's minimum number is roughly n / log n.

Erd≈ës_sumset_conjecture.name: Erd≈ës sumset conjecture
Erd≈ës_sumset_conjecture.rephrased: If a subset of the natural numbers is dense (has positive density), then it must contain all possible sums of two infinite subsets.
Erd≈ës_sumset_conjecture.implication_form: If a subset A of the natural numbers has positive density, then A contains the sumset B+C for two infinite sets B and C.
Erd≈ës_sumset_conjecture.explained: The Erd≈ës sumset conjecture states that any subset A of the natural numbers with positive upper density must contain a sumset B+C, where B and C are infinite subsets of A. In other words, there exist two infinite subsets B and C of A such that every element in the sumset {b+c | b ‚àà B, c ‚àà C} is also contained in A.

Euclid-Mullin_sequence.name: Euclid‚ÄìMullin sequence
Euclid-Mullin_sequence.rephrased: A sequence of distinct primes begins with 2, and each subsequent term is the smallest prime factor of the product of all previous terms plus one.
Euclid-Mullin_sequence.implication_form: If a sequence is generated by taking the smallest prime factor of (1 + the product of all previous terms), then all terms are prime.
Euclid-Mullin_sequence.explained: The Euclid‚ÄìMullin sequence is a specific sequence defined by the following rule: It starts with the prime number 2. Each subsequent term is the smallest prime factor of the number (1 plus the product of all the previous terms). Formally, if the sequence is denoted as p_1, p_2, p_3, ..., then p_1 = 2, and for n >= 2, p_n is the smallest prime factor of (1 + ‚àè_{i=1}^{n-1} p_i). This sequence is infinite, as shown by its construction based on Euclid's proof of the infinitude of primes, but it is not known whether every prime number will eventually appear in the sequence.
related_conjectures: Infinitude of primes (established theorem, but foundational to the sequence's construction)
Primorial conjecture (related to the product of primes)

Euclid_number.name: Euclid number
Euclid_number.rephrased: A Euclid number is defined as the primorial of the nth prime number plus one.
Euclid_number.implication_form: If n is a natural number, then the nth Euclid number is the primorial of the nth prime plus one.

Euclidean_space.name: Euclidean space
Euclidean_space.explained: Euclidean space is defined as a geometric space characterized by the axioms of Euclidean geometry. Key properties include: 1) The parallel postulate (parallel lines never meet), 2) The sum of angles in a triangle is always 180 degrees, and 3) The existence of a consistent notion of distance and angle. It exists in any number of dimensions, denoted as \( \mathbb{R}^n \) for dimension n, where \( \mathbb{R}^1 \) is a line, \( \mathbb{R}^2 \) is a plane, and \( \mathbb{R}^3 \) is the standard three-dimensional space.
related_conjectures: The foundations of geometry (e.g., independence of the parallel postulate)
Conjectures regarding the dimensionality of the universe
Relationship between Euclidean geometry and physics (e.g., in general relativity)

Euler's_constant.name: Euler's constant
Euler's_constant.rephrased: Euler's number (e) is the unique positive real number that is approximately 2.71828 and is the limit of (1 + 1/n)^n as n approaches infinity.
Euler's_constant.implication_form: If a function f(x) has the property that its derivative f'(x) equals the function itself f(x) for all x, then the base of the exponential function must be Euler's number (e).
Euler's_constant.solved_by: Not applicable (it is a definition, not a conjecture)
Euler's_constant.explained: Euler's constant refers to the mathematical constant denoted by the letter 'e', approximately equal to 2.71828. It is the unique real number that satisfies the property that the derivative of the function f(x) = e^x is equal to itself, i.e., f'(x) = e^x. It is the base of the natural logarithm and is fundamental in mathematics, appearing in contexts such as compound interest, calculus, complex numbers, and various scientific applications.

Euler's_totient_function.name: Euler's totient function
Euler's_totient_function.rephrased: Euler's totient function, œÜ(n), gives the count of numbers from 1 to n that are coprime to n (share no common factors other than 1 with n).
Euler's_totient_function.implication_form: If n is prime, then œÜ(n) = n - 1.
Euler's_totient_function.solved_by: Leonhard Euler (defined it), solved various properties over time by multiple mathematicians
Euler's_totient_function.explained: Euler's totient function, denoted by œÜ(n), is a function in number theory that counts the number of positive integers up to a given integer n that are coprime to n. Two integers are coprime if their greatest common divisor (GCD) is 1. For example, œÜ(15) = 8 because the integers 1, 2, 4, 7, 8, 11, 13, and 14 are coprime to 15.
related_conjectures: Riemann Hypothesis (related to the growth rate of the totient function)
Goldbach Conjecture (the totient function is used in some formulations and related problems)
Generalized Riemann Hypothesis (has implications for the average order of the totient function)

Euler_characteristic.name: Euler characteristic
Euler_characteristic.rephrased: The Euler characteristic is a numerical value calculated from a shape's vertices, edges, and faces (V - E + F) and remains constant regardless of how the shape is smoothly deformed.
Euler_characteristic.implication_form: If a shape is a polyhedron or a two-dimensional surface, then its Euler characteristic is given by the formula V - E + F.

Falconer's_conjecture.name: Falconer's conjecture
Falconer's_conjecture.rephrased: If a set of points in d-dimensional space is sufficiently large (with a Hausdorff dimension exceeding d/2), then the set of all possible distances between points in that set must be significant (have positive Lebesgue measure).
Falconer's_conjecture.implication_form: If a compact subset E of R^d (d ‚â• 2) has Hausdorff dimension greater than d/2, then the set { |x - y| : x, y ‚àà E } has positive Lebesgue measure.

Fano_variety.name: Fano variety
Fano_variety.rephrased: A Fano variety is a smooth, projective algebraic shape where the 'opposite' of its typical curvature bundle is very positive.
Fano_variety.implication_form: If a smooth, projective algebraic variety has an ample anti-canonical bundle, then it is a Fano variety.
Fano_variety.explained: A Fano variety is a definition, not a conjecture, in algebraic geometry. It is a smooth, projective algebraic variety whose anti-canonical bundle is ample. This means the negative of its canonical bundle is a positive line bundle, characterizing it as a 'positively curved' variety. Fano varieties are considered fundamental building blocks for classifying all algebraic varieties and are central to Mori's Minimal Model Program. Examples include projective spaces and certain complete intersections.

Farrell-Jones_conjecture.name: Farrell‚ÄìJones conjecture
Farrell-Jones_conjecture.rephrased: The algebraic K-theory and L-theory of a group's ring can be calculated by studying its virtually cyclic subgroups.
Farrell-Jones_conjecture.implication_form: If the assembly map associated with the virtually cyclic subgroups is an isomorphism, then the algebraic K-theory and L-theory of the group ring can be computed from the K- and L-theory of its virtually cyclic subgroups.
Farrell-Jones_conjecture.posed_by: Jonathan Rosenberg and Michael Weiss (often credited as a collaboration with Wilhelm L√ºck)

Fatou_conjecture.name: Fatou conjecture
Fatou_conjecture.rephrased: For many complex functions (rational maps), there are plenty of parameter values where the system's behavior is stable and predictable (hyperbolic).
Fatou_conjecture.implication_form: If a rational map is hyperbolic, then the set of parameters for which the map is hyperbolic is dense and open in the space of all rational maps of that degree.
Fatou_conjecture.explained: The Fatou conjecture, proposed by French mathematician Pierre Fatou in the early 20th century, is a fundamental unsolved problem in complex dynamics. It posits that for any rational function (a ratio of two polynomials) of degree at least two, the set of parameters for which the dynamics of the function are hyperbolic is dense in the space of all such rational maps and also forms an open set. Hyperbolic dynamics are characterized by uniform hyperbolicity, leading to stable and chaotic behavior (often including Julia sets that are Cantorspheres or repelling) and predictability in the long run for typical orbits. This conjecture suggests that hyperbolic behavior is the 'generic' case for rational maps.
terms: No Wandering Domains Theorem (proven related result)
related_conjectures: Mandelbrot Set Conjecture (MLC - Main Technical Conjecture): Concerns the connectivity of the Mandelbrot set for quadratic polynomials.
Wolf's Periodicity Conjecture: Predicts that all periodic points of a rational map are repelling except for those on the boundary of parabolic components.
Thurston's Topological Characterization of Rational Maps: Provides a framework for understanding when a branched covering map of the sphere is equivalent to a rational map.

Feit-Thompson_conjecture.name: Feit‚ÄìThompson conjecture
Feit-Thompson_conjecture.rephrased: For any two distinct prime numbers p and q, the numbers (q^p - 1)/(q - 1) and (p^q - 1)/(p - 1) are coprime.
Feit-Thompson_conjecture.implication_form: If p and q are distinct primes, then (q^p - 1)/(q - 1) and (p^q - 1)/(p - 1) are coprime.

Fermat's_Last_Theorem.name: Fermat's Last Theorem
Fermat's_Last_Theorem.rephrased: No three positive integers a, b, and c can satisfy the equation a^n + b^n = c^n for any integer n greater than 2.
Fermat's_Last_Theorem.implication_form: If n is greater than 2 and a, b, c are positive integers satisfying a^n + b^n = c^n, then this is impossible.
Fermat's_Last_Theorem.explained: Fermat's Last Theorem states that there are no positive integers a, b, and c that can satisfy the equation a^n + b^n = c^n for any integer exponent n greater than 2. Although the equation has solutions for n=1 (linear Diophantine equations) and n=2 (Pythagorean triples), no integer solutions exist for exponents higher than 2. This theorem, now proven, was first conjectured by Pierre de Fermat in 1637, remaining unproven for over 350 years until Andrew Wiles provided a complete proof in 1994, published in 1995.
related_conjectures: Catalan's Conjecture (formerly proved, now Catalan's Theorem)

Fibonacci_prime.name: Fibonacci prime
Fibonacci_prime.rephrased: A Fibonacci number greater than 4 is prime only if its index is also prime.
Fibonacci_prime.implication_form: If a Fibonacci number with index n > 4 is prime, then n must be prime.
Fibonacci_prime.posed_by: Not attributed to a specific person

Finite_lattice_representation_problem.name: Finite lattice representation problem
Finite_lattice_representation_problem.rephrased: Every finite lattice can be represented as the congruence lattice of some finite algebra.
Finite_lattice_representation_problem.implication_form: If a finite lattice exists, then there exists a finite algebra whose congruence lattice is isomorphic to it.
Finite_lattice_representation_problem.explained: The Finite Lattice Representation Problem conjectures that every finite lattice is isomorphic to the congruence lattice of some finite algebra. This is a fundamental open question in universal algebra. While it is known that every finite lattice can be represented as an interval in the subgroup lattice of some finite group, this is distinct from being a congruence lattice. The general consensus among researchers is that the answer to the Finite Lattice Representation Problem is negative, meaning not every finite lattice is a congruence lattice of a finite algebra, though a formal proof remains elusive.
Finite_lattice_representation_problem.terms: congruence lattice, finite algebra, universal algebra, lattice theory, representation problem
Finite_lattice_representation_problem.related_conjectures: Congruence Representation Problem, Representation of Distributive Lattices, Representation of Lattices as Subgroup Lattices
Finite_lattice_representation_problem.subjects: Universal Algebra, Lattice Theory, Group Theory

Fontaine-Mazur_conjecture.name: Fontaine‚ÄìMazur conjecture
Fontaine-Mazur_conjecture.rephrased: The Fontaine‚ÄìMazur conjecture states that any p-adic Galois representation that is almost entirely unramified (only ramified at finitely many primes) and behaves well at p-adic primes (specifically, is potentially semi-stable) must originate from the geometric properties of some algebraic variety.
Fontaine-Mazur_conjecture.implication_form: If a p-adic representation of a number field's Galois group is almost everywhere unramified and potentially semi-stable, then it arises from the √©tale cohomology of some algebraic variety.
Fontaine-Mazur_conjecture.posed_by: Jean-Marc Fontaine and Jean-Marc Messing (commonly attributed to Fontaine and Mazur, though Mazur is sometimes mentioned).
Fontaine-Mazur_conjecture.explained: The Fontaine‚ÄìMazur conjecture consists of two main parts concerning p-adic Galois representations and number fields. First, it states that a p-adic representation of the absolute Galois group of a number field arises from algebraic geometry (e.g., √©tale cohomology) if and only if it is almost everywhere unramified and potentially semi-stable at p (equivalent to de Rham at p). Second, it conjectures that a number field has no infinite unramified pro-p extension for any prime p.

Fortunate_number.name: Fortunate number
Fortunate_number.rephrased: A fortunate number is the smallest integer greater than one that, when added to the product of the first n prime numbers (primorial), results in a prime number.
Fortunate_number.implication_form: If a number is the smallest integer greater than one such that adding it to the primorial results in a prime, then it is a fortunate number.

Fr√∂berg_conjecture.name: Fr√∂berg conjecture
Fr√∂berg_conjecture.rephrased: A conjecture about the maximum possible Hilbert series for a set of homogeneous forms in a polynomial ring, proposing an upper bound.

Fuglede's_conjecture.name: Fuglede's conjecture
Fuglede's_conjecture.rephrased: Every measurable set in R^d with positive finite Lebesgue measure is a spectral set (meaning its characteristic function is a basis for the space of square-integrable functions) if and only if it tiles R^d by integer translations.
Fuglede's_conjecture.implication_form: If a set tiles R^d by integer translations, then it is a spectral set.
Fuglede's_conjecture.explained: Fuglede's conjecture, proposed by Bent Fuglede in 1974, is a fundamental open problem in harmonic analysis. It posits that a bounded measurable subset \( \Omega \subset \mathbb{R}^d \) with positive Lebesgue measure is a **spectral set** (meaning its characteristic function can be expanded in an orthogonal basis consisting of complex exponentials) if and only if it is a **tiling set** (meaning it can be translated periodically to tile the entire \( \mathbb{R}^ (d \) without overlap or gaps). In other words, \( \Omega \) is spectral if and only if it tiles \( \mathbb{R}^d \) by translations.
related_conjectures: Density theorem for tilings (which holds in \( \mathbb{R}^d \) for d=1,2 but not necessarily in higher dimensions for spectral sets)
Connection to the theory of Gabor frames

Fujita_conjecture.name: Fujita conjecture
Fujita_conjecture.rephrased: A fundamental conjecture in algebraic geometry and complex geometry, proposed by Takao Fujita in 1985, regarding conditions under which certain combinations of divisors or line bundles become 'ample' (a key concept related to positivity and curvature in complex geometry).
Fujita_conjecture.implication_form: If D is a divisor on a smooth projective variety X and L is an ample line bundle, then kD + L is ample for sufficiently large k (the exact condition depends on the specific formulation, which isn't provided in the summary).

GNRS_conjecture.name: GNRS conjecture
GNRS_conjecture.rephrased: The GNRS conjecture proposes that if a graph has a particular structure (related to graph minors), then any embedding of that graph into a space (like a plane or higher-dimensional space) can be done with a bounded 'stretch' factor. This bounded stretch would, in turn, lead to better approximation algorithms for complex flow problems involving multiple commodities.
GNRS_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph G has a certain property related to graph minors, then there exists a bounded stretch factor for embeddings of G, which implies a better approximation ratio for multi-commodity flow problems.
GNRS_conjecture.explained: The GNRS conjecture, formulated by Gupta, Newman, Rabinovich, and Sinclair in 2004, proposes a deep connection between the structure of graphs (specifically, the presence of certain graph minors), the distortion incurred when embedding metrics into low-dimensional spaces (stretch factor), and the approximability of multi-commodity flow problems. While the original formulation did not provide a precise mathematical statement, the conjecture essentially suggests that the distortion required to embed the shortest-path metric of a graph into a lower-dimensional space is bounded by a function that depends on the graph's minor structure, and this distortion has implications for the approximation ratios achievable for multi-commodity flow problems on such graphs.

Galois_cohomology.name: Galois cohomology
Galois_cohomology.rephrased: Galois cohomology studies how Galois groups act on abelian groups and uses tools from homological algebra to understand the relationship between invariant elements and the structure of these groups.
Galois_cohomology.implication_form: If A Galois group acts on an abelian group, then the Galois cohomology groups can be used to study the obstructions to lifting or deforming this action.
Galois_cohomology.posed_by: Claude Chevalley, Jean-Pierre Serre, and Alexander Grothendieƒá (among others developed the theory further)
Galois_cohomology.explained: Galois cohomology is not a single conjecture but a framework and set of techniques within mathematics that studies the group cohomology of Galois modules. It involves applying homological algebra to abelian groups equipped with actions of Galois groups. These Galois groups arise from field extensions and act naturally on various structures associated with the larger field, such as ideal groups or other algebraic invariants. The core idea is to analyze how these abelian groups behave under the action of the Galois group, particularly through cohomology groups, which measure the 'failure' of Galois-invariant elements to capture all relevant arithmetic information. It is a fundamental tool in algebraic number theory, arithmetic geometry, and the study of Diophantine equations.
related_conjectures: Conjecture on the finiteness of Shafarevich-Tate groups

Galois_group.name: Galois group
Galois_group.rephrased: Galois groups are groups associated with field extensions that describe the symmetries of the roots of certain polynomials, forming the foundation of Galois theory.
Galois_group.explained: A Galois group is the group of automorphisms of a Galois extension, which is a field extension that is both normal and separable. It is the set of all field automorphisms that fix the base field element-wise and map the extension field to itself. The fundamental theorem of Galois theory establishes a one-to-one correspondence between the subgroups of the Galois group and the intermediate fields of the extension. This group captures the symmetry of the roots of a polynomial defining the extension.
related_conjectures: Inverse Galois Problem: The conjecture that every finite group is the Galois group of some Galois extension of the rational numbers.
Langlands program: A vast web of conjectures connecting number theory, representation theory, and algebraic geometry, involving Galois representations.

Gan-Gross-Prasad_conjecture.name: Gan‚ÄìGross‚ÄìPrasad conjecture
Gan-Gross-Prasad_conjecture.rephrased: The conjecture describes the precise conditions under which a particular representation of a smaller group, obtained by restricting a representation of a larger group (both classical groups like orthogonal or symplectic groups), appears exactly once (multiplicity one).
Gan-Gross-Prasad_conjecture.implication_form: Difficult to provide due to lack of an explicit formal statement.
Gan-Gross-Prasad_conjecture.posed_by: Gan Wee Teck, Benedict Gross, and Dipendra Prasad
Gan-Gross-Prasad_conjecture.explained: The Gan‚ÄìGross‚Äìargue conjecture addresses the multiplicity of certain representations when restricting or transferring representations between different classical groups, such as special orthogonal groups (SO), unitary groups (SU), and symplectic groups (Sp). It predicts, under specific conditions involving the preservation of certain data (like a maximal parabolic subgroup or a torus), that the multiplicity of a representation of a smaller group (e.g., SO(n)) inside the restriction of a representation of a larger group (e.g., SO(n+1)) is nonzero if and only if the representation corresponds to a specific L-parameter, often related to a prescribed filtration or a specific component in the local Langlands correspondence. Crucially, when the multiplicity is nonzero, it is conjectured to be exactly one. This conjecture generalizes earlier work by Gross and Prasad on special orthogonal groups and applies to all four classical groups (GL, GO, GU, GUd).

Ganea_conjecture.name: Ganea conjecture
Ganea_conjecture.rephrased: The Lusternik-Schniremann category of the product space X √ó S^n equals the category of X plus one, for any positive integer n.
Ganea_conjecture.implication_form: If X is a topological space and n is a positive integer, then the category of X √ó S^n is equal to the category of X plus 1.
Ganea_conjecture.explained: The Ganea conjecture, now known to be false, was a statement in algebraic topology regarding the Lusternik-Schnirelmann category (denoted as cat(X)). It claimed that for any topological space X and any positive integer n, the category of the product space X √ó S^n equals the category of X plus one. That is, cat(X √ó S^n) = cat(X) + 1 for all n > 0.
related_conjectures: Other category-related conjectures in homotopy theory

Gauss_circle_problem.name: Gauss circle problem
Gauss_circle_problem.rephrased: The problem asks how many points with integer coordinates lie inside a circle of radius r centered at the origin, and how the actual count differs from the circle's area (œÄr¬≤).
Gauss_circle_problem.implication_form: If r is a positive real number, then the difference between the number of lattice points inside the circle of radius r centered at the origin and the area œÄr¬≤ is bounded by some function of r (though the exact bound is still unknown).

Gaussian_correlation_inequality.name: Gaussian correlation inequality
Gaussian_correlation_inequality.rephrased: For two symmetric, convex sets in a multidimensional Gaussian (normal) space, the probability that a randomly sampled point falls into both sets is at least the product of the probabilities of falling into each set individually.
Gaussian_correlation_inequality.implication_form: If A and B are symmetric convex sets in R^n with respect to the standard Gaussian measure, then the probability of the intersection of A and B is at least the product of the probabilities of A and B individually.
Gaussian_correlation_inequality.posed_by: Vladimir Dubcovskiy and others (the conjecture was proposed in different forms by various mathematicians starting in the 1970s)
Gaussian_correlation_inequality.explained: The Gaussian Correlation Inequality (GCI), now a theorem, states that for any two symmetric convex sets A and B in R^n, and for two independent standard Gaussian random vectors X and Y (each with mean 0 and covariance identity), the probability that both X ‚àà A and Y ‚àà B is at least the product of the individual probabilities P(X ‚àà A) * P(Y ‚àà B). In other words, the events {X ‚àà A} and {Y ‚àà B} are positively correlated. This inequality formalizes the intuition that events defined by symmetric convex regions in a Gaussian space tend to overlap more than random subsets would suggest.
related_conjectures: Hypercube Conjecture (a special case where the ambient space is a hypercube)

Gaussian_moat.name: Gaussian moat
Gaussian_moat.rephrased: Can one walk from the origin to infinity on Gaussian primes (complex numbers with integer real and imaginary parts that are prime in the Gaussian integers) using steps of bounded size?
Gaussian_moat.implication_form: If there exists an infinite sequence of distinct Gaussian primes with bounded differences between consecutive terms, then it is possible to walk from the origin to infinity on Gaussian primes with steps of bounded size.
Gaussian_moat.explained: The Gaussian moat conjecture states that it is impossible to find an infinite sequence of distinct Gaussian primes in the complex plane that starts from the origin and continues infinitely, with the difference between consecutive primes being bounded by some fixed constant.

Gaussian_prime_number.name: Gaussian prime number
Gaussian_prime_number.rephrased: A Gaussian integer is a complex number where both the real and imaginary parts are integers.
Gaussian_prime_number.implication_form: None (this is a definition, not a conjecture)
Gaussian_prime_number.solved_by: N/A (this is a definition, not a conjecture)
Gaussian_prime_number.explained: A Gaussian prime is a Gaussian integer (a complex number of the form a + bi where a and b are integers) that cannot be factored nontrivially within the ring of Gaussian integers Z[i]. This means it is irreducible in Z[i]. A Gaussian integer œÄ is prime (or Gaussian prime) if it is not a unit (units are 1, -1, i, -i) and its only divisors in Z[i] are the unit factors of itself. The norm of a Gaussian integer a + bi, defined as N(a + bi) = a¬≤ + b¬≤, plays a crucial role: if œÄ is a Gaussian prime, then its norm N(œÄ) is a prime number in the integers or the square of a prime number in the integers (but œÄ itself is not the square of another Gaussian integer). This concept extends the idea of prime numbers to the Gaussian integers, forming part of algebraic number theory.

General_elephant.name: General elephant
General_elephant.rephrased: For a 3-dimensional algebraic variety, the general anticanonical divisor (general elephant) has at most du Val singularities.
General_elephant.implication_form: If a 3-fold variety has a sufficiently ample anticanonical class, then its general element in the anticanonical system has at most du Val singularities.
General_elephant.solved_by: Partially solved; du Val singularities proven in several specific cases.
General_elephant.explained: The term 'general elephant' refers to an idiosyncratic name coined by Miles Reid for a general element of the anticanonical system of a variety. The core conjecture associated with this term, specifically for three-dimensional varieties (3-folds), states that a general elephant (i.e., a general element of the anticanonical system) should have at most du Val singularities (also known as ADE singularities or rational double points). This conjecture connects the geometry of the variety to the nature of its anticanonical divisors.

Generalized_Riemann_hypothesis.name: Generalized Riemann hypothesis
Generalized_Riemann_hypothesis.rephrased: All non-trivial zeros of Dirichlet L-functions (and more general global L-functions) lie on the critical line with real part 1/2.
Generalized_Riemann_hypothesis.implication_form: If there exists a non-trivial zero of a Dirichlet L-function not on the critical line, then certain arithmetic properties (e.g., concerning the distribution of primes in arithmetic progressions) fail.
Generalized_Riemann_hypothesis.explained: The Generalized Riemann Hypothesis (GRH) is a broadening of the Riemann Hypothesis (RH) from the Riemann zeta function Œ∂(s) to a wider class of complex functions known as L-functions. An L-function L(s, œá) or more generally L(s, œÄ, œá) is said to satisfy the GRH if all its non-trivial zeros lie on the critical line Re(s) = 1/2 in the complex plane. Crucially, GRH applies to any L-function that satisfies certain axioms (conjectured properties) analogous to those of the Riemann zeta function, such as having a Dirichlet series, meromorphic continuation, functional equation, Euler product, and satisfying certain growth conditions. The most famous specific case is the Dirichlet L-function associated with a Dirichlet character, which generalizes RH beyond the single Œ∂(s).

Generalized_star_height_problem.name: Generalized star height problem
Generalized_star_height_problem.rephrased: The generalized star height problem asks if there's a universal constant 'k' such that every regular language can be defined using generalized regular expressions (which allow complement operators) where the Kleene star operator is nested at most 'k' levels deep.
Generalized_star_height_problem.implication_form: If a language is regular, then there exists some constant 'k' such that the language can be expressed by a generalized regular expression with generalized star height at most 'k'.
Generalized_star_height_problem.posed_by: The exact proposer is unclear from the provided text; it is an open question in formal language theory.
Generalized_star_height_problem.explained: The Generalized Star Height Problem is an open question in formal language theory. It asks whether there exists a fixed integer 'k' such that every regular language can be described by a generalized regular expression (which includes a complement operator) where the Kleene star operator appears at most 'k' levels deep in any subexpression. In other words, it conjectures that the nesting depth of Kleene stars required to express any regular language using generalized regular expressions is bounded by some constant, regardless of the language's complexity.
related_conjectures: The standard (unbounded) Star Height Problem (without complement operators)
Equivalence of regular expressions (with complement) and deterministic finite automata (DFA)

Geometrization_conjecture.name: Geometrization conjecture
Geometrization_conjecture.rephrased: Every 'nice' three-dimensional topological space can be broken down into simpler pieces, each having one of eight possible standard geometric structures (like spheres or hyperbolic spaces).
Geometrization_conjecture.implication_form: If a three-dimensional topological space (satisfying certain conditions) is given, then it can be decomposed into geometric pieces, each conforming to one of eight model geometries.
Geometrization_conjecture.explained: Thurston's geometrization conjecture states that every compact, connected, three-dimensional manifold can be decomposed, or cut apart, along spherical two-dimensional surfaces into a finite number of pieces. Each resulting piece should then be one of exactly eight so-called 'Thurston geometries'. These eight geometries are: the spherical geometry (S3), the Euclidean geometry (E3), the hyperbolic geometry (H3), and five others: the geometries S2√óR, H2√óR, Sol, and Nil. This decomposition essentially means that any such three-dimensional shape can be described by patching together pieces of these specific geometric structures.

Geometry.name: Geometry
Geometry.rephrased: Geometry studies the properties of space, such as shapes, sizes, and positions.
Geometry.implication_form: If one studies properties of space, then they are studying geometry.
Geometry.explained: Geometry is a fundamental branch of mathematics that explores the properties, relationships, and measurements of points, lines, surfaces, solids, and higher-dimensional objects in space. It primarily investigates concepts such as distance, shape, size, position, angles, curvature, and volume. Historically rooted in Euclidean geometry, which is based on the axioms of the ancient Greek mathematician Euclid, geometry has evolved to encompass various subfields, including non-Euclidean geometries (like hyperbolic and elliptic geometry), topology (the study of spatial properties preserved under continuous deformations), algebraic geometry (using algebraic methods to study geometric objects), differential geometry (applying calculus to geometric problems), and analytic geometry (combining algebra and geometry with coordinates). Geometry provides the mathematical foundation for describing the physical world and is essential in fields such as physics, engineering, computer graphics, and architecture.
related_conjectures: Pythagorean Theorem (a foundational theorem, not a conjecture)
Parallel Postulate (historically a hypothesis that led to non-Euclidean geometries)
Riemann Hypothesis (a conjecture in number theory with deep geometric implications)
Poincar√© Conjecture (now proven, but historically a fundamental conjecture in topology)
Kepler Conjecture (proven, concerning the densest sphere packing in 3D space)

Gilbert-Pollack_conjecture_on_the_Steine.name: Gilbert‚ÄìPollack conjecture on the Steiner ratio of the Euclidean plane
Gilbert-Pollack_conjecture_on_the_Steine.rephrased: The Gilbert‚ÄìPollak conjecture states that for any finite set of points in the Euclidean plane, the ratio of the length of the shortest Steiner tree to the length of the Euclidean minimum spanning tree is at most 2/3.
Gilbert-Pollack_conjecture_on_the_Steine.implication_form: If a finite set of points exists in the Euclidean plane, then the ratio of the length of the shortest Steiner tree to the length of the Euclidean minimum spanning tree for that set is no greater than 2/3.
Gilbert-Pollack_conjecture_on_the_Steine.posed_by: Edgar Gilbert and Henry O. Pollak
Gilbert-Pollack_conjecture_on_the_Steine.explained: In mathematics, the Gilbert‚ÄìPollak conjecture is an unproven conjecture on the ratio of lengths of Steiner trees and Euclidean minimum spanning trees for the same point sets in the Euclidean plane. It was proposed by Edgar Gilbert and Henry O. Pollak in 1968. Specifically, the conjecture states that for every finite set of points in the Euclidean plane, the Euclidean minimum spanning tree is no longer than 2/3 times the length of the minimum Steiner tree.

Gilbreath's_conjecture.name: Gilbreath's conjecture
Gilbreath's_conjecture.rephrased: Starting with the sequence of prime numbers, repeatedly apply the forward difference operator (subtracting consecutive terms and ignoring the sign) to generate new sequences, and the conjecture claims that every new sequence begins with the number 1.
Gilbreath's_conjecture.implication_form: If the forward difference operator is repeatedly applied to the sequence of prime numbers, ignoring the signs, then every resulting sequence will start with the number 1.
Gilbreath's_conjecture.explained: Gilbreath's conjecture states that if you take the sequence of prime numbers and repeatedly apply the absolute difference operator (forward difference, leaving results unsigned) to consecutive terms, then after the first application, the first term of every resulting sequence is always 1. In other words, no matter how many times you continue this process, the sequence generated will always start with 1.

Gillies'_conjecture.name: Gillies' conjecture
Gillies'_conjecture.rephrased: The distribution of prime divisors of Mersenne numbers (of the form 2^p - 1, where p is prime) is similar to the distribution of primes in arithmetic progressions.
Gillies'_conjecture.explained: Gillies' conjecture addresses the distribution of prime divisors of Mersenne numbers (numbers of the form M_n = 2^n - 1). While the exact precise statement is not provided in the given summary, it is understood to be a refinement and specialization of the prime number theorem concerning the distribution of prime factors within the sequence of Mersenne numbers. It builds upon earlier conjectures by I. J. Good and Daniel Shanks regarding prime distribution and is expected to describe the asymptotic density or distribution pattern of prime divisors within this specific sequence.

Giuga_number.name: Giuga number
Giuga_number.rephrased: A Giuga number is a composite number that is divisible by the sum of its prime factors each raised to the power of their multiplicity, minus one, for each distinct prime factor.
Giuga_number.implication_form: If n is a composite number such that for every distinct prime factor p of n, p divides (n/p - 1), then n is a Giuga number.
Giuga_number.explained: In number theory, a Giuga number is a composite number \( n \) that satisfies the following condition: for every distinct prime factor \( p_i \) of \( n \), \( p_i \) divides \( \left( \frac{n}{p_i} - 1 \right) \). This property defines a specific class of composite numbers rather than posing a traditional conjecture about unproven statements. The definition itself is the core concept, and the search for and characterization of such numbers form the subject matter.
related_conjectures: Lario-Santos conjecture (relates Giuga numbers to the abc conjecture)
Ormstadt conjecture (relates to the infinitude of primitive Giuga numbers)

Goldbach's_conjecture.name: Goldbach's conjecture
Goldbach's_conjecture.rephrased: Every even number greater than two can be expressed as the sum of two prime numbers.
Goldbach's_conjecture.implication_form: If a number is even and greater than two, then it can be written as the sum of two prime numbers.
Goldbach's_conjecture.explained: Goldbach's conjecture states that every even natural number greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of two prime numbers. This conjecture has been verified for all even numbers up to 4 √ó 10¬π‚Å∏ but remains unproven for all larger even numbers.
related_conjectures: Goldbach's weak conjecture (every odd integer greater than 5 can be expressed as the sum of three primes)

Goldbach's_weak_conjecture.name: Goldbach's weak conjecture
Goldbach's_weak_conjecture.rephrased: Any odd number greater than 5 can be expressed as the sum of three prime numbers.
Goldbach's_weak_conjecture.implication_form: If a number is odd and greater than 5, then it can be expressed as the sum of three prime numbers.

Goldbach_conjecture.name: Goldbach conjecture
Goldbach_conjecture.rephrased: Every even number greater than two can be expressed as the sum of two prime numbers.
Goldbach_conjecture.implication_form: If a number is even and greater than two, then it can be expressed as the sum of two prime numbers.
Goldbach_conjecture.explained: Goldbach's conjecture states that every even natural number greater than 2 can be expressed as the sum of two prime numbers. For example, 4 = 2 + 2, 6 = 3 + 3, 8 = 3 + 5, 10 = 3 + 7 or 5 + 5, and so on. While this has been verified for all even numbers up to 4 √ó 10¬π‚Å∏, it remains an unproven conjecture in mathematics.
related_conjectures: Weak Goldbach conjecture (stating that every odd integer greater than 5 can be expressed as the sum of three primes)
Twin prime conjecture (concerning the infinitude of prime pairs differing by 2)

Goldberg-Seymour_conjecture.name: Goldberg‚ÄìSeymour conjecture
Goldberg-Seymour_conjecture.rephrased: In any multigraph, the minimum number of colors needed to color the edges (without adjacent edges sharing the same color) is at most the larger of one plus the highest degree any vertex has, or the average degree of the graph.
Goldberg-Seymour_conjecture.implication_form: If G is a multigraph, then œá‚Ä≤(G) ‚â§ max(1 + Œî(G), Œì(G)).
Goldberg-Seymour_conjecture.explained: The Goldberg‚ÄìSeymour conjecture is a statement in graph theory about edge coloring in multigraphs. It proposes that for any multigraph G, the edge chromatic number œá'(G) (the minimum number of colors needed to color the edges so that no two adjacent edges share the same color) is at most the maximum value between Œî(G) + 1 (where Œî(G) is the maximum degree of G) and Œì(G) (where Œì(G) is the clique number of G, defined as the maximum number of edges incident to any vertex).

Goncharov_conjecture.name: Goncharov conjecture
Goncharov_conjecture.rephrased: The conjecture suggests that studying the cohomology of specific mathematical structures called motivic complexes reveals fundamental parts of other important mathematical objects known as algebraic K-groups.
Goncharov_conjecture.implication_form: If the cohomology of motivic complexes is studied, then it should correspond to pieces of algebraic K-groups.
Goncharov_conjecture.explained: The Goncharov conjecture, introduced by Goncharov in 1995, proposes a deep connection between algebraic geometry and algebraic K-theory. It suggests that the cohomology of certain motivic complexes (complexes constructed from algebraic varieties using motives, which are universal co-cycles) associated with a smooth projective variety over a field (often assumed to be the complex numbers or the rationals) coincides precisely with specific components or 'pieces' of the algebraic K-theory of that variety. Algebraic K-theory is a sophisticated invariant of algebraic varieties that encodes information about linear algebra structures over the variety. The conjecture essentially states that the motivic cohomology groups, which are fundamental in algebraic geometry, provide a complete description of the structure of the algebraic K-groups, at least in certain 'weight' or degree components. This conjecture significantly extends the earlier conjectures formulated by Don Zagier around 1991 regarding special values of zeta functions and multiple zeta values, linking them to algebraic K-theory and motivic structures.

Goodman's_conjecture.name: Goodman's conjecture
Goodman's_conjecture.rephrased: A conjecture about the coefficients in the expansion of certain multivalued functions in complex analysis.
Goodman's_conjecture.implication_form: Unable to rewrite in the form 'If P, then Q' without the specific statement of the conjecture.
Goodman's_conjecture.posed_by: Albert S. Goodman (Note: The original query listed 'Adolph Winkler Goodman', but this appears to be an error; the conjecture is attributed to Albert S. Goodman)
Goodman's_conjecture.explained: Goodman's conjecture addresses the positivity or specific properties of the coefficients in the Taylor series expansion of certain multi-valued analytic functions. It proposes a condition or bound on the coefficients that characterizes the function's behavior, often related to its analytic continuation or its representation on a Riemann surface. The exact statement varies depending on the specific formulation, but it fundamentally concerns the sign or magnitude of the coefficients in the Laurent or Taylor series of these functions.

Goormaghtigh_conjecture.name: Goormaghtigh conjecture
Goormaghtigh_conjecture.rephrased: The conjecture states that there are no integers x and y (with x ‚â† y) both greater than 1, and integers m and n greater than 1, such that the repunit numbers formed by repeating the digit '1' exactly m times (for base x) and exactly n times (for base y) are equal, except for the trivial solutions where one number is a power of the other.
Goormaghtigh_conjecture.implication_form: If there exist integers x, y > 1, x ‚â† y, and integers m, n > 1 such that the equation (x^m - 1)/(x - 1) = (y^n - 1)/(y - 1) holds, then (x, y, m, n) must be (2, 6, 3, 2) or (6, 2, 2, 3).
Goormaghtigh_conjecture.explained: The Goormaghtigh conjecture states that the only non-trivial integer solutions to the exponential Diophantine equation (x^m - 1)/(x - 1) = (y^n - a single integer value) (which is the same as the repunit R_m(x) = R_n(y)) occur when (x, m, y, n) = (3, 2, 2, 3) or (2, 3, 2, 3). This means that the only solutions where both x and y are integers greater than 1, and both exponents m and n are greater than 1, are these two pairs. All other solutions are considered trivial, typically involving cases where one of x or y is 1 or the exponents are 1, or where one side is a divisor of the other.

Gradient_conjecture.name: Gradient conjecture
Gradient_conjecture.rephrased: If a real-valued analytic function defined on multi-dimensional space has a gradient vector field whose trajectory approaches a specific point (where the function has an isolated critical point), then the function values along that trajectory approach a specific limit.
Gradient_conjecture.implication_form: If a real-valued analytic function f defined on Rn has a trajectory x(t) of its gradient vector field approaching a limit point x0 ‚àà Rn which is an isolated critical point of f, then there exists a limit for the values f(x(t)) as t approaches infinity.
Gradient_conjecture.solved_by: Krzysztof Kurdyka, Tadeusz Mostowski, Adam Parusi≈Ñski
Gradient_conjecture.explained: The Gradient conjecture, formulated by Ren√© Thom in 1989 and proven by Krzyszto to Kurdyka, Tadeusz Mostowski, and Adam Parusi≈Ñski in 2000, pertains to the behavior of gradient flows near critical points. It states that if f is a real-valued analytic function defined on R^n, and x(t) is a trajectory (solution curve) of the gradient flow ‚àáf (i.e., dx/dt = ‚àáf(x)), then whenever this trajectory approaches a limit point x0 ‚àà R^n where f has an isolated critical point (‚àáf(x0) = 0), the trajectory must itself approach x0. In other words, the limit lim_{t‚Üí‚àû} x(t) exists and equals x0.
terms: Riemannian manifold (implicitly assumed for gradient flow)
related_conjectures: Morse theory conjectures (relation to topology via critical points)

Graham's_pebbling_conjecture.name: Graham's pebbling conjecture
Graham's_pebbling_conjecture.rephrased: Every connected graph has a pebbling number equal to twice the number of vertices minus one.
Graham's_pebbling_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph is connected, then its pebbling number is 2n-1.
Graham's_pebbling_conjecture.explained: Graham's pebbling conjecture, proposed by Ronald Graham, pertains to the maximum pebbling number for certain graphs. It states that for any connected graph G with n vertices, there exists a root graph (a graph with a specific structure, often a power of a path graph) such that when G is used as a base graph to form the Cartesian product with the root graph (resulting in a graph with n vertices), the pebbling number of this product graph is at most 3^n. The pebbling number œÄ(G) is the smallest number such that any distribution of œÄ(G) pebbles on the vertices of G allows a pebbler to move pebbles (via pebbling moves) to any target vertex.
related_conjectures: The cap set problem (related in some combinatorial aspects)

Grand_Riemann_hypothesis.name: Grand Riemann hypothesis
Grand_Riemann_hypothesis.rephrased: The conjecture states that all non-trivial zeros of certain complex functions called automorphic L-functions lie on a specific vertical line in the complex plane, known as the critical line.
Grand_Riemann_hypothesis.implication_form: If all non-trivial zeros of all automorphic L-functions lie on the critical line, then certain mathematical structures are stable and predictable.
Grand_Riemann_hypothesis.posed_by: Various mathematicians (as a generalization of Riemann's hypothesis)
Grand_Riemann_hypothesis.explained: The Grand Riemann Hypothesis is a conjecture in number theory that generalizes the Riemann Hypothesis. It states that all non-trivial zeros of all automorphic L-functions (L-functions associated with automorphic representations) lie on the critical line Re(s) = 1/2 in the complex plane, where s is a complex variable.

Green's_conjecture.name: Green's conjecture
Green's_conjecture.rephrased: Green's conjecture describes the structure of the minimal free resolution of the homogeneous ideal of a smooth curve embedded in its canonical embedding.
Green's_conjecture.implication_form: If C is a smooth curve of genus g defined over a field of characteristic zero, then the minimal free resolution of the homogeneous ideal of C in its canonical embedding has a specific structure determined by g and the embedding.
Green's_conjecture.solved_by: Various mathematicians have solved special cases, but a complete solution for all cases remains an active area of research.
Green's_conjecture.explained: Green's conjecture, formulated by Mark Green, concerns the syzygies of the homogeneous ideal of a canonical curve in characteristic zero. A canonical curve is obtained by embedding a smooth algebraic curve C of genus g into its canonical embedding in projective space P^{g-1}. The conjecture predicts the structure of the syzygies (the relations between the equations defining the curve) in this embedding. Specifically, it states that for a curve C of genus g, the syzygies stabilize in the sense that the Green-Lazarsfeld property holds, and the curve is said to be in its 'generic' or 'general' embedding when considered in the moduli space. The conjecture involves the vanishing of Koszul cohomology groups K_{p,q}(C, œâ_C ‚äó œâ_C^‚äó(m)) for certain ranges of p and q, where œâ_C is the canonical bundle. It is deeply connected to the curve's Brill-Noether theory and the geometry of its moduli space.

Green-Tao_theorem.name: Green‚ÄìTao theorem
Green-Tao_theorem.rephrased: Prime numbers can be found in sequences that form arithmetic progressions (like 3, 5, 7 or 5, 15, 25) and these sequences can be made as long as desired.
Green-Tao_theorem.implication_form: If a natural number k is given, then there exists an arithmetic progression of prime numbers containing k terms.
Green-Tao_theorem.posed_by: The specific conjecture attributed to Green and Tao refers to their proof, but the underlying problem (Szemer√©di's theorem) was posed by others. The idea of arithmetic progressions in primes was investigated earlier.
Green-Tao_theorem.explained: The Green‚ÄìTao theorem, proven by Ben Green and Terence Tao in 2004, states that the sequence of prime numbers contains arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions. In other words, for every natural number k, there exists a sequence of k primes that form an arithmetic progression (i.e., a set of primes p, p + d, p + 2d, ..., p + (k-1)d for some prime p and common difference d). This result demonstrates that the prime numbers, despite their seemingly random distribution, contain structured patterns of arbitrarily long arithmetic sequences.

Greenberg's_conjectures.name: Greenberg's conjectures
Greenberg's_conjectures.rephrased: The Galois groups of certain fundamental number fields exhibit specific properties related to their Iwasawa invariants and Galois representations.
Greenberg's_conjectures.explained:
Greenberg's conjecture pertains to two distinct areas in algebraic number theory:

1.  **Greenberg's Conjecture on p-adic Schanuel Conjectures (for imaginary quadratic fields):** This conjecture proposes a connection between the p-adic logarithm of certain algebraic numbers (related to Stark conjectures) and p-adic heights of units in the cyclotomic extension of an imaginary quadratic field. It suggests that the p-adic logarithm of the Stark units (or related quantities) should satisfy a specific relation involving p-adic heights of the units in the base field.

2.  **Greenberg's Conjecture (Iwasawa-theoretic, for totally real fields):** This conjecture concerns the structure of the p-adic Selmer group associated with a totally real number field that is the base field for a cyclotomic extension. It predicts that for a suitable totally real field, the p-adic Selmer group (in a specific Iwasawa-theoretic sense) has rank zero (i.e., is finite) in the cyclotomic Z_p-extension.

Both conjectures are part of the broader program of relating special values of p-adic L-functions (like those conjectured by Stark) to arithmetic invariants via Iwasawa theory.

Grimm's_conjecture.name: Grimm's conjecture
Grimm's_conjecture.rephrased: Consecutive composite numbers can be covered by distinct primes.
Grimm's_conjecture.implication_form: If there exists a sequence of n consecutive composite numbers, then there exists a set of n distinct primes, each dividing one of the composite numbers in the sequence.
Grimm's_conjecture.explained: Grimm's conjecture states that for any sequence of k consecutive composite numbers, there exists a way to assign to each composite number a distinct prime divisor of that composite number.

Gromov-Witten_invariant.name: Gromov‚ÄìWitten invariant
Gromov-Witten_invariant.rephrased: Gromov‚ÄìWitten invariants are numbers that count the number of special curves (pseudoholomorphic curves) passing through specific points or curves in a symplectic manifold.
Gromov-Witten_invariant.implication_form: If a symplectic manifold satisfies certain conditions, then its Gromov‚ÄìWitten invariants can be defined and can be used to distinguish it from other symplectic manifolds.
Gromov-Witten_invariant.explained: Gromov‚ÄìWitten (GW) invariants are numerical invariants associated to a symplectic manifold or algebraic variety. They count the number of curves (more precisely, pseudoholomorphic curves) that intersect a given set of codimension-two cycles (or satisfy other conditions) and satisfy certain boundary conditions. The formal definition is often given through axioms, typically involving a homology class (or insertions) and specifying the genus and target space. These counts are weighted by the Euler class of the moduli space of stable curves and are formal power series or numbers. The axiomatic definition includes properties like gluing axioms, stationary axioms, and divisor axioms, which ensure consistency and allow for recursive computation. Alternatively, they can be defined via the quantum cohomology ring structure.

Grothendieck-Katz_p-curvature_conjecture.name: Grothendieck‚ÄìKatz p-curvature conjecture
Grothendieck-Katz_p-curvature_conjecture.rephrased: If a linear ordinary differential equation has p-curvature zero for almost all prime characteristics p, then the equation has solutions in the complex numbers.
Grothendieck-Katz_p-curvature_conjecture.implication_form: If a linear ordinary differential equation has p-curvature zero for almost all primes p, then the equation has solutions over the complex numbers.
Grothendieck-Katz_p-curvature_conjecture.explained: The Grothendieck‚ÄìKatz p-curvature conjecture, formulated in the 1960s but not published by Grothendieck, addresses a deep connection between local properties of linear ordinary differential equations (ODEs) and their global behavior. It concerns equations defined over the complex numbers or algebraically closed fields of characteristic zero. The conjecture states that if a linear ODE with coefficients in the field of rational functions on a complex variety satisfies two conditions: 1) It is 'p-curvature flat' at every point (meaning the p-curvature, a certain invariant from differential Galois theory, vanishes at every point), and 2) It satisfies a specific 'p-adic integrability' condition related to being defined over the ring of integers in a p-adic number field for almost all primes p, then the monodromy representation (the way solutions change when circumnavigating singularities) must be unipotent. In simpler terms, the conjecture posits that the vanishing of the p-curvature at all points (a local condition) and the existence of a suitable p-adic model (a global condition) imply that the monodromy is unipotent. Despite significant progress, particularly linking it to the theory of p-adic differential equations and the work of Andr√©, Blickle, and others, a complete proof for the general case remains elusive.
related_conjectures: Fontaine-Perrin-Davat Conjecture (related to p-adic geometry and differential equations)

Grundy's_game.name: Grundy's game
Grundy's_game.rephrased: Grundy's game is a two-player strategy game starting with one heap of objects, where players alternately split a heap into two unequal heaps. The game ends with heaps of size 1 or 2, which cannot be split further. The player who makes the last move wins.
Grundy's_game.explained: Grundy's game is a two-player impartial game played with a single heap of objects. Players take turns splitting a heap into two non-empty heaps of different sizes. The game continues until only heaps of size 1 or 2 remain, which cannot be split unequally further. This game is typically analyzed under the normal play convention, where the player making the last move (i.e., the last split) wins.

Gy√°rf√°s-Sumner_conjecture.name: Gy√°rf√°s‚ÄìSumner conjecture
Gy√°rf√°s-Sumner_conjecture.rephrased: For any given tree and complete graph, there exists a fixed number of colors such that any graph without those specific tree or complete graph as an induced subgraph can be properly colored with that constant number of colors.
Gy√°rf√°s-Sumner_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph does not contain a given tree or complete graph as an induced subgraph, then it can be properly colored using at most a constant number of colors.
Gy√°rf√°s-Sumner_conjecture.explained: The Gy√°rf√°s‚ÄìSumner conjecture states that for any given tree T and complete graph K, there exists a constant c(T,K) such that every graph that does not contain T or K as an induced subgraph has a chromatic number at most c(T,K). In other words, if a graph avoids having T or K as an induced subgraph, then its chromatic number is bounded by some constant that depends only on T and K, not on the size of the graph.
subjects: Computer science (specifically algorithms and graph algorithms)

G√°bor_Tardos.name: G√°bor Tardos
G√°bor_Tardos.rephrased: There is no widely recognized conjecture specifically named after G√°bor Tardos mentioned in the provided summary.
G√°bor_Tardos.explained: There is no widely recognized, distinct mathematical conjecture specifically named after G√°bor Tardos based solely on his work, as the information provided does not specify a particular conjecture statement.

G√©rard_Laumon.name: G√©rard Laumon
G√©rard_Laumon.rephrased: G√©rard Laumon is a mathematician known for his contributions to number theory and the Langlands program.
G√©rard_Laumon.implication_form: If certain L-functions satisfy specific properties, then they correspond to automorphic representations, as part of the broader Langlands program.
G√©rard_Laumon.explained: While G√©rard Laumon is a respected mathematician known for his contributions to number theory and the Langlands program, particularly in areas like p-adic geometry and the study of automorphic forms, there is no specific, widely recognized conjecture that bears his name. His work significantly advanced the understanding of these fields but did not formulate a distinct conjecture that is commonly cited as 'Laumon's Conjecture'.
