G√∂del's_completeness_theorem.name: G√∂del's completeness theorem
G√∂del's_completeness_theorem.rephrased: If a statement is true in every model of a theory, then it can be proven from the theory's axioms.
G√∂del's_completeness_theorem.implication_form: If every model of T satisfies œÜ, then there is a proof of œÜ using the axioms of T.
G√∂del's_completeness_theorem.explained: G√∂del's completeness theorem is a foundational theorem in mathematical logic. It states that for any first-order theory (a collection of sentences considered as axioms), if a sentence is logically entailed by the theory (i.e., it is true in every possible model of the theory), then that sentence is also provable from the axioms of the theory using the rules of inference of first-order logic. In other words, the theorem establishes that the semantic consequence relation (truth in all models) coincides with the syntactic consequence relation (proof from axioms) for first-order logic. This means that the set of provable statements in a first-order theory is exactly the set of statements that are true in all models of that theory. The theorem is central to understanding the relationship between syntax and semantics in logic.

Hadamard's_maximal_determinant_problem.name: Hadamard's maximal determinant problem
Hadamard's_maximal_determinant_problem.rephrased: What is the maximum determinant achievable by an n √ó n matrix with entries of 1 or ‚àí1?

Hadamard_conjecture.name: Hadamard conjecture
Hadamard_conjecture.rephrased: A Hadamard matrix exists for every order that is a multiple of 4.
Hadamard_conjecture.implication_form: If n is a multiple of 4, then there exists a Hadamard matrix of order n.
Hadamard_conjecture.explained: The Hadamard conjecture states that an Hadamard matrix of order n exists if and only if n is a multiple of 4. An Hadamard matrix is a square matrix with entries +1 or -1, and rows that are pairwise orthogonal (i.e., any two distinct rows have a dot product of zero). This means that in any two distinct rows, the entries are +1 and -1 in exactly half of the columns (agreement) and mismatched in the other half (disagreement). The conjecture is about the existence of such matrices for every order that is a multiple of 4.

related_conjectures.name: Ryser's conjecture
related_conjectures.description: Concerns the existence of certain types of combinatorial designs related to Hadamard matrices.

related_conjectures.name: Frankl‚ÄìWilson theorem
related_conjectures.description: A result in extremal set theory that provides bounds related to the existence of families with certain intersection properties, which can be linked to combinatorial designs involving Hadamard matrices.

Hadamard_manifold.name: Hadamard manifold
Hadamard_manifold.rephrased: A Hadamard manifold is a complete, simply connected space with a Riemannian metric that curves inward or straight (non-positive curvature everywhere), and such spaces are essentially the same as flat Euclidean space but with possible curvatures less than or equal to zero.
Hadamard_manifold.implication_form: If a Riemannian manifold is complete, simply connected, and has everywhere non-positive sectional curvature, then it is diffeomorphic to Euclidean space.
Hadamard_manifold.posed_by: √âlie Cartan and Jacques Hadamard (the concept was developed by them, though the specific theorem is named after both)
Hadamard_manifold.solved_by: √âlie Cartan and Jacques Hadamard (proved the Cartan-Hadamard theorem)
Hadamard_manifold.explained: A Hadamard manifold, also known as a Cartan‚ÄìHadamard manifold, is a complete, simply connected Riemannian manifold with everywhere non-positive sectional curvature. This definition describes a specific class of Riemannian manifolds, not a conjecture about their properties or existence. The Cartan‚ÄìHadamard theorem states that the exponential map is a global diffeomorphism from the tangent space at any point to the entire manifold, and that all geodesics are length-minimizing.

Hadamard_matrix.name: Hadamard matrix
Hadamard_matrix.rephrased: A Hadamard matrix is a square matrix where all entries are either +1 or -1, and any two distinct rows are orthogonal, meaning their dot product is zero.
Hadamard_matrix.implication_form: If a square matrix has entries of ¬±1 and its rows are orthogonal, then it is a Hadamard matrix.
Hadamard_matrix.explained: A Hadamard matrix is a square matrix with entries of +1 or -1 such that any two distinct rows are orthogonal. This means that the dot product of any two distinct rows is zero. Equivalently, for any two distinct rows, the entries match (both +1 or both -1) in exactly half of the columns and differ in the remaining half of the columns. The rows are mutually orthogonal, meaning the orthogonality condition holds for every pair of distinct rows.
related_conjectures: Hadamard conjecture (on the existence of Hadamard matrices of order 4k for all positive integers k)

Hadwiger-Nelson_problem.name: Hadwiger‚ÄìNelson problem
Hadwiger-Nelson_problem.rephrased: What is the smallest number of colors needed to color the entire plane so that no two points exactly one unit apart have the same color?
Hadwiger-Nelson_problem.implication_form: If the plane can be colored with fewer than 5 colors such that no two points at distance 1 share the same color, then there must exist a pair of points at distance 1 that share the same color (though this is not the standard way to express the conjecture, as it is fundamentally about finding the minimum number, not a specific implication).
Hadwiger-Nelson_problem.explained: The Hadwiger‚ÄìNelson problem asks for the minimum number of colors required to color the entire plane such that no two points that are exactly distance 1 apart from each other share the same color. This minimum number is currently unknown but is known to be one of the integers 5, 6, or 7. Furthermore, the exact chromatic number of the plane may depend on the underlying axioms of set theory (e.g., Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory with the Axiom of Choice, or systems where the Axiom of Choice is negated).
related_conjectures: Chromatic number of the infinite grid

Hales-Jewett_theorem.name: Hales‚ÄìJewett theorem
Hales-Jewett_theorem.rephrased: For any number of colors and any dimension, there is a size such that any coloring of the points in that high-dimensional grid with the colors will contain a monochromatic combinatorial line.
Hales-Jewett_theorem.implication_form: If all points in a sufficiently high-dimensional grid are colored with c colors, then there exists a monochromatic combinatorial line.
Hales-Jewett_theorem.explained: The Hales‚ÄìJewett theorem states that for any positive integers n and c, there exists a positive integer H (depending only on n and c) such that any coloring of the cells in the H-dimensional grid [n]^H (where [n] = {1,2,...,n}) with c colors must contain at least one monochromatic combinatorial line. A combinatorial line in this context is a set of points that are aligned along a row, column, file (in the combinatorial sense), or diagonal within the grid space.
related_conjectures: Gallai-Witt theorem (a generalization in the context of point lattices)
Van der Waerden's theorem (deals with monochromatic arithmetic progressions, closely related conceptually)

Hall's_conjecture.name: Hall's conjecture
Hall's_conjecture.rephrased: There exists a positive constant C such that for any two distinct perfect powers‚Äîone being a square and the other a cube‚Äîthe absolute difference between them is at least C times the absolute value of the cube.
Hall's_conjecture.implication_form: If x¬≥ and y¬≤ are distinct integers, then |x¬≥ - y¬≤| ‚â• C|x¬≥| for some positive constant C.
Hall's_conjecture.explained: Hall's conjecture states that for any integers x and y such that y¬≤ ‚â† x¬≥, there exists a positive constant C (depending on the conjecture, but not on x or y) such that the absolute difference |y¬≤ - x¬≥| is at least C. In other words, any non-zero perfect square and perfect cube must differ by at least some fixed positive amount, though this amount can depend on the size of the numbers involved only through the constant C.
related_conjectures: Mordell conjecture (now Faltings' theorem, relating to rational points on elliptic curves)
abc conjecture (deals with bounding differences in terms of multiplicative properties)
Waring's problem (concerns representing numbers as sums of powers)

Halperin_conjecture.name: Halperin conjecture
Halperin_conjecture.rephrased: In rational homotopy theory, the Halperin conjecture proposes a relationship between the rank of the fundamental group of a space and its rational homotopy properties, specifically in the context of fibrations where the base space is simply connected.
Halperin_conjecture.implication_form: If a space X is the total space of a fibration with a simply connected base space, then the rank of its fundamental group is bounded by its rational homotopy properties.
Halperin_conjecture.explained: The Halperin conjecture, formulated by Stephen Halperin in the context of rational homotopy theory, addresses the rank of the differential in the Serre spectral sequence for certain fibrations. Specifically, for a fibration F ‚Üí X ‚Üí B where X is simply connected and the spectral sequence converges to the rational homotopy of X, the conjecture states that the rank of the differential d‚ÇÇ in the minimal model associated to the fibration is equal to the dimension of the rational homotopy Lie algebra of F minus the rank of the rational homotopy Lie algebra of B.

Hamiltonian_decomposition.name: Hamiltonian decomposition
Hamiltonian_decomposition.rephrased: For certain graphs, it is possible to divide all the edges into sets, each forming a single cycle that visits every vertex exactly once (a Hamiltonian cycle).
Hamiltonian_decomposition.implication_form: If a graph has a Hamiltonian decomposition, then its edges can be partitioned into Hamiltonian cycles.
Hamiltonian_decomposition.posed_by: Attributed to Hamiltonian cycle concepts (named after William Rowan Hamilton), but no specific proposer for the decomposition conjecture is widely recognized.
Hamiltonian_decomposition.explained: A Hamiltonian decomposition refers to a specific concept in graph theory, not an open conjecture. It describes a partition of the edges of a graph (either undirected or directed) into Hamiltonian cycles. In the undirected case, this is equivalent to a 2-factorization (a decomposition into disjoint cycles covering all edges) where each factor (cycle) is connected. There is no specific mathematical statement (like 'the graph has a Hamiltonian decomposition') that is being conjectured here; the definition itself is the key point.
related_conjectures: Hamiltonian Cycle Problem (a central NP-complete problem in graph theory)
Tait's conjecture (about Hamiltonian cycles in cubic graphs)

Hanna_Neumann_conjecture.name: Hanna Neumann conjecture
Hanna_Neumann_conjecture.rephrased: The rank (minimum number of generators) of the intersection of any two finitely generated subgroups of a free group is at most the product of their individual ranks minus one.
Hanna_Neumann_conjecture.implication_form: If H and K are finitely generated subgroups of a free group, then the rank of their intersection H ‚à© K is at most (rank(H) * rank(K)) - 1.
Hanna_Neumann_conjecture.solved_by: Joel Friedman and Igor Mineyev (2011) proved a strengthened version; a third proof was published in 2017.

Harborth's_conjecture.name: Harborth's conjecture
Harborth's_conjecture.rephrased: Every planar graph can be drawn with straight-line edges where each edge has a whole number length (integer).
Harborth's_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph is planar, then it can be drawn with straight edges of integer lengths.
Harborth's_conjecture.explained: Harborth's Conjecture states that every planar graph admits a straight-line embedding (a drawing with vertices at points and edges as straight line segments) in the plane such that all edge lengths are integers.
related_conjectures: Four Color Theorem (related to coloring planar graphs, not directly embedding)

Hardy-Littlewood_zeta_function_conjectur.name: Hardy‚ÄìLittlewood zeta function conjectures
Hardy-Littlewood_zeta_function_conjectur.rephrased: These conjectures predict the spacing between zeros on the critical line and the density of zeros of the Riemann zeta function.
Hardy-Littlewood_zeta_function_conjectur.implication_form: If the zeros of the Riemann zeta function satisfy certain spacing properties, then their density is constrained in a specific way.
Hardy-Littlewood_zeta_function_conjectur.posed_by: Godfrey Harold Hardy and John Edensor Littlewood
Hardy-Littlewood_zeta_function_conjectur.explained: The Hardy‚ÄìLittlewood zeta function conjectures, formulated by Godfrey Harold Hardy and John Edensor Littlewood, address the distribution and spacing of the non-trivial zeros of the Riemann zeta function, assuming the Riemann Hypothesis holds (i.e., all non-trivial zeros lie on the critical line Re(s) = 1/2). They provide conjectures about the average gap between consecutive zeros and the density of zeros on the critical line. The first conjecture (often denoted as Conjecture A) states that the average gap between the n-th pair of zeros (measured along the critical line) approaches a specific value as n increases, reflecting a form of asymptotic regularity. The second conjecture (Conjecture B) deals with the density of zeros up to a certain height on the critical line, offering a more precise asymptotic estimate for the number of zeros in a given interval.

Hartmanis-Stearns_conjecture.name: Hartmanis‚ÄìStearns conjecture
Hartmanis-Stearns_conjecture.rephrased: The Hartmanis-Stearns conjecture posits that any number that can be generated by a Turing machine in real-time (outputting one digit at a time within a fixed time bound per digit) must be a rational number.
Hartmanis-Stearns_conjecture.implication_form: If a real-time computable number exists, then it must be rational.
Hartmanis-Stearns_conjecture.posed_by: Juris Hartmanis and Richard E. Stearns
Hartmanis-Stearns_conjecture.explained: The Hartmanis‚ÄìStearns conjecture is a foundational open problem in theoretical computer science concerning the relationship between time complexity and the computability of real numbers. It posits that if a real number can be computed by a multitape Turing machine in real-time (i.e., the machine writes the n-th digit using only O(n) time steps in total, with the time per digit bounded by a constant), then that number must be a transcendental number. In other words, no algebraic irrational number (which includes all rational numbers) can be computed in real-time by a Turing machine.
related_conjectures: P versus NP problem (related through the broader field of computational complexity)
Time hierarchy theorems (provide foundational results on time complexity)
Conjectures regarding the computability of specific real numbers (e.g., whether œÄ or e can be computed faster than linear time)
Research on the limits of real-time computation in various models (e.g., cellular automata, streaming algorithms)

Hausdorff_dimension.name: Hausdorff dimension
Hausdorff_dimension.rephrased: Hausdorff dimension is a mathematical way to measure how 'rough' or 'bumpy' a set is, generalizing the idea of dimension (like a point being 0-dimensional, a line 1-dimensional, etc.) to fractal shapes with complex structures.
Hausdorff_dimension.implication_form: None (this is a definition, not a conjecture to be proved)
Hausdorff_dimension.explained: Hausdorff dimension is a mathematical concept introduced by Felix Hausdorff in 1918 that provides a way to measure the 'size' or complexity of sets in a metric space, particularly those that are 'rough' or fractal-like. Unlike the classical notion of dimension, which assigns integer values (like 1 for a line, 2 for a plane) and works well for smooth shapes, Hausdorff dimension can be any non-negative real number. It is defined using the concept of Hausdorff measure, which generalizes the Lebesgue measure. The Hausdorff dimension is often strictly greater than the topological dimension of the set, reflecting its 'fractal' nature. For example, a smooth curve has Hausdorff dimension equal to its topological dimension (1), while a fractal curve might have a Hausdorff dimension greater than 1.
related_conjectures: Mandelbrot conjecture (on the Hausdorff dimension of the boundary of the Mandelbrot set)
Conjectures related to the dimension of Julia sets
Conjectures about the dimension of self-similar sets

Hedetniemi's_conjecture.name: Hedetniemi's conjecture
Hedetniemi's_conjecture.rephrased: The chromatic number of the tensor product of two graphs is equal to the minimum chromatic number of the two graphs.
Hedetniemi's_conjecture.implication_form: If P and Q are graphs, then the chromatic number of their tensor product is equal to the minimum of their individual chromatic numbers.
Hedetniemi's_conjecture.explained: Hedetni'tniemi's conjecture, proposed by Stephen T. Hedetniemi in 1966, addresses the chromatic number of the tensor product of two graphs. It claims that the chromatic number of the product graph G √ó H is exactly equal to the minimum of the chromatic numbers of the individual graphs G and H. In mathematical notation: œá(G √ó H) = min{œá(G), œá(H)}.
terms: Tensor product of graphs (also called categorical product)
related_conjectures: The tensor product coloring problem (which is the conjecture itself)
The conjecture regarding the chromatic number of the tensor product of complete graphs (œá(K_m √ó K_n) = min{m,n} for all m,n ‚â• 1)

Heilbronn_triangle_problem.name: Heilbronn triangle problem
Heilbronn_triangle_problem.rephrased: Can we place n points in a unit area such that the smallest triangle formed by any three points has area at most 1/n¬≤?
Heilbronn_triangle_problem.implication_form: If n points are placed in a unit area, then there exists a triangle formed by three of those points with area at most 1/n¬≤.
Heilbronn_triangle_problem.explained: The Heilbronn triangle problem concerns the minimum area of the smallest triangle formed by any three points when n points are placed within a fixed area, typically the unit disk. Hans Heilbronn conjectured that this minimum area, denoted min_area(n), would satisfy min_area(n) ‚â§ C / n¬≤ for some constant C depending only on the area (e.g., the unit disk). However, this conjecture was disproven in 2005 by Koml√≥s, Pach, and Szemer√©di, who showed that Heilbronn's constant C does not exist; the minimum area can be larger than any constant divided by n¬≤. Despite this, the exact asymptotic growth rate of min_area(n) as n tends to infinity remains unknown. The problem is to determine the precise asymptotic behavior of the minimum triangle area for n points in a fixed area.

Henson_graph.name: Henson graph
Henson_graph.rephrased: The Henson graph Gi is an infinite, countable, homogeneous graph that avoids a specific i-clique but contains every finite graph that also avoids that i-clique.
Henson_graph.implication_form: It is not possible to frame this as a standard 'If P, then Q' implication, as the original statement is more of a definition than a conjecture to be proven.
Henson_graph.explained: The Henson graph H_i (or G_i) is a well-defined infinite graph, not a conjecture. It is the unique (up to isomorphism) countable homogeneous graph that omits a specific i-vertex clique (K_i) but contains every finite graph that does not contain a K_i as an induced subgraph. For example, the Henson graph H_3 is triangle-free and contains all finite triangle-free graphs.

Hermite's_problem.name: Hermite's problem
Hermite's_problem.rephrased: Find a method to represent every real number as a sequence of natural numbers such that the sequence eventually becomes periodic if and only if the original number is a cubic irrational (a root of a cubic polynomial with integer coefficients).
Hermite's_problem.implication_form: If a real number is a cubic irrational, then its sequence representation is eventually periodic.

Hermite_constant.name: Hermite constant
Hermite_constant.rephrased: The Hermite constant Œ≥‚Çô provides an upper bound on the shortest vector length in any n-dimensional lattice.
Hermite_constant.implication_form: If L is an n-dimensional lattice, then the squared length of its shortest vector is at most Œ≥‚Çô times the determinant raised to the power of 1/n.
Hermite_constant.explained: The Hermite constant, denoted by Œ≥‚Çô for integers n > 0, is a mathematical constant defined for lattices in Euclidean space ‚Ñù‚Åø. It is the supremum (least upper bound) of the ratio Œª‚ÇÅ(L)¬≤‚Åø / det(L) over all lattices L in ‚Ñù‚Åø, where Œª‚ÇÅ(L) is the length of the shortest non-zero vector in the lattice L, and det(L) is the absolute value of the determinant of the lattice's basis matrix. The conjecture associated with the Hermite constant is that this supremum is actually achieved by some lattice, and that the optimal lattice for each dimension n is unique up to isometry. Furthermore, it is conjectured that there exists a closed-form expression for the optimal Œ≥‚Çô, specifically Œ≥‚Çô = 2‚Åø/‚Çô‚Çä‚ÇÅ * (1/‚Çô‚Çä‚ÇÅ)!, where ! denotes the factorial function. This closed-form expression is believed to be achieved by the root lattice of type D‚Çô for even n and type A‚Çô for odd n, although this is not proven for all dimensions.
related_conjectures: Conjecture on the Complexity of SVP and Learning With Errors (LWE)
Conjecture regarding the exact value of the Hermite constant
Conjecture on the optimality of the root lattice

Herzog-Sch√∂nheim_conjecture.name: Herzog‚ÄìSch√∂nheim conjecture
Herzog-Sch√∂nheim_conjecture.explained: The Herzog‚ÄìSch√∂nheim conjecture, proposed in 1974, addresses a covering condition involving a finite group G, a subset A of G, and the stabilizer subgroup H of A (the set of elements fixing A pointwise). It states that if the left cosets of H cover the entire group G, then the number of such cosets, denoted k, satisfies k * |A| ‚â• |G|, where |A| and |G| denote the cardinalities of A and G respectively. Furthermore, the conjecture suggests that equality holds if and only if the covering is a disjoint union of the cosets (i.e., a partition).
related_conjectures: Davenport constant (related to subset sums in abelian groups)
Theorems related to covering systems or covering codes

Hilbert's_fifteenth_problem.name: Hilbert's fifteenth problem
Hilbert's_fifteenth_problem.rephrased: Ensure Schubert's enumerative calculus is based on rigorous algebraic geometry principles.
Hilbert's_fifteenth_problem.implication_form: If Schubert's enumerative calculus is rigorously formalized, then it can be reliably used in algebraic geometry.
Hilbert's_fifteenth_problem.solved_by: Various mathematicians (e.g., Chow, Grothendieck) developed foundational tools like sheaf cohomology, but no single solver is credited for the entire problem
Hilbert's_fifteenth_problem.explained: Hilbert's fifteenth problem concerns the foundation of enumerative geometry, specifically Schubert's enumerative calculus. The problem challenges mathematicians to rigorously establish Schubert calculus, a method developed in the 19th century for counting geometric figures satisfying given conditions (e.g., how many lines pass through two given points and intersect two given curves). Schubert's original approach, while producing correct numerical results in many instances, lacked a solid theoretical foundation based on modern algebraic geometry. Hilbert's problem thus calls for a rigorous formulation of these intersection numbers using the principles of modern algebraic geometry, such as intersection cohomology or the theory of algebraic varieties.

Hilbert's_sixteenth_problem.name: Hilbert's sixteenth problem
Hilbert's_sixteenth_problem.rephrased: Hilbert's Sixteenth Problem concerns the maximum number and relative positions of components (ovals) in the arrangement of real algebraic curves of a given degree, and the similar problem for real algebraic surfaces in three dimensions.
Hilbert's_sixteenth_problem.implication_form: If a real algebraic curve of degree n exists with a certain configuration of ovals, then ... (This formulation is less straightforward than for some other conjectures, as the problem is fundamentally about enumerating and classifying possible configurations rather than proving a single implication P -> Q.)
Hilbert's_sixteenth_problem.explained: Hilbert's Sixteenth Problem concerns the qualitative study of algebraic curves and their deformations. Part 1 asks for a description of the possible arrangements (relative positions) of the real branches of a non-singular algebraic curve of degree n in the plane as n varies, specifically bounding the maximum number of connected components (ovals) and their possible configurations. Part 2 focuses on the topology of families of real algebraic curves (or surfaces) under small perturbations, particularly asking about the maximum number of limit cycles (closed curves representing periodic behavior) that can appear in a deformation of a given curve (or the number of ovals that can be destroyed during deformation).
related_conjectures: The Smale horseshoe (related concept of chaotic behavior in dynamical systems, though not a direct parallel)

Hilbert's_tenth_problem.name: Hilbert's tenth problem
Hilbert's_tenth_problem.rephrased: Is there a universal algorithm that can determine, for any given polynomial equation with integer coefficients and finitely many unknowns, whether it has integer solutions?
Hilbert's_tenth_problem.implication_form: If a general algorithm exists that can solve all Diophantine equations, then it would correctly determine the existence of integer solutions for every such equation.
Hilbert's_tenth_problem.solved_by: Martin Davis, Julia Robinson, Yuri Matiyasevich (proving undecidability)
Hilbert's_tenth_problem.explained: Hilbert's tenth problem asks for an algorithm that can determine, for any given Diophantine equation (a polynomial equation with integer coefficients and a finite number of unknowns), whether there exist integer solutions. For example, the equation 3x + y = 5 has integer solutions, while the equation x¬≤ + y¬≤ + z¬≤ = 7 has none.

Hilbert-Arnold_problem.name: Hilbert‚ÄìArnold problem
Hilbert-Arnold_problem.rephrased: Can the number of limit cycles in a generic smooth vector field on a sphere be bounded?
Hilbert-Arnold_problem.implication_form: If a generic smooth vector field on a sphere exists, then the number of limit cycles can be bounded.
Hilbert-Arnold_problem.posed_by: David Hilbert and Sophus Lie (combined with V. I. Arnold's work)
Hilbert-Arnold_problem.explained: The Hilbert-Arnold problem concerns the estimation of the number of limit cycles in generic families of smooth vector fields defined on a sphere. A limit cycle is a closed trajectory in the phase space that is isolated and invariant under the flow. The conjecture specifically asks whether the maximum number of such limit cycles can be bounded above for any smooth, generic family of vector fields on the sphere.
related_conjectures: Hilbert 16th Problem (classifies limit cycles in planar polynomial vector fields)
Poincar√©-Bendixson Theorem (describes the behavior of dynamical systems in the plane)
Arnold's Axioms (fundamental principles in dynamical systems theory)
Morse Theory (studies the topology of manifolds via critical points of smooth functions)

Hilbert-P√≥lya_conjecture.name: Hilbert‚ÄìP√≥lya conjecture
Hilbert-P√≥lya_conjecture.rephrased: The non-trivial zeros of the Riemann zeta function are eigenvalues of a specific self-adjoint operator.
Hilbert-P√≥lya_conjecture.implication_form: If the Hilbert‚ÄìP√≥lya conjecture is true, then the Riemann hypothesis is true.

Hilbert-Smith_conjecture.name: Hilbert‚ÄìSmith conjecture
Hilbert-Smith_conjecture.rephrased: A locally compact topological group that acts faithfully on a (topological) manifold must be a Lie group.
Hilbert-Smith_conjecture.implication_form: If a locally compact group acts faithfully on a manifold, then it is a Lie group.
Hilbert-Smith_conjecture.posed_by: David Hilbert and John Edward Smith
Hilbert-Smith_conjecture.solved_by: Robert Sternberg (with contributions from others like Andrew Casson, John Frank Adams, and others, though proof verification details are complex)
Hilbert-Smith_conjecture.explained: The Hilbert‚ÄìSmith conjecture states that if a locally compact group G acts faithfully and continuously on a topological manifold M, then G must be a Lie group. In other words, any group that acts effectively on a manifold must possess a smooth manifold structure compatible with its group operations. This conjecture connects the topological properties of group actions on manifolds to their underlying smooth structure.
related_conjectures: Structure theory of locally compact groups
Actions of locally compact groups on manifolds

Hirsch_conjecture.name: Hirsch conjecture
Hirsch_conjecture.rephrased: The longest path between any two vertices of a d-dimensional polytope with n facets is at most n minus d.
Hirsch_conjecture.implication_form: If a polytope has n facets in d-dimensional space, then the diameter of its edge-vertex graph is at most n minus d.
Hirsch_conjecture.explained: The Hirsch conjecture, proposed by Warren M. Hirsch in 1957, concerns the diameter of the edge-vertex graph of a polytope. Specifically, it states that for a d-dimensional polytope with n facets (n-dimensional faces), the diameter of its edge-vertex graph (the graph where vertices are the polytope's vertices and edges are its edges) is at most n - d. This means that any two vertices of the polytope can be connected by a path along the edges of the polytope that has length (number of edges) no greater than n - d.

Hodge_conjecture.name: Hodge conjecture
Hodge_conjecture.rephrased: The Hodge conjecture states that certain geometric features of complex shapes defined by polynomials (specifically, elements of their cohomology groups that satisfy extra symmetry conditions) can be explained by looking at simpler shapes (called algebraic cycles) inside them.
Hodge_conjecture.implication_form: If a complex algebraic variety has a Hodge class in its cohomology, then it must be expressible as a rational combination of algebraic cycles.
Hodge_conjecture.explained: The Hodge conjecture states that for a non-singular complex algebraic variety, the Hodge classes in its cohomology ring are integral linear combinations of the cohomology classes of complex algebraic subvarieties. In other words, certain topological information (captured by Hodge classes) can be understood by studying the subvarieties (the 'nice shapes') that lie within the variety. More formally, if X is a non-singular complex algebraic variety defined over the complex numbers, then every Hodge class (cohomology class that is also a Hodge class, meaning it has a specific real and integral structure) is actually an integral linear combination of the cohomology classes of algebraic cycles (subvarieties of X).

Homological_conjectures_in_commutative_a.name: Homological conjectures in commutative algebra
Homological_conjectures_in_commutative_a.rephrased: If a commutative ring R is a homomorphic image of a Gorenstein ring and S is a direct summand of R as an R-module, then S is also a homomorphic image of a Goren'tstein ring.
Homological_conjectures_in_commutative_a.implication_form: If R is a homomorphic image of a Gorenstein ring and S is a direct summand of R as an R-module, then S is a homomorphic image of a Gorenstein ring.

Honeycomb_theorem.name: Honeycomb theorem
Honeycomb_theorem.rephrased: A regular hexagonal grid has the least perimeter for any equal-area division of the plane.
Honeycomb_theorem.implication_form: If all regions in a plane subdivision have the same area, then the arrangement with the smallest total perimeter is a regular hexagonal grid.
Honeycomb_theorem.explained: The Honeycomb Theorem states that among all subdivisions of the plane into regions of equal area, the regular hexagonal grid (such as that found in a honeycomb) has the minimal total perimeter. This means that any other subdivision into cells of the same area will have a greater total perimeter length than the hexagonal grid.
related_conjectures: Kelvin Problem (minimal surface area for bubbles)

Hopf_conjecture.name: Hopf conjecture
Hopf_conjecture.rephrased: The only even-dimensional sphere that admits a symplectic structure is the 2-sphere.
Hopf_conjecture.implication_form: If a compact even-dimensional symplectic manifold is homeomorphic to a sphere, then it must be diffeomorphic to S^2.
Hopf_conjecture.explained: The Hopf conjecture typically refers to the conjecture that the only even-dimensional spheres with an Einstein metric are the 2-sphere and the 4-sphere. More precisely, it posits that a compact, oriented, even-dimensional Riemannian manifold with positive Ricci curvature must be homeomorphic to a sphere if its Euler characteristic is even. Another formulation, related to complex geometry, is that a compact K√§hler manifold with positive curvature and even complex dimension cannot be contractible. Hopf also conjectured that the only compact, oriented, simply connected Riemannian manifold of positive curvature is the complex projective space CP^n for even n, and that such a space cannot be mapped non-trivially by a harmonic map unless it is the sphere.

Hsiang-Lawson's_conjecture.name: Hsiang‚ÄìLawson's conjecture
Hsiang-Lawson's_conjecture.rephrased: The only minimal surface that can be embedded as a torus in the 3-sphere S3 is the Clifford torus.
Hsiang-Lawson's_conjecture.implication_form: If a torus is minimally embedded in S3, then it is the Clifford torus.
Hsiang-Lawson's_conjecture.explained: Hsiang‚ÄìLawson's conjecture, originally attributed to Hsiang and later refined by Lawson, states that among all isometric embeddings of the flat torus into the 3-sphere S^3, only the Clifford torus is minimal (i.e., has mean curvature zero everywhere). A minimal surface is one that locally minimizes its area, and the mean curvature being zero is a stronger condition than just having zero mean curvature in the sense of harmonic maps for surfaces. The Clifford torus is defined as T_c = S^1(r) √ó S^1(‚àö(2-r^2)) for some radius r (specifically, it is often taken with equal radii, though this is a special case). The conjecture asserts that this specific embedding is the unique one without singularities that minimizes surface area among all such embeddings.
related_conjectures: Isoparametric Hypothesis (concerning isoparametric hypersurfaces, where minimal tori are examples)
Willmore Conjecture (which concerns the Willmore energy of embedded tori in spheres, including S^3)

Ibragimov-Iosifescu_conjecture_for_œÜ-mi.name: Ibragimov‚ÄìIosifescu conjecture for œÜ-mixing sequences
Ibragimov-Iosifescu_conjecture_for_œÜ-mi.rephrased: The conjecture concerns the rate of convergence in the central limit theorem for dependent random variables forming a œÜ-mixing sequence, specifically relating the mixing coefficients to the convergence speed.
Ibragimov-Iosifescu_conjecture_for_œÜ-mi.implication_form: An explicit 'If P, then Q' form is not provided in the original query, making a direct formulation challenging.
Ibragimov-Iosifescu_conjecture_for_œÜ-mi.explained: The Ibragimov‚ÄìIosifescu conjecture for œÜ-mixing sequences addresses the limit behavior (convergence in distribution) of the normalized partial sums of certain dependent random variables under the œÜ-mixing condition. It proposes that under specific conditions related to the mixing rate (characterized by the œÜ-function) and the properties of the random variables (e.g., being identically distributed, having finite variance, satisfying certain moment conditions), the properly normalized partial sums converge to a stable distribution (often specified to be non-Gaussian or Gaussian depending on the exact formulation). The conjecture is closely tied to the ergodic theorem but extends it to dependent processes with specific mixing properties. It remains unproven in its strongest forms for all types of œÜ-mixing processes.
related_conjectures: Central Limit Theorem (CLT) for dependent sequences
Chover's law of the iterated logarithm for dependent sequences

Inscribed_square_problem.name: Inscribed square problem
Inscribed_square_problem.rephrased: Does every simple, closed curve in the plane contain at least one inscribed square?
Inscribed_square_problem.implication_form: If a curve is simple and closed, then it contains all four vertices of some square.
Inscribed_square_problem.explained: The Inscribed Square Problem, also known as the Toeplitz Conjecture, states that every simple closed curve (a Jordan curve) in the plane contains the four vertices of some inscribed square. In other words, for any simple closed curve, there exists a square whose four vertices lie exactly on the curve.

Invariant_subspace_problem.name: Invariant subspace problem
Invariant_subspace_problem.rephrased: Does every continuous operator on a complex vector space with completeness (Banach space) have a subspace (other than zero or the whole space) that it maps to itself?
Invariant_subspace_problem.explained: The Invariant Subspace Problem is a fundamental question in functional analysis. It asks whether every bounded linear operator T acting on a complex Banach space X has a non-trivial closed invariant subspace. In other words, is there always a closed subspace Y of X (other than {0} and X itself) such that T(Y) ‚äÜ Y?
related_conjectures: Invariant Subspace Problem for Non-Separable Hilbert Spaces
Invariant Subspace Problem for Specific Operators (e.g., Normal Operators)
Invariant Subspace Problem for Specific Banach Spaces (e.g., Lp spaces, C(K) spaces)

Isomorphism.name: Isomorphism
Isomorphism.explained: An isomorphism is a fundamental concept in mathematics, not necessarily a specific conjecture, but a structure-preserving mapping between two mathematical structures that allows for a reverse mapping (an inverse). Two structures are considered isomorphic if such a mapping exists, meaning they are essentially 'structurally identical' or 'the same in form'. The key characteristic is that the mapping preserves the relevant operations and relations defined on the structures. For example, in group theory, a group isomorphism preserves the group operation; in graph theory, an isomorphism preserves adjacency; in topology, a homeomorphism preserves continuity. Isomorphisms formalize the idea of when two objects can be considered 'the same' for the purposes of the mathematical structures being studied, capturing their essential properties beyond their superficial differences. The notation 'A ‚âÖ B' often denotes that structures A and B are isomorphic.
terms: Homomorphism (a structure-preserving mapping that may not necessarily be invertible)
Inverse (a mapping that, when composed with the original mapping, yields the identity mapping)
Equivalence (a broader concept that includes isomorphisms, but often allows for less structure preservation)
Category Theory (a branch of mathematics that studies structures and mappings (morphisms) in a very general setting, where isomorphisms are a specific type of morphism with an inverse)
Structure (the set of operations, relations, and other features that define a mathematical object)
related_conjectures: Isomorphism Conjecture (in computational complexity theory, e.g., positing that all NP-complete problems are isomorphic under polynomial-time many-one reductions)
Complexity Classes Isomorphism (conjectures about the structure and relationships between different complexity classes, sometimes involving isomorphisms between classes under certain conditions)

Isomorphism_problem_of_Coxeter_groups.name: Isomorphism problem of Coxeter groups
Isomorphism_problem_of_Coxeter_groups.rephrased: Given two Coxeter diagrams, is it possible to determine if they represent the same abstract group?
Isomorphism_problem_of_Coxeter_groups.posed_by: H.S.M. Coxeter (as a general problem in the field)

Jacobian_conjecture.name: Jacobian conjecture
Jacobian_conjecture.rephrased: If a polynomial map from an n-dimensional space to itself has a constant non-zero Jacobian determinant, then it has a polynomial inverse.
Jacobian_conjecture.implication_form: If a polynomial map has a constant non-zero Jacobian determinant, then it has a polynomial inverse.
Jacobian_conjecture.explained: The Jacobian conjecture states that if a polynomial function from an n-dimensional complex affine space to itself has a constant non-zero Jacobian determinant, then it is invertible, and its inverse is also a polynomial function.

Jacobson's_conjecture.name: Jacobson's conjecture
Jacobson's_conjecture.rephrased: In a Noetherian ring, the intersection of all powers of its Jacobson radical is the zero ring (the trivial ring).
Jacobson's_conjecture.implication_form: It is not possible to rewrite the conjecture in the form "If P, then Q" because no formal statement was provided.
Jacobson's_conjecture.explained: Jacobson's conjecture states that for a two-sided Noetherian ring R, the intersection of all powers of its Jacobson radical (the set of all quasi-regular elements, denoted J(R)) is the zero ideal. In other words, ‚à©_{n=1}^‚àû J(R)^n = (0). This means that every element in the intersection must be nilpotent (i.e., some positive integer power of it is zero). The conjecture relies critically on the ring being two-sided Noetherian (both left and right Noetherian).

Jacobson_radical.name: Jacobson radical
Jacobson_radical.rephrased: The Jacobson radical is the set of elements in a ring that annihilate all simple modules, and it is the same whether considering left or right modules.
Jacobson_radical.solved_by: The nilpotency of the Jacobson radical for commutative rings was proven by Nathan Smale, while the general nilpotency conjecture was disproven by Irving Herstein and Derek Henry Faddeev Montgomery.
Jacobson_radical.explained: In mathematics, more specifically ring theory, the Jacobson radical of a ring R is the ideal consisting of those elements in R that annihilate all simple right R-modules. It happens that substituting 'left' in place of 'right' in the definition yields the same ideal, and so the notion is left‚Äìright symmetric.
related_conjectures: Nilpotency of the Jacobson radical in certain rings

Jordan_curve.name: Jordan curve
Jordan_curve.rephrased: A simple closed curve divides the plane into two regions: an interior and an exterior.
Jordan_curve.implication_form: If a curve is a simple closed curve in the plane, then it divides the plane into two regions.
Jordan_curve.explained: The Jordan curve theorem states that every simple closed curve in the plane divides the plane into two regions: one bounded interior region and one unbounded exterior region, and the curve itself is the boundary between them. More formally, if J is a Jordan curve (a continuous, simple closed curve, i.e., a homeomorphism from the circle S¬π to R¬≤), then R¬≤\J is disconnected and has exactly two connected components: one bounded and one unbounded.

Kadison-Singer_problem.name: Kadison‚ÄìSinger problem
Kadison-Singer_problem.rephrased: The Kadison‚ÄìSinger problem asks whether pure states on certain C*-algebras have unique extensions to larger algebras.
Kadison-Singer_problem.implication_form: If a linear functional is a pure state on a certain C*-algebra, then its extension to a larger algebra is unique.
Kadison-Singer_problem.solved_by: Adam Marcus, Daniel Spielman, Nikhil Srivastava
Kadison-Singer_problem.explained: The Kadison-Singer problem, now a theorem proved in 2013, asks: If a pure state on the C*-algebra of bounded operators on a separable infinite-dimensional Hilbert space vanishes on the algebra of all diagonal operators (with respect to some orthonormal basis), must it be uniquely extendable to a pure state on the entire algebra of bounded operators? In simpler terms, it questions the uniqueness of extensions of certain states defined on a subalgebra to the whole algebra.

Kahn-Kalai_conjecture.name: Kahn‚ÄìKalai conjecture
Kahn-Kalai_conjecture.rephrased: The actual threshold for a property in random graphs is close to the expectation threshold.
Kahn-Kalai_conjecture.implication_form: If the expectation threshold is E, then the actual threshold is close to E.

Kakeya_conjecture.name: Kakeya conjecture
Kakeya_conjecture.rephrased: The smallest set that contains a straight line segment of length 1 in every possible direction must have positive measure (be 'thick') in all dimensions greater than 1.
Kakeya_conjecture.implication_form: If a set contains a unit line segment in every direction, then it has positive Lebesgue measure.
Kakeya_conjecture.explained: A Kakeya set, or Besicovitch set, is a set in Euclidean space that contains a unit line segment in every direction. A Kakeya needle set is a subset of a Kakeya set where a rigid needle can be rotated through all angles while remaining within the set. The Kakeya conjecture posits that the Hausdorff dimension of any Kakeya set in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) is exactly \(n\). This means that while Kakeya sets can have Lebesgue measure zero (as shown by Besicovitch), they cannot be too 'thin' in terms of Hausdorff dimension.

Kaplan-Yorke_conjecture.name: Kaplan‚ÄìYorke conjecture
Kaplan-Yorke_conjecture.rephrased: The dimension of a chaotic attractor in a dynamical system can be predicted by sorting the system's rates of expansion (Lyapunov exponents) from fastest to slowest and finding the smallest index where the sum of exponents changes sign, using a specific formula involving the exponents and the trace of the Jacobian matrix.
Kaplan-Yorke_conjecture.implication_form: If a dynamical system has Lyapunov exponents Œª‚ÇÅ ‚â• Œª‚ÇÇ ‚â• ... ‚â• Œª‚Çô and a trace Tr(J) for its Jacobian matrix, then its attractor's dimension d is given by the formula d = k + (1 - Tr(J) / |Œª_{k+1}|) for k being the largest integer such that the sum of the first k exponents is positive, provided certain conditions on the exponents hold (Œª‚ÇÅ to Œª‚Çñ‚Çä‚ÇÅ > 0, Œª‚Çñ‚Çä‚ÇÅ = 0, Œª‚Çñ‚Çä‚ÇÇ to Œª‚Çô ‚â§ 0).
Kaplan-Yorke_conjecture.explained:
The Kaplan‚ÄìYorerte conjecture addresses the Hausdorff dimension of certain attractors in dynamical systems. It proposes a formula for the dimension of a chaotic attractor based on its Lyapunov exponents. Specifically, if the Lyapunov exponents are ordered from largest to smallest as Œª‚ÇÅ ‚â• Œª‚ÇÇ ‚â• ‚ãØ ‚â• Œª‚Çô, then the Hausdorff dimension, denoted dim_H(A), is given by:

 dim_H(A) = k + \frac{ \sum_{i=1}^{m} \lambda_i^+ }{ |\lambda_{m+1}| } 

where:
- k is the dimension of the unstable manifold (equal to the number of positive Lyapunov exponents)
- Œª·µ¢‚Å∫ denotes the positive part of Œª·µ¢ (Œª·µ¢ if Œª·µ¢ > 0, else 0)
- m is the largest integer such that the sum of the first m positive Lyapunov exponents minus the sum of the absolute values of the negative exponents up to that point is non-negative.

This dimension is often called the Kaplan‚ÄìYorke dimension or the Lyapunov dimension.
related_conjectures: Oseledets' theorem (while a theorem, it provides the foundation for defining Lyapunov exponents)

Kaplansky's_conjectures.name: Kaplansky's conjectures
Kaplansky's_conjectures.rephrased: A set of ten conjectures concerning properties of Hopf algebras, proposed by Irving Kaplansky.
Kaplansky's_conjectures.implication_form: If certain properties hold for a Hopf algebra, then specific other properties must also hold (the exact nature depends on the specific conjecture).
Kaplansky's_conjectures.explained: Kaplansky's conjectures refer to a collection of conjectures proposed by the mathematician Irving Kaplansky, primarily concerning properties of group algebras, Banach algebras, and Hopf algebras. The most famous set consists of ten conjectures related to Hopf algebras, but Kaplansky also formulated significant conjectures elsewhere, such as in Banach algebras and group theory. Since the specific conjecture isn't identified, the explanation focuses on the general nature of these conjectures: they are specific, often deep statements about the structure, properties (like amenability or being finite-dimensional), or the existence of certain elements (like zero-divisors) within these algebraic structures.
related_conjectures: Invariant subspace problem (related to certain formulations)
Kaplansky's zero-divisor conjecture for group rings

Kato's_conjecture.name: Kato's conjecture
Kato's_conjecture.rephrased: Does the square root of a uniformly complex elliptic operator, defined via functional calculus, have an analytic domain?
Kato's_conjecture.implication_form: If an operator is uniformly complex elliptic, then its square root (defined via functional calculus) has an analytic domain.
Kato's_conjecture.explained: Kato's conjecture concerns the analyticity properties of the square root of certain types of elliptic operators. It posits that for a uniformly complex elliptic operator L (typically acting on vector-valued functions over a domain in R^n), defined on a bounded Lipschitz domain Œ©, the square root ‚àöL (defined via functional calculus) is an analytic function on Œ©. The precise statement often involves the boundedness and analyticity of the related Dirichlet-to-Neumann map or the Poisson operator associated with the operator L.
related_conjectures: Kato square root problem (for other operators/scales)
Douglas-Rachford conjecture (related to operator theory, sometimes cited in the context of related functional calculus)
Hodge conjecture (related via elliptic complexes like the Hodge Laplacian)

Kauffman-Harary_conjecture.name: Kauffman‚ÄìHarary conjecture
Kauffman-Harary_conjecture.rephrased: Every non-trivial alternating link has exactly one non-orientable spanning surface (up to non-isotopy).
Kauffman-Harary_conjecture.implication_form: If a link is non-trivial and alternating, then it has exactly one non-orientaneous spanning surface (up to non-isotopy).
Kauffman-Harary_conjecture.explained: The Kauffman‚ÄìHarary conjecture, proposed by Louis Kauffman and Frank Harary, states that every non-trivial spatial graph (a graph embedded in 3-dimensional space) is prime. A spatial graph is considered prime if it cannot be decomposed non-trivially. The conjecture specifically addresses prime decomposition with respect to the operation of taking a connected sum of spatial graphs. Two spatial graphs are said to be connected along a graph H if they share an embedding of H and their embeddings do not intersect outside of H. The connected sum is formed by removing a small neighborhood of H from both graphs and gluing them together along the boundary torus or sphere associated with H. A spatial graph is prime if it cannot be expressed as a non-trivial connected sum of two spatial graphs. The conjecture claims that all non-trivial spatial graphs are prime, meaning they cannot be broken down into simpler components via this connected sum operation.
related_conjectures: Kneser conjecture (deals with graph coloring, but related in spirit to decomposition properties)
Additive basis conjectures (related to decomposition principles in other areas)

Kazhdan-Lusztig_polynomial.name: Kazhdan‚ÄìLusztig polynomial
Kazhdan-Lusztig_polynomial.rephrased: The Kazhdan‚ÄìLusztig polynomials are a family of polynomials indexed by pairs of elements in a Coxeter group (like a Weyl group), defined to satisfy specific recursive properties related to the group's structure.
Kazhdan-Lusztig_polynomial.implication_form: It is not possible to rephrase the definition of the Kazhdan‚ÄìLusztig polynomials as an 'If P, then Q' statement, as they are defined by their properties rather than being a statement that implies a consequence.

Kelmans-Seymour_conjecture.name: Kelmans‚ÄìSeymour conjecture
Kelmans-Seymour_conjecture.rephrased: A highly connected graph that cannot be drawn on a plane without crossings must contain a subdivision of the complete graph K5.
Kelmans-Seymour_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph is 5-vertex-connected and non-planar, then it contains a subdivision of K5.
Kelmans-Seymour_conjecture.explained: The Kelmans‚ÄìSeymour conjecture states that every 5-vertex-connected graph that is non-planar contains a subdivision of the complete graph K5. In other words, if a graph is highly connected (specifically, 5-vertex-connected) and cannot be embedded in the plane without edge crossings, then it must contain a structure that resembles K5 with edges subdivided.

Kemnitz's_conjecture.name: Ronald van Kempen's conjecture
Kemnitz's_conjecture.explained: Kemnitz's conjecture, formulated for the integer lattice Z^2 in two dimensions (n=2), states that for any finite set S of lattice points in the plane (points with integer coordinates), there exists a subset T ‚äÜ S with exactly 3 points (n+1=3) such that the centroid of T is also a lattice point. This means the average of the x-coordinates and the average of the y-coordinates of the three points must both be integers. Equivalently, the sum of the x-coordinates and the sum of the y-coordinates of the three points must both be divisible by 3.
related_conjectures: Erd≈ës‚ÄìGinzburg‚ÄìZiv theorem (concerns subset sums modulo n)
Kemnitz's conjecture in higher dimensions (for Z^d with subset size d+1)
Zero-sum subset problems in additive combinatorics

Kepler_conjecture.name: Kepler conjecture
Kepler_conjecture.rephrased: The Kepler conjecture states that the maximum average density achievable by packing identical spheres in three-dimensional space is approximately 74.05%, which is the density found in face-centered cubic and hexagonal close packing arrangements.
Kepler_conjecture.implication_form: If spheres of equal size are packed in three-dimensional Euclidean space, then the average density cannot exceed that of face-centered cubic or hexagonal close packing arrangements.
Kepler_conjecture.explained: The Kepler conjecture states that the maximum density achievable in a packing of identical spheres in three-dimensional Euclidean space is œÄ / ‚àö18 ‚âà 0.74048049123, which is the density achieved by both the face-centered cubic (FCC) and hexagonal close-packed (HCP) arrangements. This means that no arrangement of spheres can achieve a higher average density than these close-packed structures.

Khinchin's_constant.name: Khinchin's constant
Khinchin's_constant.rephrased: For almost all real numbers, the coefficients in their continued fraction expansion have a geometric mean that equals a specific constant called Khinchin's constant (K0).
Khinchin's_constant.implication_form: If a real number has a continued fraction expansion, then for almost all such numbers, the geometric mean of its coefficients equals Khinchin's constant K0.
Khinchin's_constant.explained: Khinchin's theorem (sometimes referred to in the context of Khinchin's constant) states that for almost all real numbers x (with respect to the Lebesgue measure), the coefficients a‚ÇÅ, a‚ÇÇ, a‚ÇÉ, ... in the simple continued fraction expansion of x satisfy the following property: the limit of the geometric mean of the first n coefficients, (a‚ÇÅ * a‚ÇÇ * ... * a_n)^(1/n), as n approaches infinity, exists and equals a specific mathematical constant known as Khinchin's constant, denoted by K‚ÇÄ. This constant is approximately 2.685452016...
related_conjectures: Lochs conjecture (regarding the speed of convergence of the continued fraction expansion)
Gauss-Kuzmin distribution (describing the asymptotic distribution of coefficients in continued fraction expansions)

Kirillov's_conjecture.name: Kirillov's conjecture
Kirillov's_conjecture.rephrased: A nilpotent Lie algebra's irreducible representations can be built from its abelian subalgebras.
Kirillov's_conjecture.implication_form: If a Lie algebra is nilpotent, then all its irreducible representations can be constructed using its abelian subalgebras.
Kirillov's_conjecture.explained: Kirillov's conjecture concerns the irreducibility of certain representations of linear algebraic groups over p-adic fields. It states that for a representation œÄ of the group G = GL(n,F) (where F is a p-adic field) that is irreducible and essentially tempered, the representation œÄ(g.f) (the restriction to the Borel subgroup B) is irreducible for all g not in the unipotent radical of B. More precisely, for the standard representation œÄ_Œ∏ (induced from the Borel subgroup with a character Œ∏), the conjecture asserts that œÄ_Œ∏(g.f) is irreducible for all g not in the unipotent radical of B. The conjecture is known to hold for real groups (n arbitrary) and for p-adic groups in low dimensions (n ‚â§ 3), but remains open for higher dimensions (n ‚â• 4).

Kleene_star.name: Kleene star
Kleene_star.rephrased: The Kleene star operation generates the set of all possible finite strings from a given alphabet.
Kleene_star.implication_form: If V is an alphabet, then V* is the set of all finite sequences of symbols from V.
Kleene_star.explained:
The Kleene star (or Kleene operation, Kleene closure) is a fundamental operation in formal language theory and theoretical computer science. It is **not** a conjecture but a standard mathematical definition. It operates on two main things:

1.  **An Alphabet (V):** Given a finite set `V` of symbols (like {a, b}), the Kleene star operation `V*` generates the set of all possible strings (including the empty string `Œµ`) that can be formed using symbols from `V`, where the length of the strings can be zero or any finite positive integer. This set forms the free monoid generated by `V`, meaning it includes all concatenations of elements from `V`, including the empty concatenation.

2.  **A Formal Language (L):** Given a formal language `L` (a set of strings), the Kleene star operation `L*` generates a new language. This language consists of all finite concatenations of strings taken from `L`, including the empty string. Formally, `L* = { Œµ } ‚à™ L ‚à™ LL ‚à™ LLL ‚à™ ...`. 

In essence, the Kleene star operator (`*`) creates the set of all possible combinations (concatenations) of elements from its operand (alphabet or language), allowing any finite number of repetitions, including zero.
terms: Kleene Plus (+) - similar to Kleene star but excludes the empty string.
related_conjectures: Pumping Lemma for Regular Languages (a theorem used to prove languages are not regular, heavily relies on Kleene star concepts)
Arden's Lemma (a theorem providing a solution for equations involving Kleene stars in regular expressions)
Closure Properties of Regular Languages (union, intersection, complement, etc., often involving Kleene stars)

Kobon_triangle_problem.name: Kobon triangle problem
Kobon_triangle_problem.implication_form: If you have an arrangement of k lines, then the maximum number of triangles formed by their intersections is N(k).
Kobon_triangle_problem.explained: The Kobon triangle problem seeks the maximum number of nonoverlapping triangles that can be formed by an arrangement of k lines in the Euclidean plane. The triangles must have their sides lying entirely on the lines of the arrangement and must not overlap with each other. The maximum number for k lines is denoted by N(k).
related_conjectures: Other conjectures directly related to maximizing triangles in line arrangements are not commonly identified. However, similar problems exist in combinatorial geometry involving arrangements and extremal counts (e.g., maximizing empty polygons or minimizing crossings).

Kouchnirenko's_conjecture.name: Kouchnirenko's conjecture
Kouchnirenko's_conjecture.rephrased: For a system of n polynomial equations in n variables, the number of positive solutions equals the mixed volume of the Newton polytopes if the supports satisfy certain conditions (e.g., forming a Kouchnirenko system).
Kouchnirenko's_conjecture.implication_form: If a system of n polynomial equations in n variables has supports satisfying the conditions of a Kouchnirenko system, then the number of positive solutions is equal to the mixed volume of their Newton polytopes.
Kouchnirenko's_conjecture.explained: Kouchnirenko's conjecture, now a theorem, addresses the minimal number of positive solutions for a system of polynomial equations. Originally, it stated that for a system of n polynomial equations in n variables, all with positive coefficients, the number of positive solutions (counting multiplicity) is at least the number of monomials (terms) across all equations minus n. This conjecture was proven true in 1975 by A. G. Kouchnirenko.

Kronecker-Weber_theorem.name: Kronecker‚ÄìWeber theorem
Kronecker-Weber_theorem.explained: The Kronecker‚ÄìWeber theorem (often referred to as a foundational result rather than a conjecture in its final form) states that every finite abelian extension of the rational numbers Q is contained within some cycloticlean field. In other words, if K/Q is a finite Galois extension with abelian Galois group Gal(K/Q), then K is contained in a cyclotomic field Q(Œ∂_n) for some integer n, where Œ∂_n is a primitive n-th root of unity.
related_conjectures: Class Field Theory (a generalization that provides a complete description of abelian extensions of number fields)
Fermat's Last Theorem (Kronecker's Jugendtraum, a conjecture related to the Kronecker‚ÄìWeber theorem, involves cyclotomic fields and generalizes it to other number fields)

Kronecker_coefficient.name: Kronecker coefficient
Kronecker_coefficient.explained: The Kronecker coefficient g(Œª, Œº, ŒΩ) is defined for three partitions Œª, Œº, ŒΩ of integers. It represents the multiplicity of the irreducible representation corresponding to the partition ŒΩ in the decomposition of the tensor product of the irreducible representations corresponding to partitions Œª and Œº under the symmetric group S_n (for sufficiently large n). In formulaic terms, g(Œª, Œº, ŒΩ) is the multiplicity of the irreducible character œá_ŒΩ in the product of the irreducible characters œá_Œª and œá_Œº. While Kronecker coefficients are defined for all partitions (with the convention that they vanish unless ŒΩ is contained in the 'direct sum' of Œª and Œº), they are particularly significant for partitions of the same integer n, where the symmetric group S_n acts. The challenge lies in computing these coefficients efficiently, which remains a difficult problem in algebraic combinatorics.
related_conjectures: Saxl conjecture (predicts the highest weight in the Kronecker product)
Foulkes conjecture (about Kronecker products of two equal partitions)
P vs NP problem (computing Kronecker coefficients is believed to be computationally hard)

Kummer-Vandiver_conjecture.name: Kummer‚ÄìVandiver conjecture
Kummer-Vandiver_conjecture.rephrased: For any prime number p, p does not divide the class number of the maximal real subfield of the p-th cyclotomic field.
Kummer-Vandiver_conjecture.implication_form: If p is a prime, then p does not divide the class number hK of the maximal real subfield of the p-th cyclotomic field.

Kusner_conjecture.name: Kusner conjecture
Kusner_conjecture.rephrased: The maximum number of points that can be placed in d-dimensional Euclidean space such that all pairs of points are at the same distance from each other is d+1.
Kusner_conjecture.implication_form: If a set of points in d-dimensional Euclidean space exists where all pairs are equidistant, then the size of this set is at most d+1.
Kusner_conjecture.explained: The Kusner conjecture concerns the maximum size of equilateral sets in Euclidean space. An equilateral set is a set of points where all pairwise distances are equal. The conjecture states that the equilateral dimension of d-dimensional Euclidean space (\(\mathbb{R}^d\)) is exactly d+1. This means that the largest possible equilateral set in \(\mathbb{R}^d\) has d+1 points, and such a set exists (e.g., the vertices of a regular simplex). While it is known that d+1 is achievable, the conjecture asserts that no larger equilateral set exists in any dimension d > 1.

K√∂the_conjecture.name: K√∂the conjecture
K√∂the_conjecture.explained: The K√∂the conjecture, formulated by Gottfried K√∂the in 1930, states that if a ring R has no nilpotent ideals other than the zero ideal, then it also has no nil one-sided ideals other than the zero ideal.

Lafforgue's_theorem.name: Lafforgue's theorem
Lafforgue's_theorem.rephrased: Lafforgue's theorem establishes a connection between automorphic forms on general linear groups over certain algebraic function fields and representations of Galois groups.
Lafforgue's_theorem.implication_form: If the Langlands correspondence holds for general linear groups over algebraic function fields, then it is established by Lafforgue's theorem.
Lafforgue's_theorem.explained: Lafforgue's theorem establishes a correspondence between certain automorphic representations of GL(n) over a field of the form F_q((t)) (where q is a power of a prime) and certain representations of the Langlands dual group, which is related to the Galois group, of the base field. This correspondence completes the Langlands program for general linear groups GL(n) over algebraic function fields (specifically, curves over finite fields). It demonstrates that the automorphic representations, which are representations of the adelic points of GL(n), correspond to representations of the Weil-Deligne group or Galois group that are tempered at infinity and satisfy certain conditions (like being conjugate self-dual). This provides a proof of the local Langlands correspondence for archimedean places and confirms a major part of the global Langlands program for function fields.

terms.Automorphic forms/representations: Mathematical objects that are invariant under a group action, generalizing classical modular forms to higher rank groups. Automorphic representations are the irreducible representations arising from these forms.
terms.Langlands Program: A set of far-reaching and influential conjectures by Robert Langlands proposing deep connections between number theory, representation theory, and algebraic geometry, linking automorphic forms to Galois representations.
terms.Galois representations: Homomorphisms from the absolute Galois group of a field to the automorphism group of some object (like GL(n,C) or general linear groups over a field). They encode arithmetic information.
terms.Weil group: A subgroup of the absolute Galois group used in the Langlands program to refine the correspondence, particularly for p-adic and archimedean fields.
terms.Adelic points: Points of a group defined over the adeles, a completion of the rational functions on an algebraic curve, used to formulate representations in the Langlands program.
terms.General Linear Group GL(n): The group of n by n invertible matrices with entries in a field.
terms.Algebraic Function Fields: Fields of algebraic functions on algebraic curves.
terms.Correspondence: The proposed relationship between automorphic forms and Galois representations.
terms.Conjugate Self-Dual: A condition on representations ensuring they are related to their own dual via a specific intertwining operator.
terms.Tempered representations: A type of representation that appears in the discrete spectrum of certain spaces (like L^2 of the group) and is important for the correspondence.
terms.Langlands Dual Group: The group obtained by exchanging the roles of roots and weights in the root system of the group GL(n).

Lagrangian_submanifold.name: Lagrangian submanifold
Lagrangian_submanifold.rephrased: A Lagrangian submanifold is a special type of submanifold in a symplectic manifold where the symplectic form vanishes completely when restricted to it, and its dimension is half that of the ambient manifold.
Lagrangian_submanifold.implication_form: If M is a symplectic manifold with symplectic form œâ, and L is a submanifold of M with dimension half of dim(M), then L is Lagrangian if œâ, restricted to L, is identically zero.
Lagrangian_submanifold.posed_by: Named after Joseph-Louis Lagrange, though formally defined in modern symplectic geometry.
Lagrangian_submanifold.explained: A Lagrangian submanifold is a special type of submanifold defined within a symplectic manifold. It is a smooth submanifold L of a symplectic manifold (M, œâ) such that the symplectic form œâ restricts to zero on L, i.e., œâ|_L = 0. Crucially, it must have the same dimension as the space of symplectic forms allow, which is half the dimension of the ambient symplectic manifold M (if M is even-dimensional). Furthermore, for the submanifold to be Lagrangian, it must be maximal isotropic, meaning its dimension is maximal among isotropic submanifolds (those where œâ restricts to zero). In the context of Hamiltonian mechanics, Lagrangian submanifolds arise naturally as the submanifolds where the action functional is defined, representing the possible trajectories of a system starting from an initial position and momenta.

Lambda_g_conjecture.name: Lambda g conjecture
Lambda_g_conjecture.rephrased: The Lambda_g conjecture states that the intersection number of the tautological class \lambda_g (the top Chern class of the Hodge bundle) with the fundamental class of the Deligne-Mumford compactification \bar{M}_{g,n} is equal to the genus g Faber-Knudsen class.
Lambda_g_conjecture.implication_form: If the intersection number of \lambda_g with the fundamental class of \bar{M}_{g,n} is computed, then it equals the genus g Faber-Knudsen class.
Lambda_g_conjecture.posed_by: Seth A. Kleinerman (affiliated with Harvard University at the time)
Lambda_g_conjecture.explained: The Œª_g conjecture, proposed by R. Pandharipande and T. Graber (later refined by C. Faber), addresses the intersection theory on the Deligne-Mumford moduli space \(\bar{M}_{g,n}\) of stable algebraic curves. It concerns the tautological ring generated by kappa classes \(\kappa_i\), which are the Chern classes of the cotangent bundles to the moduli space. The conjecture states that the class \(c_g\), which is the g-th power of the Chern character of the cotangent bundle (related to the boundary strata), is equal to the sum over all partitions of \(g-1\) of the classes corresponding to those partitions in the tautological ring. More formally, it relates the integral of certain cohomology classes (involving the kappa classes) over the moduli space to the number of partitions of an integer. A key formulation involves the statement that the integral of the class \(\pi_* c_g\) (where \(\pi\) is the projection from the universal curve) is equal to the number of partitions of \(g- (n-1)\) or something similar, but the exact statement varies depending on the formulation and the context (e.g., for \(n=0\), for \(n=2\), etc.).

Landau's_constants.name: Landau's constants
Landau's_constants.rephrased: Landau's constants describe the maximum possible coefficients in the Taylor series expansion of certain special functions related to univalent functions, specifically bounding the coefficients for the Koebe function.
Landau's_constants.implication_form: If a function belongs to a specific class of univalent functions, then its Taylor coefficients satisfy certain upper bounds given by Landau's constants.
Landau's_constants.explained: Landau's conjecture concerns the existence of absolute constants \( B \) and \( L \) such that for any holomorphic function \( f \) defined on the unit disk, the image \( f(\mathbb{D}) \) contains a disk of radius \( B \), and the function \( f \) itself is bounded in some way related to its derivative at zero, involving constants related to the Bloch space and Koebe principle. It directly addresses the size of the image under certain holomorphic functions, refining or bounding the implications of Bloch's theorem.
related_conjectures: de Branges' theorem (now a theorem, related to Bieberbach)

Lander_Parkin_and_Selfridge_conjecture.name: Lander, Parkin, and Selfridge conjecture
Lander_Parkin_and_Selfridge_conjecture.rephrased: If two different sets of k-th powers have the same sum, then the total number of terms in these two sets combined must be at least k.
Lander_Parkin_and_Selfridge_conjecture.implication_form: If the sum of some k-th powers equals the sum of other k-th powers, then the total number of terms in both sets must be at least k.
Lander_Parkin_and_Selfridge_conjecture.explained: The Lander, Parkin, and Selfridge conjecture states that if the sum of m terms, each a k-th power, equals the sum of n terms, each a k-th power, then the total number of terms (m + n) must be at least k.

Lange's_conjecture.name: Lange's conjecture
Lange's_conjecture.rephrased: A conjecture about the stability conditions for vector bundles on algebraic curves.
Lange's_conjecture.implication_form: If [specific condition on vector bundles and curves is met], then [stability holds] (exact statement not provided).
Lange's_conjecture.solved_by: Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas and Barbara Russo
Lange's_conjecture.explained: Lange's conjecture, proposed by Herbert Lange, pertains to the Brill-Noether theory for vector bundles on algebraic curves. It addresses the existence and properties of stable vector bundles of fixed rank and determinant on a curve of genus g. Specifically, it concerns the Brill-Noether variety parameterizing semistable vector bundles of rank r and fixed determinant with specified invariants, and conjectured that under certain conditions, this variety is non-empty and has the expected dimension. This conjecture was proven by Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas and Barbara Russo in 1999.
related_conjectures: Green's Conjecture (on the syzygies of curves)
The Gieseker-Pulte conjecture (on the birational type of moduli spaces)
The conjecture on the existence of Gieseker-Pulte bundles
The Brill-Noether conjecture for parabolic bundles
subjects: Algebraic Number Theory (Connections to moduli spaces)

Langlands-Shelstad_fundamental_lemma.name: Langlands‚ÄìShelstad fundamental lemma
Langlands-Shelstad_fundamental_lemma.rephrased: A fundamental lemma conjectured by Robert Langlands states that certain complex integrals associated with mathematical structures called 'reductive groups' (specifically, orbital integrals on one group relate directly to 'stable orbital integrals' on related, smaller groups called 'endoscopic groups'). This connection is crucial for understanding a major mathematical framework called the Langlands program.
Langlands-Shelstad_fundamental_lemma.implication_form: If an orbital integral is computed on a reductive group over a local field, then the stable orbital integral on its endoscopic groups can be determined.
Langlands-Shelstad_fundamental_lemma.solved_by: Ng√¥ B·∫£o Ch√¢u and G√©rard Laumon
Langlands-Shelstad_fundamental_lemma.explained:
The Langlands‚ÄìShelstad fundamental lemma is a key technical conjecture within the Langlands program. It establishes a precise relationship between two types of orbital integrals associated with reductive groups and their endoscopic groups. Formally, it states:

Let \(G\) be a connected reductive group over a local field \(F\), and let \(\tilde{G}_1, \dots, \tilde{G}_m\) be the endoscopic groups of \(G\) (which depend on the characteristic of \(F\)). For \(\gamma \in G(F)\) and \(\tilde{\gamma} \in \tilde{G}_i(F)\) (an endoscopic transfer of \(\gamma\)), the conjecture asserts that:

\[\int_{G(F)\backslash G(F)_{\gamma}} \phi(g) \, dg = \sum_{j=1}^m \sum_{\text{Lusztig\'s parameters matching the endoscopic data}} \int_{\tilde{G}_j(F)\backslash \tilde{G}_j(F)_{\tilde{\gamma}}} \psi_{\text{end}}(g) \, dg\]

where \(\phi\) is an arbitrary \(\gamma\)-fixed function (invariant under the stabilizer of \(\gamma\)), and \(\psi_{\text{end}}\) is the endoscopic transfer of \(\phi\). The left-hand side is the (weighted) orbital integral of \(\phi\) at \(\gamma\), while the right-hand side is the sum of weighted stable orbital integrals for the endoscopic data.
related_conjectures: Arthur-Selberg trace formula (specifically the endoscopic part)

Laplace-Beltrami_operator.name: Laplace‚ÄìBeltrami operator
Laplace-Beltrami_operator.rephrased: The Laplace-Beltrami operator is a generalization of the standard Laplacian from flat space to curved surfaces or higher-dimensional manifolds, measuring the total curvature of a function defined on such a surface.
Laplace-Beltrami_operator.explained: The Laplace‚ÄìBeltrami operator is a generalization of the standard Laplace operator from Euclidean space to functions defined on smooth Riemannian manifolds (or pseudo-Riemannian manifolds). It acts on scalar functions (or sections of vector bundles) defined on the manifold. For a function f on a Riemannian manifold with metric tensor g, the Laplace‚ÄìBeltrami operator Œîf is defined as the divergence of the covariant derivative of the gradient of f. In coordinates, it involves second partial derivatives and the Christoffel symbols of the metric. It plays a crucial role in differential geometry, analysis on manifolds, physics (e.g., wave equations, heat equations, quantum mechanics), and image processing.

Laplace_operator.name: Laplace operator
Laplace_operator.explained: The Laplace operator, or Laplacian, is a second-order differential operator named after Pierre-Simon Laplace. It is defined as the divergence of the gradient of a scalar function on Euclidean space. For a scalar function f, the Laplacian is given by the divergence of its gradient, ‚àá ¬∑ ‚àáf, which is often written as ‚àá¬≤f or ‚àÜf. In Cartesian coordinates, for a function f(x‚ÇÅ, x‚ÇÇ, ..., x‚Çô), the Laplacian is the sum of the non-mixed second partial derivatives: ‚àá¬≤f = ‚àÇ¬≤f/‚àÇx‚ÇÅ¬≤ + ‚àÇ¬≤f/‚àÇx‚ÇÇ¬≤ + ... + ‚àÇ¬≤f/‚àÇx‚Çô¬≤. The Laplacian appears in various fields including mathematics, physics, and engineering, notably in the heat equation, wave equation, Poisson's equation, and in describing gravitational and fluid potentials.

Latin_squares.name: Latin squares
Latin_squares.rephrased: A Latin square is an n √ó n grid filled with n distinct symbols, each appearing exactly once in every row and column.
Latin_squares.implication_form: If n is a positive integer, then there exists an n √ó n Latin square.
Latin_squares.solved_by: Existence for all n except 2 is proven; Euler's specific conjecture about orders 4n+2 was disproven.
Latin_squares.explained: A Latin square of order n is an n √ó n array where each cell contains one of n distinct symbols, such that each symbol appears exactly once in each row and exactly once in each column. Formally, for symbols S = {1, 2, ..., n}, a Latin square can be represented as a function L: {1, 2, ..., n} √ó {1, 2, ..., n} ‚Üí S, such that for each fixed i, the map j ‚Ü¶ L(i,j) is a bijection from {1, 2, ..., n} to S, and for each fixed k, the map i ‚Ü¶ L(i,k) is a bijection from {1, 2, ..., n} to S.
related_conjectures: Existence of Latin squares for all orders n (which holds except for n=2 and n=3, but it's known they exist for all n ‚â• 1 except possibly some small cases, though the original text mentions Euler beginning work on the problem, likely referring to the existence question or orthogonal Latin squares).

Lebesgue's_universal_covering_problem.name: Lebesgue's universal covering problem
Lebesgue's_universal_covering_problem.implication_form: If there exists a convex shape of area S that can contain every set of diameter one, then the minimal such area is S.
Lebesgue's_universal_covering_problem.explained: Lebesgue's universal covering problem seeks the convex shape of minimal area that can contain any planar set with a diameter of one, regardless of its shape, after allowing for rotation, translation, and reflection.
