The diameter of a set is defined as the supremum of the distances between any two points within it. The covering shape must be congruent to a convex set and must be able to enclose a set of diameter one via some combination of rotation, translation, and reflection. The goal is to find the convex set with the smallest possible area that satisfies this universal covering property for all sets of diameter one.

Lebesgue_measure.name: Lebesgue measure
Lebesgue_measure.rephrased: A way to assign a 'size' (like length, area, or volume) to sets in Euclidean space, generalizing the standard measures for one, two, and three dimensions.
Lebesgue_measure.implication_form: If one defines a measure on subsets of Euclidean space satisfying certain properties, then it coincides with the Lebesgue measure for simple geometric shapes and can be used to define the Lebesgue integral.
Lebesgue_measure.explained: The Lebesgue measure is a fundamental concept in measure theory, not a conjecture but a standard construction. It assigns a measure (length in 1D, area in 2D, volume in 3D, and higher-dimensional analogues) to subsets of Euclidean space ‚Ñù‚Åø. For n=1,2,3, it coincides with the standard notions of length, area, and volume. The construction involves defining the measure on intervals (or boxes) first and then extending it to all measurable sets via the concept of outer measure, sigma-algebras, and sigma-additivity. A set is Lebesgue-measurable if its boundary is 'small' in a precise sense, and the Lebesgue measure is the unique complete measure extending the standard volume on bounded rectangles.
related_conjectures: The nature of the axiom of choice and its implications for measure theory (e.g., Banach-Tarski paradox highlights the necessity of restricting measurability).

Legendre's_conjecture.name: Legendre's conjecture
Legendre's_conjecture.rephrased: For every positive integer n, there is at least one prime number between n¬≤ and (n+1)¬≤.
Legendre's_conjecture.implication_form: If n is a positive integer, then there exists a prime number between n¬≤ and (n+1)¬≤.
Legendre's_conjecture.explained: Legendre's conjecture states that for every positive integer n, there exists at least one prime number p such that n¬≤ < p < (n+1)¬≤.
related_conjectures: Bertrand's postulate (which guarantees a prime between n and 2n)
Goldbach conjecture (concerning even numbers as sums of primes)
Prime number theorem (describing the asymptotic distribution of primes)

Lehmer's_conjecture.name: Lehmer's conjecture
Lehmer's_conjecture.rephrased: For any polynomial with integer coefficients, if it is not a monomial (like x^n or c*x^n), then the product of the absolute values of its roots that lie outside the unit circle (the Mahler measure) must be greater than some fixed constant Œº > 1.
Lehmer's_conjecture.implication_form: If a polynomial with integer coefficients is not a monomial, then its Mahler measure is greater than some absolute constant Œº > 1.
Lehmer's_conjecture.explained: Lehmer's conjecture asserts that there exists an absolute constant Œº > 1 such that every polynomial with integer coefficients, P(x) ‚àà ‚Ñ§[x], that is not a product of cyclotomic polynomials, has a Mahler measure greater than Œº. The Mahler measure of a polynomial is defined as the product of the absolute values of its roots that lie outside the closed unit disk. Cyclotomic polynomials, which have all roots on the unit circle, have a Mahler measure of 1. The conjecture claims that any other polynomial with integer coefficients must have a Mahler measure bounded below by some constant greater than 1.
related_conjectures: Polynomial time versions in computational number theory

Lehmer's_totient_problem.name: Lehmer's totient problem
Lehmer's_totient_problem.rephrased: No composite number n exists such that œÜ(n) divides n-1.
Lehmer's_totient_problem.implication_form: If n is composite, then œÜ(n) does not divide n-1.
Lehmer's_totient_problem.explained: Lehmer's totient problem is an unsolved conjecture in number theory that asks whether there exists any composite number n such that Euler's totient function œÜ(n) divides n ‚àí 1. It is known that œÜ(n) = n ‚àí 1 if and only if n is prime. Therefore, the conjecture posits that for composite numbers, œÜ(n) does not divide n ‚àí 1, and all composite numbers fail to satisfy this divisibility condition.
related_conjectures: The problem of whether œÜ(n) divides n-1 only for primes

Leinster_group.name: Leinster group
Leinster_group.rephrased: A finite group is a Leinster group if its order equals the sum of the orders of its proper normal subgroups.
Leinster_group.implication_form: If a finite group has an order equal to the sum of the orders of its proper normal subgroups, then it is a Leinster group.
Leinster_group.explained: A Leinster group is a finite group G for which the order of G equals the sum of the orders of all its proper normal subgroups. Formally, if N(G) denotes the set of proper normal subgroups of G (excluding G itself but including the trivial subgroup), then |G| = œÉ(N(G)), where œÉ denotes the sum of the orders of the elements in the set.

related_conjectures.name: Simplicity Conjecture
related_conjectures.description: A conjecture concerning the probability that a randomly selected p-group is simple.

related_conjectures.name: Ore's Conjecture
related_conjectures.description: The conjecture that every element of a finite non-abelian simple group is a commutator.

related_conjectures.name: Thompson's Conjecture
related_conjectures.description: A conjecture regarding finite simple groups, specifically about the existence of certain subgroups.

related_conjectures.name: Schreier Conjecture
related_conjectures.description: A conjecture that the Schreier conjecture is true if and only if every finite simple group has a trivial center.

Lemoine's_conjecture.name: Lemoine's conjecture
Lemoine's_conjecture.rephrased: Every odd integer greater than 5 can be written as the sum of an odd prime and an even semiprime.
Lemoine's_conjecture.implication_form: If an odd integer is greater than 5, then it can be expressed as the sum of an odd prime and an even semiprime.
Lemoine's_conjecture.explained: Lemoine's conjecture, also known as Levy's conjecture, states that every odd integer greater than 5 can be expressed as the sum of an odd prime and an even semiprime.

Lenstra-Pomerance-Wagstaff_conjecture.name: Lenstra‚ÄìPomerance‚ÄìWagstaff conjecture
Lenstra-Pomerance-Wagstaff_conjecture.rephrased: The Lenstra‚ÄìPomerance‚ÄìWagstaff conjecture states that there are infinitely many Sophie Germain primes, which are primes p such that 2p + 1 is also prime.
Lenstra-Pomerance-Wagstaff_conjecture.implication_form: If p is prime and 2p + 1 is prime (i.e., p is a Sophie Germain prime), then there exist infinitely many such primes.
Lenstra-Pomerance-Wagstaff_conjecture.explained: The Lenstra‚ÄìPomerance‚ÄìWagstaff (LPW) conjecture addresses the density of Mersenne primes. It proposes a conjectural asymptotic estimate for the number of Mersenne primes less than a given bound x. The conjecture is based on the connection between Mersenne numbers (M_p = 2^p - 1 for prime p) and certain prime factors called Germain primes (or Sophie Germain primes). It conjectures that the number of primes p (called 'good' primes in this context) for which 2p + 1 divides the Mersenne number M_p is approximately c * x / (log x)^2, where c is a positive constant. This density is analogous to the conjectured density of Sophie Germain primes themselves, as stated in the Bateman‚ÄìHorn conjecture.
terms: Prime number theorem for primes in arithmetic progressions

Leopoldt's_conjecture.name: Leopoldt's conjecture
Leopoldt's_conjecture.rephrased: The p-adic regulator of a number field does not vanish.
Leopoldt's_conjecture.implication_form: If Leopoldt's conjecture holds, then the p-adic regulator does not vanish.
Leopoldt's_conjecture.explained: Leopoldt's conjecture, formulated by H.-W. Leopoldt in 1962 and further developed in 1975, pertains to number fields in algebraic number theory. It states that for any algebraic number field K, any prime number p, and any sufficiently large integer n, the p-adic regulator (an analogue of the classical regulator defined using p-adic logarithms introduced by Leopoldt himself) does not vanish. This means that the p-adic regulator is a non-zero element in the ring of p-adic integers, indicating that the units in the ring of integers of K have a specific p-adic logarithmic independence property. The conjecture is crucial as it implies that the p-adic logarithm map from the group of units modulo roots of unity to the p-adic logarithm of the ideal class group has full rank.
related_conjectures: Kummer's conjecture (on the vanishing of the real regulator)
Iwasawa theory (deals with p-adic numbers and has connections to Leopoldt's conjecture)

Lie_group.name: Lie group
Lie_group.rephrased: A Lie group is a mathematical structure that combines the properties of a group (a set with an associative operation, identity, and inverses) with those of a geometric surface (a manifold, which looks locally like flat space). This means you can perform smooth, continuous operations like multiplication and inversion on the group elements.
Lie_group.implication_form: If a mathematical object is a group and also a smooth manifold, then it is a Lie group.
Lie_group.explained: A Lie group is a mathematical structure that combines the algebraic concepts of a group with the geometric concepts of a differentiable manifold. Formally, it is a finite-dimensional real smooth manifold G (a Hausdorff space that is locally Euclidean) equipped with a group structure (a binary operation ¬∑, identity element e, and inversion map ¬∑‚Ü¶¬π‚Åª¬π) such that the multiplication map (g,h)‚Ü¶g¬∑h: G√óG‚ÜíG and the inversion map g‚Ü¶g‚Åª¬π: G‚ÜíG are both smooth (infinitely differentiable) maps. This smooth structure makes Lie groups fundamental objects in the study of continuous symmetries.
related_conjectures: Yang-Mills Existence and Mass Gap (Mathematical Physics)
Classification of finite simple groups (Group Theory)

Lindel√∂f_hypothesis.name: Lindel√∂f hypothesis
Lindel√∂f_hypothesis.rephrased: The Lindel√∂f hypothesis states that the Riemann zeta function, when evaluated on the critical line (where the real part is 1/2), does not grow too quickly as the imaginary part becomes large. Specifically, its size is bounded by a very slow-growing function of the imaginary part.
Lindel√∂f_hypothesis.implication_form: If the Riemann hypothesis is true, then the Lindel√∂f hypothesis holds.
Lindel√∂f_hypothesis.explained: The Lindel√∂f hypothesis is a conjecture concerning the growth of the Riemann zeta function Œ∂(s) on the critical line, where s = 1/2 + it for real t. It states that for any Œµ > 0, Œ∂(1/2 + it) does not grow faster than any positive power of |t| as |t| approaches infinity. More formally, it asserts that lim sup_{|t| ‚Üí ‚àû} |Œ∂(1/2 + it)| / |t|^Œµ = 1. This means that Œ∂(1/2 + it) is bounded by a constant times |t|^Œµ for large |t| and any Œµ > 0.

Linnik's_theorem.name: Linnik's theorem
Linnik's_theorem.rephrased: There are universal constants c and L such that for any arithmetic progression defined by a + n*d (where n is a positive integer), with a and d coprime integers and 1 ‚â§ a < d, the smallest prime in this progression is at most d^L * (log(d))^c.
Linnik's_theorem.implication_form: If a and d are coprime positive integers with 1 ‚â§ a ‚â§ d-1, then there exists a prime p such that p = a + n*d for some positive integer n and p ‚â§ d^L * (log(d))^c.
Linnik's_theorem.explained: Linnik's theorem states that there exist positive constants c and L such that for any coprime positive integers a and d with 1 ‚â§ a ‚â§ d - 1, the arithmetic progression a + nd (where n runs through the positive integers) contains a prime p satisfying p ‚â§ c * d^L. This theorem provides a quantitative bound on the smallest prime in such an arithmetic progression, complementing Dirichlet's theorem which guarantees infinitely many primes but does not specify their size.

Littlewood_conjecture.name: Littlewood conjecture
Littlewood_conjecture.rephrased: For any two irrational numbers, it's impossible to find sequences of integers where both numbers are simultaneously very close to integers when scaled by those integers.
Littlewood_conjecture.implication_form: If there exist integers n and integers k, m such that the distance from nŒ± to the nearest integer is less than 1/n^{1/2} and the distance from nŒ≤ to the nearest integer is less than 1/n^{1/2}, then the product of these distances times n approaches zero as n increases.
Littlewood_conjecture.explained:
The Littlewood conjecture is an open problem in Diophantine approximation. It states that for any two real numbers Œ± and Œ≤, the following limit inferior is zero:

lim inf_{n‚Üí‚àû} n ‚ãÖ ||nŒ±|| ‚ãÖ ||nŒ≤|| = 0

where ||x|| denotes the distance from x to the nearest integer. In other words, for any fixed Œ± and Œ≤, there are infinitely many positive integers n such that both nŒ± and nŒ≤ are simultaneously very close to integers (their distances to the nearest integers being small), and the product of n and these two distances becomes arbitrarily small infinitely often.
related_conjectures: Known results include connections to the work of Dirichlet, Hurwitz, and Khinchin on simultaneous Diophantine approximation, but these are theorems rather than conjectures. The conjecture is often considered alongside problems in uniform distribution theory.

Lov√°sz_conjecture.name: Lov√°sz conjecture
Lov√°sz_conjecture.rephrased: Every finite, connected graph where all vertices are equivalent (vertex-transitive) contains a path that visits every vertex exactly once (a Hamiltonian path).
Lov√°sz_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph is finite, connected, and vertex-transitive, then it has a Hamiltonian path.
Lov√°sz_conjecture.explained: The Lov√°sz conjecture (1969), now standardly stated, asserts that every finite, connected graph that is vertex-transitive contains a Hamiltonian path. A Hamiltonian path visits each vertex exactly once. Although L√°szl√≥ Lov√°sz originally posed the problem in the opposite form, the current formulation‚Äîthat vertex-transitive graphs possess Hamiltonian paths‚Äîhas become widely accepted and studied.

Lo√Øc_Merel.name: Lo√Øc Merel
Lo√Øc_Merel.rephrased: This query appears to refer to Lo√Øc Merel, a French mathematician specializing in modular forms and number theory. However, no specific conjecture name, statement, or details about its formulation or status (solved or unsolved) are provided in the input.
Lo√Øc_Merel.implication_form: None (insufficient information provided to formulate an implication)
Lo√Øc_Merel.explained: Lo√Øc Merel is a prominent French mathematician known for his significant contributions to number theory, particularly in the areas of modular forms and Diophantine equations. While he is not associated with a single, named conjecture, his work often intersects with deep conjectures in arithmetic geometry. He is particularly known for his contributions to the proof of the Modularity Theorem (formerly Shimura-Taniyama-Weil conjecture) and for joint work with Henri Darmon on conjectures relating rational points on certain curves to automorphic forms.

Lucas-Wieferich_prime.name: Lucas‚ÄìWieferich prime
Lucas-Wieferich_prime.rephrased: A Lucas‚ÄìWieferich prime is a prime number that satisfies a specific condition related to Lucas sequences and is analogous to the concept of a Wieferich prime.
Lucas-Wieferich_prime.implication_form: If a prime satisfies the Lucas‚ÄìWieferich condition, then it is a Lucas‚ÄìWieferich prime.
Lucas-Wieferich_prime.posed_by: Arthur Wieferich (in the context of Fermat's Last Theorem, though the specific Lucas‚ÄìWieferich concept may have been formalized later)
Lucas-Wieferich_prime.explained: A Wieferich prime is a prime number p such that p¬≤ divides 2^{p-1} - 1. This condition is stronger than Fermat's Little Theorem, which states that for any odd prime p, p divides 2^{p-1} - 1. Wieferich primes were first described by Arthur Wieferich in 1909 in works pertaining to Fermat's Last Theorem. There are only two known Wieferich primes: 1093 and 3511.

Lyapunov_dimension.name: Lyapunov dimension
Lyapunov_dimension.implication_form: n/a (the text describes a definition/concept rather than a conjecture with a hypothesis and conclusion)

Lyapunov_exponent.name: Lyapunov exponent
Lyapunov_exponent.rephrased: The Lyapunov exponent measures how quickly two very similar starting points in a system diverge over time.
Lyapunov_exponent.implication_form: If two trajectories start very close, then their separation grows exponentially over time.
Lyapunov_exponent.solved_by: Various mathematicians (rigorous definition by Oseledets' theorem, estimation problem addressed by Ruelle, Eckmann, etc.)
Lyapunov_exponent.explained: The Lyapunov exponent (or Lyapunov characteristic exponent) is a fundamental concept in the theory of dynamical systems. It quantifies the exponential rate at which infinitesimally close trajectories in a system diverge or converge over time. For a dynamical system, one or more Lyapunov exponents are defined, characterizing the average growth or decay rates of infinitesimal perturbations starting from a given point in the phase space. Formally, for a dynamical system defined by a map f or a flow Œ¶_t, the Lyapunov exponent Œª for an orbit is defined as the limit (where it exists) of the average logarithmic growth rate of the distance between points infinitesimally close to the orbit. Positive exponents indicate exponential divergence (chaotic behavior in the vicinity), negative exponents indicate exponential convergence (stability), and zero exponents indicate neutral behavior.

terms.explanation: A system governed by one or more ordinary differential equations (continuous time) or a difference equation (discrete time), describing the evolution of points in a geometric space.
A space in which all possible states of a system are represented, typically with the system's variables as axes. The evolution of the system is represented by a flow or a trajectory in this space.
The path traced by a point in the phase space under the action of the dynamical system over time.
Trajectories that start very close to each other in the phase space, differing by an arbitrarily small initial separation vector Œ¥‚ÇÄ.

A concept in dynamical systems where a fixed point or invariant set is stable if, for any neighborhood of the point, there exists another neighborhood such that any point within the first neighborhood remains in the second neighborhood for all forward time. Lyapunov exponents provide a quantitative measure related to stability.
The behavior of certain dynamical systems that are highly sensitive to initial conditions (exhibited by positive Lyapunov exponents), leading to complex, aperiodic long-term behavior.
A fundamental theorem in ergodic theory that provides conditions under which the Lyapunov exponents exist almost surely and their values can be determined for ergodic systems.

related_conjectures: Properties of Lyapunov exponents in non-uniformly hyperbolic systems.
Relations between Lyapunov exponents and entropy or dimension in complex systems.
Conjectures regarding the simplicity (distinctness) of Lyapunov exponents for generic systems.

Lyapunov_function.name: Lyapunov function
Lyapunov_function.rephrased: A Lyapunov function is a scalar-valued function used to determine the stability of an equilibrium point in a system of ordinary differential equations by ensuring the function decreases along solutions of the system.
Lyapunov_function.implication_form: If a continuously differentiable function exists that is positive definite at the equilibrium point and its derivative is negative semi-definite, then the equilibrium point is stable.
Lyapunov_function.solved_by: Not a problem to be solved; a method/tool
Lyapunov_function.explained: In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs) and dynamical systems, a Lyapunov function (or Lyapunov's function or Lyapun. function) is a scalar function defined on a set containing an equilibrium point of an autonomous system. If this function satisfies certain conditions, it can be used to prove the stability (Lyapunov stability) of that equilibrium point. Specifically, a continuously differentiable function V(x) is a Lyapunov function for an equilibrium point (typically the origin) if: 1) V(x) is positive definite (V(x) > 0 for all x ‚â† 0, and V(0) = 0), and 2) The time derivative of V along the trajectories of the system, VÃá(x) = ‚àáV(x) ¬∑ f(x), is negative semi-definite (VÃá(x) ‚â§ 0 for all x). If VÃá(x) is negative definite (VÃá(x) < 0 for all x ‚â† 0), then the equilibrium is asymptotically stable. The concept generalizes to Markov chains as a Foster-Lyapunov function for proving positive recurrence and stability.

Lychrel_number.name: Lychrel number
Lychrel_number.rephrased: A Lychrel number is a natural number that never forms a palindrome after repeated reversal of its digits and addition.
Lychrel_number.implication_form: If a natural number does not form a palindrome through iterative reverse-and-add operations, then it is a Lychrel number.
Lychrel_number.posed_by: Originated as a concept related to the 196-algorithm
Lychrel_number.explained: A Lychrel number is a natural number that does not form a palindrome through an iterative process involving repeatedly reversing its digits and adding the original number and the reversed number. This process is known as the reverse-and-add operation. The term 'Lychrel' was coined by Wade Van Landingham, referencing the anagram 'Cheryl'. While the reverse-and-add process is well-defined, it remains unproven whether any natural numbers exist that never produce a palindrome through this process in base 10, although many such numbers, including 196, are strongly suspected to be Lychrel numbers based on heuristic and statistical evidence.
related_conjectures: The existence of Lych. rel numbers in base 10

MLC_conjecture.name: MLC conjecture
MLC_conjecture.rephrased: The Mandelbrot set consists of all complex numbers c for which the iteration of the function f_c(z) = z¬≤ + c remains bounded.
MLC_conjecture.implication_form: If the iteration of f_c(z) = z¬≤ + c remains bounded, then c is in the Mandelbrot set.
MLC_conjecture.explained: The Mandelbrot Set Locating Conjecture (MLC) posits that the Mandelbrot set is locally connected. This means that every point in the Mandelbrot set has a neighborhood that is entirely contained within the set and that the set is connected in a local sense. The conjecture is crucial because it relates to the connectivity of the Julia sets associated with points in the Mandelbrot set. Specifically, if the Mandelbrot set is locally connected, then the Julia set of a quadratic polynomial is connected if and only if the parameter is in the Mandelbrot set. Despite its fundamental importance, the MLC remains unproven.
related_conjectures: Mandelbrot set is not a filled Julia set

Maass_wave_form.name: Maass wave form
Maass_wave_form.rephrased: Maass forms are smooth, complex-valued functions on the upper half-plane that transform under a discrete subgroup of SL(2,R) and are eigenfunctions of the hyperbolic Laplacian.
Maass_wave_form.implication_form: If a smooth, complex-valued function on the upper half-plane transforms under a discrete subgroup of SL(2,R) and satisfies certain invariance conditions, then it is an eigenfunction of the hyperbolic Laplacian.
Maass_wave_form.explained:
Maass forms (or Maass wave forms) are complex-valued smooth functions defined on the upper half-plane \(\mathbb{H}\), which are eigenfunctions of the hyperbolic Laplacian with eigenvalue \(\lambda 
eq 0\) and transform like automorphic forms under the action of a discrete subgroup \(\Gamma\) of \(\mathrm{SL}(2,\mathbb{R})\). Specifically, a Maass form for \(\Gamma\) is a function \(f: \mathbb{H} 	o \mathbb{C}\) satisfying the following conditions:

1. **Transformation Property:** For all \(\gamma =  egin{pmatrix} a & b \ c & d \end{pmatrix} \in \Gamma\) and \(z \in \mathbb{H}\), \(f\left( rac{az + b}{cz + d}ight) = (cz + d)^0 f(z)\), where the exponent 0 indicates no additional factor (contrasted with non-zero exponents for holomorphic modular forms).

2. **Eigenfunction of the Laplacian:** It satisfies the eigenvalue equation \(\Delta f = \lambda f\), where \(\lambda 
eq 0\) and the hyperbolic Laplacian is given by \(\Delta = -\left( rac{1}{y^2}  rac{\partial^2}{\partial x^2} +  rac{1}{y^2}  rac{\partial^2}{\partial y^2} +  rac{2i}{y}  rac{\partial}{\partial x}ight)\) (often defined with a negative sign, making \(\lambda\) positive).

3. **Smoothness:** \(f\) is smooth (infinitely differentiable) on \(\mathbb{H}\).

4. **Growth Condition (Implicit):** While not always explicitly stated in the minimal definition, functions that are eigenfunctions of the Laplacian and invariant under \(\Gamma\) are necessarily bounded if \(\Gamma\) is non-compact (like \(\mathrm{SL}(2,\mathbb{Z})\)), due to the spectral theorem for the Laplacian on \(\Gamma ackslash\mathbb{H}\). Fourier expansions of Maass forms involve hyperbolic Bessel functions and have a Fourier expansion of the form \(f(z) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty c_n \sqrt{y} K_{2\sqrt{\lambda} i n}(2\pi n z)\), where \(K_
u\) is the modified Bessel function of the second kind.
related_conjectures: Ramanujan-Petersson Conjecture (relates to bounding Fourier coefficients and eigenvalues)
Langlands Program (relates Maass forms to Galois representations and L-functions)
Selberg Eigenvalue Conjecture (predicts that all non-trivial eigenvalues of the Laplacian on \(\Gamma=\mathrm{SL}(2,\mathbb{Z})\backslash\mathbb{H}\) are positive)

Magic_square_of_squares.name: Magic square of squares
Magic_square_of_squares.rephrased: Is there a three-by-three magic square where every number is a perfect square?
Magic_square_of_squares.implication_form: If a three-by-three magic square can be constructed with all square numbers, then it satisfies the magic square conditions.
Magic_square_of_squares.explained: The Magic Square of Squares conjecture asks whether it is possible to construct a 3x3 magic square where all 9 elements are distinct perfect squares. A magic square is an arrangement of distinct numbers in a 3x3 grid such that the sum of the numbers in each row, each column, and both main diagonals is the same, known as the magic constant. The conjecture specifically requires all elements to be perfect squares. Despite numerous attempts, no such magic square has been found, nor has it been proven impossible.
related_conjectures: The existence of a 3x3 magic square with distinct positive integers (standard magic square problem)
Euler's 36 officers problem (related to Latin squares, which are combinatorial analogues)
Sum of three squares (problem of representing numbers as sums of squares, relevant to the magic constant)

Mahler's_3_2_problem.name: Mahler's 3/2 problem
Mahler's_3_2_problem.rephrased: A Z-number is a nonzero real number that remains in the interval [0, 0.5) for all its fractional parts when repeatedly multiplied by (3/2).
Mahler's_3_2_problem.implication_form: If a nonzero real number x satisfies the condition that the fractional part of x * (3/2)^n is less than 0.5 for all positive integers n, then x is a Z-number.
Mahler's_3_2_problem.explained: Mahler's 3/2 problem is a conjecture concerning the existence of 'Z-numbers'. A Z-number is defined as any nonzero real number x such that the fractional part of x multiplied by (3/2)^n is strictly less than 1/2 for every positive integer n. The conjecture, associated with mathematician Kurt Mahler, asks whether any such nonzero real numbers exist.
related_conjectures: Problems involving fractional parts with irrational bases
Questions about the distribution of sequences defined by iterated multiplication

Mandelbrot_set.name: Mandelbrot set
Mandelbrot_set.rephrased: The Mandelbrot set consists of all complex numbers 'c' for which the sequence defined by 'z‚ÇÄ = 0' and 'z_{n+1} = z_n¬≤ + c' does not diverge to infinity.
Mandelbrot_set.implication_form: If the sequence defined by iterating the function f(z) = z¬≤ + c starting from 0 remains bounded, then the complex number c belongs to the Mandelbrot set.
Mandelbrot_set.explained: The Mandelbrot set is a mathematical set of complex numbers c for which the function f_c(z) = z¬≤ + c, when iterated starting from z = 0, does not diverge to infinity. A complex number c is in the Mandelbrot set if the sequence defined by z_0 = 0, z_{n+1} = z_n¬≤ + c remains bounded (does not escape to infinity) for all n. It is defined in the complex plane and is one of the most famous examples of a fractal, characterized by an infinitely repeating, jagged boundary.
related_conjectures: The Mandelbrot-Siegel conjecture (regarding the Hausdorff dimension of the boundary)
The density of the Mandelbrot set in the sense that hyperbolic components are dense in its boundary

Manin_conjecture.name: Manin conjecture
Manin_conjecture.rephrased: The Manin conjecture predicts how many rational points with a certain bounded 'size' (measured by a height function) there are on a given algebraic variety, suggesting that the count grows roughly like the volume of a certain geometric shape.
Manin_conjecture.implication_form: If the height function is appropriately chosen for an algebraic variety, then the number of rational points with bounded height grows asymptotically like the volume of a certain region defined by the variety and the height function.
Manin_conjecture.explained: The Manin conjecture, formulated by Yuri I. Manin and his collaborators in 1989, addresses the asymptotic distribution of rational points on algebraic varieties defined over the field of rational numbers. It posits that for a smooth, projective, geometrically irreducible variety X defined over the rationals, the number of points with Weil height at most H grows asymptotically as c * H^{1/2} * (log H)^k for some constant c and some integer k depending on the variety and the height function. In simpler terms, the density of rational points increases, but not too rapidly, as one considers larger and larger denominators or heights.

Map_folding.name: Map folding
Map_folding.implication_form: Cannot be directly rewritten as 'If P, then Q' as the original statement is more of a definition or counting problem.
Map_folding.explained: Map folding refers to the problem of counting the number of distinct ways a piece of paper can be folded, where the paper is divided by creases and all folds must occur along these creases. There are two main variants: the stamp folding problem, which involves folding a strip of stamps (each a unit square) separated by creases, and the map folding problem, which involves folding a map (typically a rectangular grid of smaller rectangles) along its creases. The folding sequences must result in a compact shape, often a single point or a small area, and different sequences or resulting shapes are considered distinct foldings.

Markov_number.name: Markov number
Markov_number.implication_form: If x, y, and z are integers satisfying the equation x¬≤ + y¬≤ + z¬≤ = 3xyz, then each of x, y, and z is a Markov number.
Markov_number.explained: A Markov number is a positive integer that appears in any solution to the Markov Diophantine equation x¬≤ + y¬≤ + z¬≤ = 3xyz, where x, y, z are positive integers. The solutions to this equation are generated recursively from the seed solution (1,1,1) using a greedy algorithm. The Markov numbers are all the positive integers that appear in any such solution triple.
related_conjectures: Occurrence of prime numbers in Markov numbers

Maulik-Nekrasov-Okounkov-Pandharipande_c.name: Maulik‚ÄìNekrasov‚ÄìOkounkov‚ÄìPandharipande conjecture
Maulik-Nekrasov-Okounkov-Pandharipande_c.rephrased: The Maulik‚ÄìNekrasov‚ÄìOkounkov‚ÄìPandharipande (MNOP) conjecture proposes a deep connection between two types of invariants in algebraic geometry: Donaldson‚ÄìThomas invariants, which count sheaves on Calabi‚ÄìYau threefolds using virtual fundamental classes, and Gromov‚ÄìWitten invariants, which count curves via symplectic geometry. It suggests that DT invariants can be expressed as weighted sums of GW invariants.
Maulik-Nekrasov-Okounkov-Pandharipande_c.implication_form: If certain conditions are met for Calabi‚ÄìYau threefolds, then the Donaldson‚ÄìThomas invariants equal a specific weighted sum related to the Gromov‚ÄìWitten invariants.
Maulik-Nekrasov-Okounkov-Pandharipande_c.explained: The Maulik‚ÄìNekrasov‚ÄìOkounkov‚ÄìPandharipande (MNOP) conjecture, formulated by Maulik, Nekrasov, Okounkov, and Pandharipande, proposes a deep equivalence between two seemingly different approaches to counting curves in Calabi-Yau threefolds. It states that the generating function for Gromov-Witten invariants (counting curves using intersection cohomology theory) with certain insertions (Gopakumar-Vafa invariants) is equal to the generating function for the Euler characteristics (or more precisely, the integral of the class 1) of the moduli spaces of stable coherent sheaves (counted via Donaldson-Thomas invariants) in the Gopakumar-Vafa presentation. In essence, the MNOP conjecture claims that the Donaldson-Thomas invariants, which are defined via the virtual fundamental class of the moduli space of stable sheaves, count the same enumerative information as the Gromov-Witten invariants do, specifically when expressed in terms of the Gopak-umar-Vafa BPS invariants, under certain conditions (typically requiring the moduli space to be proper and the stability condition to be generic).
terms: String Theory (Connects physical concepts of BPS states)
related_conjectures: Gopakumar-Vafa Conjecture (which MNOP builds upon and provides evidence for)
Pandharipande-Thomas Conjecture (which provides an alternative, mathematically rigorous definition of curve counting using stable pairs, and is related via wall-crossing arguments)
Donaldson-Thomas / Pandharipande-Thomas wall-crossing conjecture (relating different stability conditions in sheaf theory)
Mirror Symmetry (provides another framework for counting curves, often used to compute invariants and test conjectures)

Maximal_rank_conjecture.name: Maximal rank conjecture
Maximal_rank_conjecture.rephrased: For a general curve of genus g, the expected dimension of the space of sections of the canonical bundle is achieved, meaning the map from the space of global sections to the space of sections has maximal rank.
Maximal_rank_conjecture.implication_form: If a curve is general of genus g, then the map from H^0(K_C) to H^0(L_C) has maximal rank (i.e., its dimension equals its rank).
Maximal_rank_conjecture.explained: The Maximal Rank Conjecture is a foundational conjecture in algebraic geometry and enumerative geometry. It concerns the dimension of the moduli space of curves (more precisely, stable maps) in a smooth projective variety (like a complex projective variety) that satisfy certain incidence conditions. The conjecture predicts that for a general curve (or a general stable map from a curve) and a general target variety, the expected dimension of the space of such curves (or maps) passing through a given set of points (or more generally, satisfying given conditions) is equal to the maximal possible rank of the relevant cohomology groups (or obstruction theories) involved. In simpler terms, it posits that the enumerative geometry of curves in a variety behaves in its 'largest possible' dimension, without unexpected obstructions reducing the dimension further than anticipated by standard intersection theory calculations.
related_conjectures: Conjectures regarding the Kodaira dimension of moduli spaces

McKay_conjecture.name: McKay conjecture
McKay_conjecture.rephrased: For any finite group and any prime number p, the number of irreducible complex characters of the group that are not divisible by p equals the number of such characters in the normalizer of any Sylow p-subgroup.
McKay_conjecture.explained: The McKay conjecture, formulated by John McKay, asserts that for any finite group G and any prime number p, the number of irreducible complex characters of G whose degrees are not divisible by p is equal to the number of irreducible complex characters of the normalizer N_G(P) of any Sylow p-subgroup P of G whose degrees are not divisible by p. In other words, | Irr(G | p') | = | Irr(N_G(P) | p') |, where p' denotes that the degree is coprime to p.

McMullen_problem.name: McMullen problem
McMullen_problem.rephrased: A conjecture concerning the existence of convex polytopes with specific combinatorial types and symmetry groups.
McMullen_problem.implication_form: If certain combinatorial and symmetry conditions are met, then there exists a convex polytope realizing those conditions.
McMullen_problem.explained: The McMullen problem is an open problem in discrete geometry posed by Peter McMullen. It concerns the characterization of the combinatorial types of convex polytopes. The problem seeks to identify or classify all possible combinatorial structures (types) that can be realized as the face lattices of convex polytopes in a given dimension or with specific properties. While the precise formulation can vary, it typically involves finding necessary and sufficient conditions for a combinatorial object to be the face lattice of a convex polytope, or relating the combinatorial type to its geometric realization, such as through the normal fan or the set of facet-defining inequalities.

Mersenne_number.name: Mersenne number
Mersenne_number.rephrased: A Mersenne prime is a prime number that is one less than a power of two with a prime exponent.
Mersenne_number.implication_form: If 2^n - 1 is prime, then n must be prime.
Mersenne_number.explained: A Mersenne number is defined as a number of the form Mn = 2^n - 1. A Mersenne prime is a Mersenne number that is prime. The key conjecture associated with this form is that the primality of Mn depends solely on the primality of n (i.e., if n is composite, then Mn is composite), which is not entirely proven but strongly supported. The main open question is whether there are infinitely many Mersenne primes.
related_conjectures: Connection between Mersenne primes and other conjectures (e.g., Artin's conjecture on primitive roots, Riemann Hypothesis via Miller's test)

Mersenne_prime.name: Mersenne prime
Mersenne_prime.rephrased: A Mersenne prime is a prime number that can be written as 2 raised to the power of a prime minus one.
Mersenne_prime.implication_form: If n is composite, then 2^n - 1 is composite.
Mersenne_prime.explained: A Mersenne prime is a prime number that can be expressed in the form 2^n - 1, where n is an integer. These primes are named after Marin Mersenne, who studied them. An important property is that if n is a composite number, then 2^n - 1 is also composite. Therefore, known Mersenne primes correspond to prime exponents n (though not all prime exponents yield Mersenne primes).

Minimum_overlap_problem.name: Minimum overlap problem
Minimum_overlap_problem.rephrased: Find a simplified way to describe sets with minimal intersection under certain conditions.
Minimum_overlap_problem.implication_form: Cannot be rephrased as an implication without the original conjecture statement.
Minimum_overlap_problem.explained: The Minimum Overlap Problem, proposed by Paul Erd≈ës in 1955, concerns the minimal possible maximum overlap (i.e., the size of the intersection) between two or more sets when they are used to cover or represent elements from a universe, or more generally, when considering the overlap structure of a family of sets. The precise statement often involves finding a family of sets with specific properties (like fixed size or being subsets of a given universe) that minimizes the maximum pairwise intersection size or the overall overlap structure. While the exact statement can vary depending on the specific formulation being considered, the core idea is to find configurations where overlapping elements are minimized, often relating to extremal set theory or problems in combinatorial number theory.

Minkowski_dimension.name: Minkowski dimension
Minkowski_dimension.rephrased: A method to measure how 'rough' a surface is by counting how many boxes of a given size are needed to cover it, and seeing how that number changes as the box size gets smaller.
Minkowski_dimension.implication_form: If a set S in R^n is covered by a certain number of boxes of side length Œµ, then its Minkowski dimension can be defined as the limit (as Œµ approaches 0) of the logarithm of the number of boxes divided by the logarithm of 1/Œµ.
Minkowski_dimension.solved_by: unsolved (it's a definition, not a conjecture to be solved)
Minkowski_dimension.explained: The Minkowski‚ÄìBouligand dimension, commonly known as the Minkowski dimension or box-counting dimension, is a defined method for quantifying the fractal dimension of a bounded set \(S\) within a Euclidean space \(\mathbb{R}^n\), or more generally within a metric space \((X, d)\). It is calculated by determining how the number of boxes of a given size needed to cover the set \(S\) changes as the box size decreases. Specifically, if \(N(\epsilon)\) denotes the minimum number of \(\epsilon\)-diameter boxes (or cubes in \(\mathbb{R}^n\)) required to cover \(S\), then the Minkowski dimension \(D_M\) is defined as the limit (if it exists) of \(D_M = \lim_{\epsilon \to 0^+} \frac{\log N(\epsilon)}{\log (1/\epsilon)}\). This limit provides a measure of the 'roughness' or 'complexity' of the set \(S\), often coinciding with the Hausdorff dimension but is generally easier to compute.
related_conjectures: Hausdorff Dimension Conjecture (in various contexts, e.g., Julia sets, self-similar sets)

Modularity_theorem.name: Modularity theorem
Modularity_theorem.rephrased: Every elliptic curve defined over the rational numbers is associated with a specific modular form.
Modularity_theorem.implication_form: If an elliptic curve is defined over the field of rational numbers, then it is modular.
Modularity_theorem.posed_by: Jean-Pierre Serre (conjectured the 'BSD conjecture' which includes the modularity conjecture for semistable curves), Yves Hellegouarch, Gerhard Frey, and others.
Modularity_theorem.solved_by: Andrew Wiles (with Richard Taylor) for semistable elliptic curves (enough for FLT), Brian Conrad, Fred Diamond, Christophe Breuil, and Richard Taylor (completed the proof).
Modularity_theorem.explained: The Modularity Theorem (formerly known as the Taniyama‚ÄìShimura‚ÄìWeil conjecture) states that every rational elliptic curve is modular, meaning it can be associated with a modular form (specifically, a weight 2 newform for the principal congruence subgroup). More precisely, it asserts that for any elliptic curve E defined over the field of rational numbers, there exists a modular form f (of weight 2 and level N, the conductor of E) such that the L-function of E matches the L-function of f (up to finitely many factors). This connection links the algebraic properties of elliptic curves to the analytic properties of modular forms.

Monomial_conjecture.name: Monomial conjecture
Monomial_conjecture.rephrased: For a commutative ring with enough structure (being Noetherian and local), if you have a set of parameters that define its dimension, then raising these parameters to high enough powers and considering certain algebraic combinations, you can never get something non-zero.
Monomial_conjecture.implication_form: If A is a Noetherian local ring of dimension d with parameters x1,...,xd, then for all positive integers t, the Tor module Tor_A^d(A/(x1,...,xd), A/(x1,...,xd)) tensored with the ring localized by the product of the xi's, raised to the power t, is zero.
Monomial_conjecture.explained: The Monomial Conjecture, proposed by Melvin L. Hochster, addresses the structure of certain ideals in commutative algebra. It states: Let A be a Noetherian local ring of Krull dimension d, and let x‚ÇÅ, ..., x‚Çñ be a system of parameters for A (meaning (x‚ÇÅ, ..., x‚Çñ) is an ideal defining the ring, and A/(x‚ÇÅ, ..., x‚Çñ) is an Artinian ring). Then, for all positive integers t, the monomial x‚ÇÅ·µó ‚ãØ x‚Çñ·µó is annihilated by the ideal (x‚ÇÅ, ..., x‚Çñ). In other words, x‚ÇÅ·µó ‚ãØ x‚Çñ·µó lies in the annihilator of the ideal (x‚ÇÅ, ..., x‚Çñ) in A. This means that multiplication by x‚ÇÅ·µó ‚ãØ x‚Çñ·µó sends every element of the ideal (x‚ÇÅ, ..., x‚Çñ) to 0 in A.
related_conjectures: New Foundations for Algebraic Geometry (Hochster's Work)
Homological Conjectures (Collection of conjectures by various mathematicians, many related to properties of local rings and their homology)

Montgomery's_pair_correlation_conjecture.name: Montgomery's pair correlation conjecture
Montgomery's_pair_correlation_conjecture.rephrased: The zeros of the Riemann zeta function (when normalized to have a unit average spacing) tend to behave statistically like the eigenvalues of a random Hermitian matrix from the Gaussian Unitary Ensemble (GUE).
Montgomery's_pair_correlation_conjecture.implication_form: If the zeros of the Riemann zeta function are normalized to have unit average spacing, then their two-point correlation function (pair correlation) approaches the sine-squared function correlation function of GUE eigenvalues as the height along the critical line goes to infinity.

Montserrat_Teixidor_i_Bigas.name: Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas
Montserrat_Teixidor_i_Bigas.rephrased: Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas conjectured a specific property or relationship concerning vector bundles on algebraic curves, particularly within the framework of moduli spaces.
Montserrat_Teixidor_i_Bigas.implication_form: If certain conditions on the curve or vector bundles hold, then specific properties related to their moduli space or invariants are satisfied.
Montserrat_Teixidor_i_Bigas.explained: Montserrat Teixidor i Bigas is a prominent mathematician specializing in algebraic geometry, particularly the study of moduli spaces of vector bundles over algebraic curves. While named after her, the query does not specify a formal 'conjecture' statement attributed solely to her work. Her research focuses on deep problems in this area, often involving the existence, properties, and classification of vector bundles, especially in situations involving positive characteristic fields or over finite fields. Her contributions are significant in understanding the geometry of these moduli spaces and the bundles themselves.

Moore_graph.name: Moore graph
Moore_graph.rephrased: A Moore graph is a regular graph where the shortest cycle (girth) is strictly greater than twice the maximum distance (diameter) between any two vertices.
Moore_graph.implication_form: If a graph is regular with degree d and diameter k, then its girth is exactly 2k + 1, and its number of vertices equals 1 + d + d*(d-1) + d*(d-1)^2 + ... + d*(d-1)^(k-1).
Moore_graph.solved_by: Unsolved (except for specific cases like d=2, k=2; d=3, k=2; d=7, k=2; d=57, k=2, etc.)
Moore_graph.explained: A Moore graph is a regular graph with parameters (d,k) where d is the degree (number of edges per vertex) and k is the diameter (the longest shortest path between any two vertices). It is characterized by having a girth (the length of the shortest cycle) of exactly 2k + 1. Moore graphs are maximally connected graphs with a given degree and diameter. The maximum number of vertices a graph with maximum degree d and diameter k can have is given by the Moore bound. A Moore graph achieves this bound. For a Moore graph with degree d and diameter k, the number of vertices n is given by n = 1 + d + d(d-1) + d(d-1)^2 + ... + d(d-1)^k. This geometric series simplifies to n = 1 + d*((d-1)^{k+1} - 1)/(d-1) for d > 1.

Moser's_worm_problem.name: Moser's worm problem
Moser's_worm_problem.explained: Moser's worm problem, also known as the mother worm's blanket problem, is an unsolved problem in geometry. It asks for the shape of smallest area that can accommodate any plane curve of length 1. A curve is said to be accommodated by a region if it can be rotated and translated (moved around) to fit entirely within that region. The challenge is to find the minimal area required to contain any curve of length 1, regardless of its shape.

Nagata's_conjecture.name: Nagata's conjecture
Nagata's_conjecture.rephrased: The automorphism defined by Nagata in the ring of polynomials in three variables is wild.
Nagata's_conjecture.implication_form: It is not possible to rephrase the conjecture in the form 'If P, then Q' meaningfully.
Nagata's_conjecture.solved_by: Ualbai U. Umirbaev and Ivan P. Shestakov
Nagata's_conjecture.explained: Nagata's conjecture (proposed by Masayoshi Nagata in 1972) states that the specific automorphism œï of the polynomial ring k[x,y,z] defined by œï(x) = x ‚àí 2Œîy ‚àí (Œî¬≤/z) * (some expression involving y and z), œï(y) = y, and œï(z) = z is a wild automorphism. This means that it cannot be expressed as a composition of elementary automorphisms. The conjecture was later proved true by Ualbai U. Umirbaev and Ivan P. Shestakov in 2004.

Nagata's_conjecture_on_curves.name: Nagata's conjecture on curves
Nagata's_conjecture_on_curves.rephrased: The minimal degree of a plane algebraic curve needed to pass through a set of very general points, each with a specified multiplicity, is greater than the sum of the square roots of the multiplicities.
Nagata's_conjecture_on_curves.implication_form: It is difficult to express Nagata's conjecture in a simple 'If P, then Q' form due to its existential nature regarding the minimal degree and the generality of points. It essentially states that for a collection of points and multiplicities, the condition of the curve passing through them with those multiplicities forces the degree to satisfy a lower bound.
Nagata's_conjecture_on_curves.explained: Nagata's conjecture on curves addresses the minimal degree required for a plane algebraic curve to satisfy certain conditions. Specifically, it states that for a collection of distinct points in the complex projective plane \(\mathbb{P}^2_\mathbb{C}\), with multiplicities \(m_1, m_2, \dots, m_k\), the minimal degree \(d\) of a curve passing through all these points with at least the specified multiplicities must satisfy \(d^2 > \sum_{i=1}^k m_i^2\). More precisely, the conjecture asserts that the minimal degree \(d\) is given by \(d = \sqrt{\sum m_i^2 + \epsilon}\) for some \(\epsilon > 0\), meaning that \(d^2 = \sum m_i^2 + \epsilon\) for some positive \(\epsilon\). This minimal degree is achieved for a very general choice of points (generic points) with the given multiplicities.
related_conjectures: The conjectured formula for the minimal degree of curves passing through general points with general multiplicities
Other interpolation conjectures in algebraic geometry
Minimal degree problems for curves in higher-dimensional spaces

Nagata-Biran_conjecture.name: Nagata‚ÄìBiran conjecture
Nagata-Biran_conjecture.rephrased: The Nagata‚ÄìBiran conjecture is a generalization of Nagata's work on curves, stating that for any polarised surface (a surface with an ample divisor class), the minimal number needed to resolve singularities via a divisorial contraction (flipping or blowing down curves) is related to the genus of the surface and the polarization.
Nagata-Biran_conjecture.implication_form: If a polarised surface exists, then the minimal number of curves required for a divisorial contraction is determined by a specific formula involving the polarization and the genus.
Nagata-Biran_conjecture.explained: The Nagata‚ÄìBiran conjecture posits a connection between the existence of curves with high multiplicity (or very ample line bundles) on a polarised surface and the surface being of general type. More formally, it states that a polarised surface is not of general type if and only if it contains a curve with a certain numerical condition related to its genus or degree, analogous to the conditions in Nagata's original conjecture but generalized to surfaces. It suggests that surfaces that are not 'too curved' (i.e., not of general type) must contain special curves with specific properties.
subjects: Differential geometry (aspects of minimal surfaces related to Fano varieties)

Nakai_conjecture.name: Nakai conjecture
Nakai_conjecture.rephrased: A complex algebraic variety is smooth if its ring of differential operators is generated by its derivations.
Nakai_conjecture.implication_form: If a complex algebraic variety has its ring of differential operators generated by its derivations, then it is smooth.
Nakai_conjecture.explained: The Nakai conjecture, proposed by Yoshikazu Nakai in 1961, addresses the relationship between the ring of differential operators on an algebraic variety and its smoothness. The core statement of the conjecture is: If V is a complex algebraic variety such that its ring of differential operators is generated by the derivations it contains (i.e., all differential operators are built from derivations), then V is necessarily a smooth variety. Conversely, Alexander Grothendieck proved that for smooth algebraic varieties, the ring of differential operators is indeed generated by its derivations. However, Nakai's specific conjecture pertains only to the first implication: the condition on the ring implying smoothness.
related_conjectures: Grothendieck's Theorem on Differential Operators (the converse statement, now proven)
Fundamental Conjectures in Algebraic Geometry (such as those related to Hodge theory or birational geometry)

Navier-Stokes_existence_and_smoothness.name: Navier‚ÄìStokes existence and smoothness
Navier-Stokes_existence_and_smoothness.rephrased: Smooth, infinite-time solutions exist for all initial conditions in three-dimensional space.
Navier-Stokes_existence_and_smoothness.implication_form: If the initial conditions are smooth, then the solutions remain smooth for all time.
Navier-Stokes_existence_and_smoothness.posed_by: Claire Navier, George Gabriel Stokes, and others (formalized by the Clay Mathematics Institute as a Millennium Prize Problem)
Navier-Stokes_existence_and_smoothness.explained: The Navier‚ÄìStokes existence and smoothness problem is one of the Clay Mathematics Institute's Millennium Prize Problems. It asks for a proof that solutions to the Navier‚ÄìStokes equations, which describe the motion of viscous incompressible fluids, remain smooth (i.e., infinitely differentiable) for all time and for all initial conditions with finite kinetic energy, when the Reynolds number is positive. Equivalently, it requires proof that if a solution becomes singular (develops a singularity), it must occur only at finite time or under conditions where the initial data violates the assumptions (e.g., infinite energy or non-viscosity). The problem is to rigorously establish the global existence and smoothness of solutions to these equations under standard physical assumptions.
related_conjectures: P versus NP problem (related to computational complexity)

Nearby_Lagrangian_conjecture.name: Nearby Lagrangian conjecture
Nearby_Lagrangian_conjecture.rephrased: In the context of symplectic geometry, the Nearby Lagrangian Conjecture suggests that any Lagrangian submanifold (a special type of submanifold) that is 'close' to the zero section (the base space itself) within a cotangent bundle can be smoothly deformed into the zero section using a specific type of path (called a Hamiltonian isotopy).
Nearby_Lagrangian_conjecture.implication_form: If a closed exact Lagrangian submanifold exists within a cotangent bundle, then it is Hamiltonian isotopic to the zero section.

Negami's_conjecture.name: Negami's conjecture
Negami's_conjecture.rephrased: A finite graph has a planar cover (a finite planar graph that maps onto it in a specific way) if and only if it can be embedded into the projective plane.
Negami's_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph can be embedded into the projective plane, then it has a planar cover.
Negami's_conjecture.explained: Negami's conjecture states that a finite graph has a planar cover if and only if it can be embedded into the projective plane. A planar cover is a finite covering graph of the original graph that is itself planar. This conjecture proposes a deep equivalence between the existence of a planar covering and the projective planarity of a graph.

Newman's_conjecture.name: Newman's conjecture
Newman's_conjecture.rephrased: The partition function p(n), which counts the number of ways to write n as a sum of positive integers, is equidistributed modulo any integer m. This means that for any modulus m and any residue r between 0 and m-1, there are infinitely many positive integers n such that p(n) modulo m equals r.
Newman's_conjecture.implication_form: If m is any positive integer, then for any residue r modulo m, there are infinitely many positive integers n such that p(n) ‚â° r (mod m).
Newman's_conjecture.explained: Newman's conjecture, now a theorem, pertains to the partition function p(n), which counts the number of ways to write n as a sum of positive integers. It states that for any positive integer m and any integer r satisfying 0 ‚â§ r ‚â§ m-1, there exist infinitely many positive integers n such that the partition function p(n) is congruent to r modulo m. In other words, the partition function is equidistributed modulo any integer m.
related_conjectures: Riemann Hypothesis (related via the proof's connection to complex analysis and the partition function's asymptotic growth)

Newman-Shanks-Williams_prime.name: Newman‚ÄìShanks‚ÄìWilliams prime
Newman-Shanks-Williams_prime.rephrased: An NSW prime is a prime number that appears as a term in the sequence defined by S_0 = 2, S_1 = 7, and S_n = 2*n*S_{n-1} - S_{n-2} for n ‚â• 2.
Newman-Shanks-Williams_prime.implication_form: If a term in the sequence defined by S_0 = 2, S_1 = 7, and S_n = 2*n*S_{n-1} - S_{n-2} is prime, then it is an NSW prime.
Newman-Shanks-Williams_prime.explained: A Newman‚ÄìShanks‚ÄìWilliams (NSW) prime is a prime number that appears in the sequence defined by the recurrence relation S_n = 6 * S_{n-1} - S_{n-2}, with initial conditions S_0 = 1 and S_1 = 5. The sequence begins: 1, 5, 29, 169, 985, ... The primes in this sequence are called NSW primes. The conjecture aspect relates to the characterization of primes through this specific sequence, particularly concerning the infinitude of NSW primes or their properties beyond the definition.
related_conjectures: Infinitude of primes in specific sequences

Nielsen_transformation.name: Nielsen transformation
Nielsen_transformation.rephrased: Nielsen transformations are specific automorphisms of free groups that allow for the manipulation of group presentations, acting as a non-commutative analogue of row reduction operations on matrices.
Nielsen_transformation.implication_form: If a finite basis is given for a free group, then applying a sequence of Nielsen transformations to that basis results in another basis for the same free group.
Nielsen_transformation.explained: Nielsen transformations are a set of elementary operations that generate the automorphism group of a free group. The conjecture (or statement) regarding Nielsen transformations typically addresses the question of whether these elementary operations indeed generate all automorphisms of a free group of rank n. More precisely, it concerns the structure and generation of Aut(F_n) using Nielsen transformations. While the fact that elementary Nielsen transformations generate Aut(F_n) is a theorem proven by Jakob Nielsen, the exploration of this generation process and its properties remains a central topic in combinatorial group theory.

Nikiel's_conjecture.name: Nikiel's conjecture
Nikiel's_conjecture.rephrased: A compact topological space can be mapped continuously onto a totally ordered set if and only if it is monotonically normal.
Nikiel's_conjecture.implication_form: If a compact topological space is monotonically normal, then it is the continuous image of a total order.
Nikiel's_conjecture.explained: Nikiel's conjecture states that a compact topological space is the continuous image of a compact Hausdorff total order (i.e., a compact linearly ordered topological space) if and only if it is a monotonically normal space. This characterization was formulated by Jacek Nikiel in 1986 and proven by Mary Ellen Rudin in 1999. The conjecture provides a topological characterization (in terms of monotonic normality) of spaces that arise as continuous images of compact linear orders.

Nirenberg-Treves_conjecture.name: Nirenberg‚ÄìTreves conjecture
Nirenberg-Treves_conjecture.rephrased: A pseudo-differential operator with a symbol satisfying specific conditions (related to its oscillatory behavior) is invertible if it is almost periodic.
Nirenberg-Treves_conjecture.implication_form: If a pseudo-differential operator has a symbol in the class considered and is almost periodic, then it is invertible.
Nirenberg-Treves_conjecture.explained: The Nirenberg‚ÄìTreves conjecture, formulated by Serge Nirenberg and Fran√ßois Treves, addresses the relationship between the local solvability of a linear partial differential operator and the geometric properties of its characteristic variety. It proposes that an operator is locally solvable if and only if its characteristic variety is of finite type. The 'characteristic variety' refers to the variety defined by the vanishing of the principal symbol, while 'finite type' means that at each point in the characteristic variety, there exists a finite set of vector fields generating its tangent space. 'Locally solvable' means that the operator can be inverted modulo compact operators locally. This conjecture was specifically investigated for the Cauchy-Riemann operator in several complex variables, which is a fundamental object in several complex variables and CR geometry. However, the conjecture was ultimately disproven by a counterexample constructed by J.J. Kohn and Andrew G. Tartakoff in dimensions greater than two.

No-three-in-line_problem.name: No-three-in-line problem
No-three-in-line_problem.explained: The no-three-in-line problem is a classic question in discrete geometry. It asks for the maximum number of points that can be placed on an n √ó n grid such that no three of these points lie on the same straight line. The problem considers all possible lines, including those with any slope (positive, negative, zero, infinite), not just the grid-aligned lines. Henry Dudeney introduced it in 1900. It explores the limits of arranging points on a lattice without creating certain linear dependencies, specifically forbidding any three points from being collinear.
related_conjectures: No Four In A Row problem

Noetherian_ring.name: Noetherian ring
Noetherian_ring.rephrased: A Noetherian ring is one where any collection of ideals can be built from a finite number by taking intersections and summing up, or equivalently, where any ascending sequence of ideals eventually stabilizes.
Noetherian_ring.implication_form: If a ring satisfies the ascending chain condition on its ideals (or left/right ideals), then it is a Noetherian ring.
Noetherian_ring.solved_by: The concept is foundational in ring theory and is considered solved; it's a cornerstone definition.

Normal_scalar_curvature_conjecture.name: Normal scalar curvature conjecture
Normal_scalar_curvature_conjecture.rephrased: If a surface in a Riemannian manifold has constant mean curvature, then its scalar curvature is bounded above by the scalar curvature of the ambient manifold.
Normal_scalar_curvature_conjecture.implication_form: If a surface in a Riemannian manifold has constant mean curvature, then its scalar curvature is bounded above by the scalar curvature of the ambient manifold.
Normal_scalar_curvature_conjecture.explained: The Normal Scalar Curvature Conjecture is a significant hypothesis in differential geometry, primarily concerning the topology of Riemannian manifolds with positive scalar curvature. It proposes a relationship between the existence of such a metric on a closed manifold and certain obstruction invariants derived from the manifold's topology. While the exact statement can vary depending on the formulation, the core idea is that a closed manifold admits a Riemannian metric of positive scalar curvature if and only if certain topological invariants (like the Rosenberg invariant or index invariants) vanish. The conjecture essentially states that the vanishing of these invariants is equivalent to the existence of a positive scalar curvature metric.
related_conjectures: Kreck-Leichtnam-Trace-Nistor Conjecture (about positive curvature on spin manifolds)

Novikov_conjecture.name: Novikov conjecture
Novikov_conjecture.rephrased: Higher signatures, numerical invariants derived from the Pontryagin classes, are homotopy invariants of smooth manifolds.
Novikov_conjecture.implication_form: If a smooth manifold has a certain higher signature, then that signature remains the same whenever the manifold is continuously deformed.
Novikov_conjecture.explained: The Novikov conjecture states that the higher signatures (or higher signatures associated with a cycle) of a closed oriented manifold, defined using a representation œÅ of its fundamental group into a unitary group, are homotopy invariants. More precisely, if two closed oriented manifolds M and N are homotopy equivalent, and there exist real analytic structures on them and a homotopy equivalence f: M ‚Üí N that preserves the fundamental classes and lifts to an isometry between the respective Dirac operators (or equivalently, the L-genus evaluated on the fundamental class), then the higher signatures agree. In simpler terms, certain numerical invariants derived from the Pontryagin classes and the fundamental group are invariant under homotopy equivalence.

Oberwolfach_problem.name: Oberwolfach problem
Oberwolfach_problem.rephrased: The Oberwolfach problem asks whether it is possible to schedule a dinner party where a set of people (represented as vertices) are seated around tables (cycles) such that everyone sits with everyone else exactly once, or equivalently, whether a complete graph with an even number of vertices can be decomposed into edge-disjoint cycles each covering all vertices.
Oberwolfach_problem.implication_form: If a complete graph K_{2n} (with an even number of vertices) exists, then it can be decomposed into edge-disjoint Hamiltonian cycles.
Oberwolfach_problem.explained: The Oberwolfach problem is an open question in graph theory concerning the existence of certain cycle covers in complete graphs. Abstractly, it asks: for given integers n (number of vertices) and k (cycle length), and a collection of cycle lengths {l1, l2, ..., lm} such that their sum is n, does the complete graph Kn always admit a decomposition of its edges into cycles of lengths l1, l2, ..., lm? In the scheduling interpretation, it involves arranging n people for n-1 meals (or sometimes n meals) such that at each meal, the diners are seated at a round table (cycle) of a specified length, and over the meals, every pair of diners sits together exactly once (or under other constraints depending on the specific variant). The problem is named after the Oberwolfach Research Institute for Mathematics where it was formulated in 1967 by Gerhard Ringel. It is known that the conjecture holds for sufficiently large complete graphs Kn.
related_conjectures: Eulerian path conjecture (related to decomposing into cycles/euler tours)
subjects: Theoretical computer science (in relation to complexity of finding decompositions)

Opaque_forest_problem.name: Opaque forest problem
Opaque_forest_problem.rephrased: Find the minimal total length of a set of curves that block all lines of sight between points inside a given polygon.
Opaque_forest_problem.implication_form: If a polygon requires an opaque set to block all lines of sight, then the minimal total length of such a set is the objective.
Opaque_forest_problem.explained: The Opaque Forest Conjecture, also known as the Barany-Katchalski conjecture, states that for any convex body K in d-dimensional space, there exists a set of line segments (an opaque forest) contained within K that intersects every ray that starts from a point outside K and passes through K. Furthermore, it conjectures that the minimum total length of such an opaque forest is proportional to the surface area of K. In two dimensions, this means that for any convex polygon, there is a finite set of line segments lying inside it that block the view from any point outside the polygon to any other point inside the polygon, and the minimal total length of these segments is bounded by a constant times the perimeter of the polygon.

Orchard-planting_problem.name: Orchard-planting problem
Orchard-planting_problem.rephrased: What is the maximum number of lines containing exactly three points that can be achieved by arranging n points in the plane?
Orchard-planting_problem.implication_form: If a configuration of n points in the plane is given, then the maximum number of lines containing exactly three points is less than some asymptotic bound involving n.
Orchard-planting_problem.posed_by: Hallard T. Croft and Paul Erd≈ës
Orchard-planting_problem.explained: The original orchard-planting problem (or tree-planting problem) is a question in combinatorial geometry. It asks for the maximum number of lines (termed 'k-point lines' or simply 'lines' when k=3) that can be formed by connecting at least k points in a set of n points in the plane, with the condition that no three collinear points are left out (i.e., every line with at least two points is counted if it has at least k points). Hallard T. Croft and Paul Erd≈ës proved that for any fixed k, there exists a constant c_k > 0 such that the maximum number t_k(n) of k-point lines satisfies t_k(n) > c_k * n for sufficiently large n.

Osserman_conjecture.name: Osserman conjecture
Osserman_conjecture.rephrased: A Riemannian manifold is an Osserman manifold if the characteristic polynomial of its Jacobi operator, evaluated on unit tangent vectors, is constant across the entire unit tangent bundle.
Osserman_conjecture.implication_form: If a Riemannian manifold has a constant characteristic polynomial for its Jacobi operator on the unit tangent bundle, then it is an Osserman manifold.
Osserman_conjecture.explained: The Osserman conjecture, formulated by mathematician Robert Osserman, addresses Riemannian manifolds known as Osserman manifolds. An Osserman manifold is defined by the condition that the characteristic polynomial of the Jacobi operator, evaluated on unit tangent vectors, is constant across the entire unit tangent bundle. The conjecture itself posits that any Riemannian manifold satisfying this Osserman condition (i.e., being an Osserman manifold) must be conformally flat. In other words, the underlying metric can be transformed by a conformal change to a flat metric. This conjecture connects the algebraic properties related to curvature (encoded in the Jacobi operator) to the global geometric property of conformal flatness.
related_conjectures: Hitchin‚ÄìThorpe conjecture (relates to the existence of Einstein metrics on 4-manifolds, which often relate to special curvature conditions like those in Osserman manifolds)

Differentiable Sphere theorem (addresses conditions under which a manifold with positive curvature is homeomorphic to a sphere, contrasting with the conformal flatness conclusion of the Osserman conjecture)
Conformal geometry conjectures (e.g., conjectures regarding conformal invariants or metrics with constant curvature)
subjects: Partial Differential Equations (in the context of curvature conditions)

Osserman_manifold.name: Osserman manifold
Osserman_manifold.rephrased: A Riemannian manifold is called an Osserman manifold if the characteristic polynomial of its Jacobi operator is constant across all unit tangent vectors.
Osserman_manifold.implication_form: If a Riemannian manifold has a constant characteristic polynomial for its Jacobi operator on the unit tangent bundle, then it is an Osserman manifold.
Osserman_manifold.explained: An Osserman manifold is a Riemannian manifold (M, g) defined by the property that the characteristic polynomial of the Jacobi operator acting on the tangent space at each point is constant across all unit tangent vectors at that point. Formally, for each point p ‚àà M, the Jacobi operator J: T_pM ‚Üí End(T_pM) defined by J(v) = ‚àá_v ‚àá_v R(v, ‚ãÖ)‚ãÖ‚ãÖ‚ãÖ (where ‚àá is the Levi-Civita connection and R is the curvature tensor) has a characteristic polynomial det(ŒªI - J(v)) that is independent of the unit vector v ‚àà S(T_pM).
related_conjectures: Conformal geometry conjectures (e.g., conjectures related to the conformal Laplacian)
subjects: Algebraic topology (via characteristic classes or characteristic polynomials)

PCF_theory.name: PCF theory
PCF_theory.rephrased: PCF theory, developed by Saharon Shelah, is a framework that provides upper bounds on the sizes of power sets of certain infinite sets (singular cardinals) by analyzing the possible ways sequences can be cofinally extended in their order.
PCF_theory.implication_form: If the cofinality structure of an ultrafilter or a set of ordered structures satisfies certain properties, then the cardinality of the power set of a singular cardinal is bounded above by a specific value derived from that structure.
PCF_theory.explained: PCF theory, introduced by Saharon Shelah in 1978, is a foundational theory in set theory that analyzes the structure of the set of possible cofinalities of ultraproducts (or more generally, reduced products) of chains of ordered sets. Its central aim is to provide a structure theorem for the set `pcf(S)` for any set `S` of regular cardinals. The theory culminates in the 'pcf theorem,' which guarantees the existence of a 'supporting' set of functions and an associated 'good' ultrapower embedding that captures the structure of `pcf(S)`. A key consequence is the 'theorem on the size of the continuum' (or more generally, bounding the power set of singular cardinals). Specifically, for any singular cardinal `Œª`, the size of its power set `2^Œª` is bounded by the maximum of `Œª^cf(Œª)` and the `pcf(S)` structure for `S` being the set of cofinality of all singular cardinals below `Œª` or related sets. This theory provides deep upper bounds on the continuum function at singular cardinals, significantly advancing our understanding beyond results like Easton's theorem for regular cardinals.

Painlev√©_conjecture.name: Painlev√© conjecture
Painlev√©_conjecture.rephrased: In the n-body problem of celestial mechanics, there exist solutions where all bodies collapse to a single point (singularity) without any two bodies colliding, for systems with four or more bodies.
Painlev√©_conjecture.implication_form: If the system involves four or more bodies, then there exist solutions where all bodies collapse to a single point without any collision occurring.
Painlev√©_conjecture.posed_by: Painlev√© (likely referring to the French mathematician Paul Painlev√©)
Painlev√©_conjecture.solved_by: The conjecture was proven for n ‚â• 5 by Jeff Xia in 1988 and for n = 4 by Jinxin Xue in 2014.
Painlev√©_conjecture.explained: The Painlev√© conjecture, initially proposed concerning the n-body problem in celestial mechanics, stated that there exist noncollision singularities (solutions where bodies reach infinite velocities or collide in finite time without prior collisions) for the gravitational n-body problem with n ‚â• 4 bodies. This conjecture suggested that the system could reach a 'singularity' where the motion becomes infinite without all bodies necessarily colliding directly. However, it is crucial to note that this specific *statement regarding the existence of such singularities for all configurations* was later proven to be false in a general sense, as shown by Xia (n‚â•5) and Xue (n=4). Their work demonstrated specific configurations leading to singularities, but the original conjecture's broad claim was disproven. The term 'Painlev√© conjecture' specifically refers to this initial hypothesis about the existence of noncollision singularities.
related_conjectures: The nature and classification of singularities in the n-body problem
The stability of the solar system (related to long-term predictability)
The existence of periodic orbits in the n-body problem
Conjectures related to the BBV conjecture (Birkhoff conjecture, Butcher-Vance conjecture) regarding singularities

Parshin's_conjecture.name: Parshin's conjecture
Parshin's_conjecture.explained: Parshin's conjecture (also referred to as the Beilinson‚ÄìParshin conjecture) is a statement in algebraic geometry concerning the vanishing of certain higher algebraic K-groups for smooth projective varieties defined over finite fields. The conjecture asserts that for any such variety X and for all integers i > 0, the tensor product of the i-th algebraic K-group of X with the rational numbers Q is trivial, i.e., K·µ¢(X) ‚äó ‚Ñö = 0.

Pascal's_triangle.name: Pascal's triangle
Pascal's_triangle.rephrased: Pascal's triangle is an infinite triangular array where each number is the sum of the two numbers directly above it, with the top row being 1, and it represents the binomial coefficients.
Pascal's_triangle.implication_form: If a row in Pascal's triangle is known, then the next row can be constructed by adding adjacent elements from the previous row.
Pascal's_triangle.posed_by: Blaise Pascal (though studied earlier by others)
Pascal's_triangle.explained: Pascal's triangle is an infinite, triangular array of numbers used to represent binomial coefficients. It is constructed by starting with a single 1 at the top (row 0). Each subsequent row begins and ends with 1, and any other number in the triangle is the sum of the two numbers directly above it in the previous row. The entry in row n and column k (both starting from 0) is the binomial coefficient C(n, k), which equals n! / (k! * (n-k)!) and represents the coefficient of the x^k term in the binomial expansion of (x + y)^n.
related_conjectures: Singmaster's conjecture (concerning the maximum frequency of a number appearing in Pascal's triangle)
Conjecture regarding the infinitude of primes in Pascal's triangle positions
Patterns and symmetries observed in Pascal's triangle

Pentagonal_tiling.name: Pentagonal tiling
Pentagonal_tiling.rephrased: It is impossible to tile the Euclidean plane using regular pentagons.
Pentagonal_tiling.implication_form: If one attempts to tile the Euclidean plane with regular pentagons, then it is impossible.
Pentagonal_tiling.posed_by: No specific person, it is a known impossibility
Pentagonal_tiling.explained: The conjecture states that a regular pentagonal tiling of the Euclidean plane is impossible. This impossibility arises because the internal angle of a regular pentagon (108¬∞) does not divide 360¬∞ evenly, preventing the regular pentagons from fitting together without gaps or overlaps to cover the entire plane. While regular pentagons cannot tile the Euclidean plane, they can tile the hyperbolic plane (with four pentagons meeting at each vertex) and the sphere (with three pentagons meeting at each vertex).

Petersen_graph.name: Petersen graph
Petersen_graph.rephrased: The Petersen graph is a 3-regular, non-planar graph with 10 vertices and 15 edges, serving as a fundamental counterexample in graph theory.
