Petersen_graph.explained: The Petersen graph is a specific, well-defined undirected graph with 10 vertices and 15 edges, not a conjecture itself. It is characterized as a cubic graph (each vertex has degree 3), bridgeless (no edges whose removal disconnects the graph), and non-3-edge-colorable (it cannot be properly edge-colored with three colors). It is named after Julius Petersen, who described it in 1898.

Picard_group.name: Picard group
Picard_group.rephrased: The Picard group classifies all the 'twisted sheaves' (invertible sheaves) on a ringed space, combining them into a group structure using tensor products.
Picard_group.implication_form: Not applicable (This is a definition, not a conjecture to be proved or disproved).
Picard_group.solved_by: It is a defined object, not a conjecture.
Picard_group.explained: The Picard group is not a conjecture but a fundamental construction in mathematics, specifically in algebraic geometry and the theory of complex manifolds. It is defined for a ringed space X (such as a scheme or complex manifold) as follows: The Picard group, denoted Pic(X), is the group of isomorphism classes of invertible sheaves (also known as line bundles) on X. The group operation is given by the tensor product of sheaves. This construction generalizes the concept of the ideal class group from ring theory and provides crucial information about the geometry of the space X. Alternatively, for certain types of spaces (like schemes), the Picard group can also be defined as the sheaf cohomology group H¬π(X, Pic‚ÇÄ(X)), although the isomorphism classes with tensor product is the more standard and intuitive definition.
related_conjectures: Mordell‚ÄìWeil theorem (classifies rational points on abelian varieties, whose Picard group plays a role)
Brauer‚ÄìSiegel theorem (relates to the Picard group of moduli spaces)
Tate conjecture (involves the Picard group of algebraic varieties over number fields)

Pierce-Birkhoff_conjecture.name: Pierce‚ÄìBirkhoff conjecture
Pierce-Birkhoff_conjecture.rephrased: Any function that is piecewise defined by polynomials can be expressed as the maximum over a finite set of minima, where each minimum is taken over a finite set of polynomials.
Pierce-Birkhoff_conjecture.implication_form: If a function is piecewise-polynomial, then it can be expressed as the maximum of finite minima of finite collections of polynomials.
Pierce-Birkhoff_conjecture.posed_by: Garrett Birkhoff and Richard S. Pierce (initially stated informally), Melvin Henriksen and John R. Isbell (formalized the rigorous statement)
Pierce-Birkhoff_conjecture.explained: The Pierce-Birkhoff conjecture, formulated in the context of lattice-ordered rings (l-rings) or f-rings, states that any piecewise-polynomial function defined on a compact interval (typically [0,1]) can be expressed as the supremum (maximum) of a finite collection of infima (minima) of finite collections of polynomials.
related_conjectures: Skolem Problem (Note: While both are conjectures in mathematics, the Skolem Problem is unrelated to the Pierce-Birkhoff conjecture and pertains to linear recurrence sequences.)

Pierpont_prime.name: Pierpont prime
Pierpont_prime.rephrased: Pierpont primes are prime numbers that can be written as 2 raised to some nonnegative integer power u, multiplied by 3 raised to some nonnegative integer power v, and then adding one.
Pierpont_prime.implication_form: There is no 'If P, then Q' form because the definition itself states the condition for a number to be a Pierpont prime.
Pierpont_prime.explained: In number theory, a Pierpont prime is a prime number of the form 2·µò * 3·µõ + 1 for some nonnegative integers u and v. That is, they are the prime numbers p for which p ‚àí 1 is a 3-smooth number (i.e., its prime factors are only 2 and 3). They are named after the mathematician James Pierpont, who used them to characterize polygons that can be constructed with compass, straightedge, and a marked ruler (also known as a straightedge and compass with a fixed angle).
related_conjectures: Infinitude of primes of the form 2·µò * 3·µõ + 1

Pillai's_conjecture.name: Pillai's conjecture
Pillai's_conjecture.rephrased: The only consecutive integers that are both perfect powers (powers of exponent greater than one) are 8 and 9.
Pillai's_conjecture.implication_form: If two distinct perfect powers are consecutive integers, then they must be 8 and 9.
Pillai's_conjecture.explained: Pillai's conjecture, also known as the Catalan‚ÄìPillai conjecture, is a conjecture in number theory. It states that for the equation |x^a - y^b| = 1 (where a, b > 1 and x, y are positive integers), the only solutions occur when one of the exponents is 1 or when the equation is a trivial case involving consecutive integers (like 3^2 = 9 and 2^3 = 8, which differ by 1, or 1^n and 0^m). In other words, the only time a perfect power differs from another perfect power by 1 is when one of the exponents is 1 (making it a prime power or higher power) or in the trivial cases.

Poincar√©_conjecture.name: Poincar√© conjecture
Poincar√©_conjecture.rephrased: A finite, simply connected 3D shape with no holes is like a sphere.
Poincar√©_conjecture.implication_form: If a finite, simply connected 3D shape has all loops contractible, then it is a 3-sphere.
Poincar√©_conjecture.explained: The Poincar√© conjecture, now proven as a theorem, states that any three-dimensional manifold that is compact, simply connected (meaning every loop can be continuously contracted to a point), and has no holes (i.e., its fundamental group is trivial) is topologically equivalent to the three-dimensional sphere (3-sphere). In simpler terms, it suggests that the only 'bounded' three-dimensional space that is 'sphere-like' (without any handles or holes) is actually a sphere itself.

Polignac's_conjecture.name: Polignac's conjecture
Polignac's_conjecture.rephrased: For any even positive number n, there are infinitely many pairs of consecutive prime numbers that differ by n.
Polignac's_conjecture.implication_form: If Polignac's conjecture is true, then for any even positive integer n, there are infinitely many pairs of consecutive primes differing by n.
Polignac's_conjecture.explained: Polignac's conjecture, proposed by Alphonse de Polignac in 1849, addresses the occurrence of prime gaps. It states that for any positive even number `n`, there exist infinitely many prime gaps of size `n`. This means that there are infinitely many pairs of consecutive prime numbers whose difference is exactly `n`. In formal terms, for any even `k`, the limit inferior of the `k`-th prime gap as the primes grow larger is `k`. Formally, for any even `k`, \(\lim_{n \to \infty} \inf g_n = k\), where \(g_n\) is the gap between the \(n\)-th and \((n+1)\)-th prime.
related_conjectures: Twin Prime Conjecture (a special case for n=2)
Goldbach Conjecture (related to even numbers and primes)
Polignac's Conjecture (also related to even numbers and primes)

Pollock's_conjectures.name: Pollock's conjectures
Pollock's_conjectures.rephrased: Every positive integer can be expressed as the sum of at most three three-dimensional figurate numbers (such as tetrahedral numbers or octahedral numbers).
Pollock's_conjectures.implication_form: If a positive integer can be expressed as the sum of three three-dimensional figurate numbers, then every positive integer can be expressed as the sum of at most three three-dimensional figurate numbers (though this is circular and not a standard implication form for the conjecture).
Pollock's_conjectures.explained:
Pollock's conjectures are two related statements in additive number theory regarding the representation of integers using three-dimensional figurate numbers.

Conjecture 1: Every positive integer greater than 946 can be expressed as the sum of at most three three-dimensional figurate numbers (more specifically, triangular pyramidal numbers or tetrahedral numbers).

Conjecture 2: Every positive integer greater than 21 is a sum of at most three three-dimensional square pyramidal numbers.
related_conjectures: Euler's conjectures (particularly concerning sums of powers)

Pompeiu_problem.name: Pompeiu problem
Pompeiu_problem.rephrased: If a continuous function's integral over every rotated and translated copy of a simply connected Lipschitz domain K is zero, then K must be a ball.
Pompeiu_problem.implication_form: If the integral of a nonzero continuous function vanishes on every congruent copy of a simply connected Lipschitz domain K, then K is a ball.
Pompeiu_problem.explained: The Pompeiu problem is a conjecture in integral geometry. It states that if a nonzero continuous function f defined on a Euclidean space has the property that its integral vanishes (i.e., is zero) over every congruent copy (i.e., every translation, rotation, and scaling) of a given simply connected Lipschitz domain K, then the domain K itself must be a ball (in the Euclidean space).

Pontryagin_class.name: Pontryagin class
Pontryagin_class.rephrased: The Pontryagin classes are characteristic classes associated with real vector bundles, taking values in cohomology groups where the degree is a multiple of four.
Pontryagin_class.explained: The Pontryagin classes are defined as characteristic classes for real vector bundles. Given a real vector bundle E over a base space X, the Pontryagin classes are defined via the classifying map f: X ‚Üí BO, where BO is the classifying space for real vector bundles. Specifically, they are obtained by pulling back the universal Pontryagin classes defined on BO. These classes, denoted p_k(E) for k = 1, 2, ..., and lying in the real cohomology groups H^{4k}(X; ‚Ñ§) or more precisely the image of H^{4k}(BO; ‚Ñ§) in the cohomology with real coefficients (or often considered modulo torsion), provide topological invariants of the bundle. They are defined using the curvature form of a connection on the bundle, similar to how Chern classes are defined for complex bundles. For the tangent bundle of a smooth manifold, the Pontryagin classes are used to define the Pontryagin characteristic classes of the manifold, playing a crucial role in areas like the Hirzebruch Signature Theorem.

Preda_MihƒÉilescu.name: Preda MihƒÉilescu
Preda_MihƒÉilescu.rephrased: Catalan's conjecture states that the only consecutive perfect powers in the natural numbers are 8 and 9.
Preda_MihƒÉilescu.implication_form: If two perfect powers are consecutive, then they must be 8 and 9.
Preda_MihƒÉilescu.explained: Catalan's conjecture, proposed by Eug√®ne Charles Catalan in 1848 and proven by Preda MihƒÉilescu in 2002, states that the only solution in the natural numbers for the equation x^a - y^b = 1, where a and b are exponents greater than 1, is the trivial solution x=3, a=2, y=2, b=3 (i.e., 3^2 - 2^3 = 1).
related_conjectures: Ribet's Theorem (connecting Fermat-Last Theorem to the modularity theorem)

Problems_in_Latin_squares.name: Problems in Latin squares
Problems_in_Latin_squares.rephrased: The theory of Latin squares continues to present numerous unsolved problems, despite being an active area of mathematical research.
Problems_in_Latin_squares.implication_form: null (No specific implication form derivable from the summary)
Problems_in_Latin_squares.posed_by: Researchers in the theory of Latin squares (collectively)
Problems_in_Latin_squares.explained: The theory of Latin squares is a vibrant area of combinatorial mathematics with numerous unresolved questions. A Latin square of order n is an n √ó n array filled with n different symbols, each occurring exactly once in each row and exactly once in each column. The active research area stems from the abundance of fundamental, yet challenging, open problems in this domain. These problems arise from attempts to construct specific types of Latin squares (e.g., with certain transversal properties), characterize their existence, or understand their structure and relationships (e.g., orthogonal Latin squares). Many of these open problems have been presented at specialized conferences like the Loops conferences (Prague) and the Milehigh conferences (Denver), indicating their significance to researchers. The lack of a single, overarching conjecture belies the complexity of the field, where multiple distinct, challenging questions drive the research.
related_conjectures: Existence of Latin squares of certain types (e.g., with high transversal count)
Problem of mutually orthogonal Latin squares (MOLS) of maximum order
Conjectures related to Latin squares and finite geometries

Problems_in_loop_theory_and_quasigroup_t.name: Problems in loop theory and quasigroup theory
Problems_in_loop_theory_and_quasigroup_t.rephrased: Loop theory and quasigroup theory are active research areas with many open problems, which are often presented at professional conferences.
Problems_in_loop_theory_and_quasigroup_t.implication_form: If one is studying loop theory or quasigroup theory, then one may encounter many open problems.
Problems_in_loop_theory_and_quasigroup_t.posed_by: Loop theorists and quasigroup theorists (collective effort, not attributed to a single person)
Problems_in_loop_theory_and_quasigroup_t.explained: This entry describes a category of open mathematical problems within the fields of loop theory and quasigroup theory. These are active research areas in abstract algebra, characterized by many unresolved questions. The specific problems mentioned often stem from prominent conferences like the Loops (Prague) and Mile High (Denver) gatherings, though no single, unified conjecture statement is provided here. The focus is on the collection of challenging questions driving current research in these structures.

P√≥lya_conjecture.name: P√≥lya conjecture
P√≥lya_conjecture.rephrased: P√≥lya conjectured that more than half of the natural numbers less than any given number have an odd number of prime factors.
P√≥lya_conjecture.implication_form: If n is sufficiently large, then the number of integers less than n with an odd number of prime factors is greater than the number with an even number.
P√≥lya_conjecture.explained: The P√≥lya conjecture, proposed by George P√≥lya in 1.919, concerns the natural numbers. It states that for sufficiently large N, a majority (more than 50%) of the natural numbers less than N have an odd number of prime factors (counting multiplicity). Equivalently, it posits that the Liouville function, which is +1 if a number has an even number of prime factors and -1 if odd, takes values that sum to a negative number for large N. The conjecture was proven false in 1958 by C. Brian Haselgrove, who demonstrated that the sum of the Liouville function does eventually become positive for sufficiently large N, meaning that there are more numbers with an even number of prime factors than with an odd number for sufficiently large thresholds.

Quadrisecant.name: Quadrisecant
Quadrisecant.rephrased: For generic space curves, any straight line intersects the curve at most four points, and a quadrisecant is a line that intersects exactly four points.
Quadrisecant.implication_form: If a curve is generic, then it has quadrisecants (lines intersecting it at four points).

Quillen-Lichtenbaum_conjecture.name: Quillen‚ÄìLichtenbaum conjecture
Quillen-Lichtenbaum_conjecture.rephrased: The conjecture connects √©tale cohomology to algebraic K-theory, specifically asserting that their ranks and orders at prime numbers match for certain algebraic structures.
Quillen-Lichtenbaum_conjecture.implication_form: If the algebraic K-theory groups are isomorphic to √©tale cohomology groups, then their ranks and orders at prime numbers are equal.
Quillen-Lichtenbaum_conjecture.explained: The Quillen‚ÄìLichtenbaum conjecture proposes a deep connection between √©tale cohomology and algebraic K-theory for schemes, particularly regular schemes over Dedekind domains. It predicts that the algebraic K-theory of a regular scheme X, localized at a prime p, is related to its √©tale cohomology via an isomorphism involving inverse limits. Specifically, for a regular scheme X proper over a strictly Henselian discrete valuation ring or a field, the Quillen‚ÄìLichtenbaum conjecture states that the pro-group completion of the algebraic K-theory of X is isomorphic to the √©tale cohomology of X, shifted appropriately. In simpler terms, it suggests that the higher regulators from algebraic K-theory can be understood via √©tale cohomology, providing a bridge between number-theoretic and topological invariants.
related_conjectures: Milnor conjecture (now proven part of Bloch-Kato)
Lichtenbaum conjecture (often considered a special case or related formulation)

Ramanujan-Petersson_conjecture.name: Ramanujan‚ÄìPetersson conjecture
Ramanujan-Petersson_conjecture.rephrased: A conjecture about how quickly the numbers appearing in certain mathematical objects called modular forms can grow. It states that the coefficients of these forms don't grow faster than a specific power of the number of terms.
Ramanujan-Petersson_conjecture.implication_form: If a modular form has coefficients that grow too rapidly, then it might not be a typical example of a cusp form, but the conjecture says they shouldn't grow faster than n^{k/2-1} for large n.
Ramanujan-Petersson_conjecture.solved_by: Luo, Rudnick, Sarnak, Ng√¥ B·∫£o Ch√¢u, and Kenichi Takemura
Ramanujan-Petersson_conjecture.explained: The Ramanujan-Petersson conjecture addresses the growth rate of the Fourier coefficients of certain types of mathematical objects called modular forms and more generally, automorphic forms. In its simplest form for modular forms, it states that for a non-zero holomorphic cusp form of weight k on the full modular group, the Fourier coefficients Œª(n) satisfy |Œª(n)| ‚â§ d(n) * n^{(k-1)/2 + Œµ} for all Œµ > 0, where d(n) is the number of divisors of n. This bound essentially says the coefficients cannot grow too rapidly. More generally, for an automorphic form on a reductive group, the conjecture bounds the supremum of |Œª(œÄ)(n)| / n^{(k- (d-r)/2) + Œµ} over all n, where Œª(œÄ)(n) are the Fourier coefficients, k is the weight (or analogous parameter for higher rank), d is the dimension of the ambient space, and r is the rank of the group. The conjecture was first formulated by Srinivasa Ramanujan for the specific case of the Ramanujan tau function (associated with the discriminant modular form) and later generalized by Hans Petersson to all modular forms. It essentially asserts that the L-functions associated with these automorphic forms satisfy a weak form of the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis or are 'as orthogonal as possible'.

Ramsey_numbers.name: Ramsey numbers
Ramsey_numbers.rephrased: For any two colors and any two positive integers r and s, there exists a minimum number R(r, s) such that any complete graph with R(r, s) vertices, whose edges are colored with the two colors, must contain a monochromatic clique of size r or s.
Ramsey_numbers.implication_form: If a complete graph with at least R(r, s) vertices is edge-colored with two colors, then it contains a monochromatic clique of size r or s.
Ramsey_numbers.explained: Ramsey's theorem, in its basic graph-theoretic form, asserts that for any two positive integers r and s, there exists a minimal integer R(r, s) such that any complete graph with at least R(r, s) vertices, whose edges are colored with two colors (e.g., blue and red), must contain either a blue complete subgraph (clique) on r vertices or a red complete subgraph on s vertices. This R(r, s) is known as the Ramsey number for r and s.

Ravenel's_conjectures.name: Ravenel's conjectures
Ravenel's_conjectures.rephrased: A set of conjectures concerning the structure of the stable homotopy category, particularly regarding the behavior of certain spectra and their relationship to formal groups, which were foundational in developing chromatic homotopy theory.
Ravenel's_conjectures.solved_by: Various mathematicians solved most conjectures; the 'telescope conjecture' remains unresolved.
Ravenel's_conjectures.explained: Douglas Ravenel's 1984 paper proposed seven conjectures related to the structure of the stable homotopy groups of spheres and the behavior of certain spectral sequences in chromatic homotopy theory. These conjectures aimed to refine and extend the insights provided by chromatic homotopy theory, particularly concerning the existence and properties of 'chromatic redshift' phenomena and the resolution of the telescope conjecture. Each conjecture addressed specific aspects of the relationship between formal groups, complex-oriented cohomology theories, and the structure of the stable homotopy category. The conjectures were: 1. The Telescope Conjecture (for the Adams spectral sequence), 2. The Redshift Conjecture (relating to the vanishing of certain Ext groups in the category of E(n)-local spectra), 3. The Vanishing Conjecture (for Ext groups in the category of E(n)-local spectra), 4. The Chromatic Splitting Conjecture (relating to the decomposition of E(n)-local spectra), 5. The Slice Conjecture (regarding the relationship between the slice filtration and chromatic filtration), 6. The Morava E-theory conjecture (concerning the structure of Ext groups over Morava E-theories), and 7. The Conjecture on the vanishing of certain elements in Ext groups.
related_conjectures: Nilpotence Theorem (which resolved aspects related to Ravenel's work on self-maps of spheres)

Recam√°n's_sequence.name: Recam√°n's sequence
Recam√°n's_sequence.rephrased: Recam√°n's sequence is a sequence generated by a specific recursive rule where each term depends on the previous one.
Recam√°n's_sequence.explained: Recam√°n's sequence is a well-known sequence defined recursively. It starts with a‚ÇÄ = 0. For n > 0, a‚Çô is calculated as follows: if a‚Çô‚Çã‚ÇÅ - n is positive and not already present in the sequence, then a‚Çô = a‚Çô‚Çã‚ÇÅ - n; otherwise, a‚Çô = a‚Çô‚Çã‚ÇÅ + n. This sequence is known for its complex structure and fractal-like properties, despite its simple recursive definition.
related_conjectures: Riemann Hypothesis (due to the study of sequence properties and distribution)
Collatz Conjecture (as another famous sequence with unknown properties)
Properties of the Thue-Morse sequence (comparison of complex recursive sequences)

Reinhardt's_conjecture.name: Reinhardt's conjecture
Reinhardt's_conjecture.rephrased: The smoothed octagon, constructed by modifying a regular octagon with hyperbolic arcs, is conjectured to have the lowest possible maximum packing density among all centrally symmetric convex shapes when packed into the plane.
Reinhardt's_conjecture.implication_form: If a shape is centrally symmetric and convex, then its maximum packing density in the plane is at least that of the smoothed octagon.
Reinhardt's_conjecture.explained: Reinhardt's conjecture states that the maximum packing density of the plane for any centrally symmetric convex shape is at least as high as that achievable by the smoothed octagon. Karl Reinhardt conjectured that the smoothed octagon, which is constructed by replacing the corners of a regular octagon with sections of a hyperbola tangent to the adjacent sides and asymptotic to the sides further out, achieves the minimum possible maximum packing density among all such shapes.

Reinhardt_cardinal.name: Reinhardt cardinal
Reinhardt_cardinal.rephrased: A Reinhardt cardinal is a type of large cardinal that cannot exist within ZFC set theory (ZF + Axiom of Choice), but can be considered in ZF set theory without the Axiom of Choice.
Reinhardt_cardinal.implication_form: If there exists a Reinhardt cardinal, then Zermelo‚ÄìFraenkel set theory with the Axiom of Choice (ZFC) is inconsistent.
Reinhardt_cardinal.solved_by: Proven inconsistent (thus effectively solved) by subsequent set theory results (specific solver not specified)
Reinhardt_cardinal.explained: A Reinhardt cardinal is defined as a cardinal \(\kappa\) that is the critical point of an elementary embedding \(j: \text{Set} \to \text{Set}\) (where \(\text{Set}\) is the universe of all sets), such that \(j(\kappa) = \kappa\) and \(j\) moves some set. This concept arises within Zermelo‚ÄìFraenkel set theory (ZF) without the Axiom of Choice (AC). The existence of such an embedding implies that \(\kappa\) is a cardinal and a limit cardinal with many large cardinal properties. However, it is a theorem (due to Kenneth Kunen, 1970) that no such embedding exists within Zermelo‚ÄìFraenicle set theory with the Axiom of Choice (ZFC), making Reinhardt cardinals inconsistent with ZFC. Thus, Reinhardt cardinals are studied as axioms within ZF alone, representing a very strong large cardinal axiom that cannot be proven consistent relative to ZFC.
related_conjectures: Other variants of Reinhardt cardinals in constructive set theory or other foundational systems
Inconsistency results for other strong large cardinals

Rendezvous_problem.name: Rendezvous problem
Rendezvous_problem.explained: The Rendezvous Problem is a logical dilemma concerning two people who arrive independently at a large park with unknown dimensions and must meet each other. They arrive at the park at random times, and upon arrival, each must decide independently whether to adopt a waiting strategy (remaining stationary) or a searching strategy (moving around the park). The dilemma arises because each person must choose a strategy without knowing the other's choice or arrival time. The goal is to minimize the expected time until they meet (rendezvous time). The challenge lies in coordinating their actions optimally despite the lack of communication and knowledge about the other's strategy.

terms.Arrival Time: The random time at which each person arrives at the park.
terms.Waiting Strategy: A strategy where a person remains stationary at a fixed location.
terms.Searching Strategy: A strategy where a person moves around the park in an attempt to find the other.
terms.Rendezvous Time: The time elapsed from the later person's arrival until the two meet.
terms.Random Arrival: The condition that arrival times are unpredictable and independent.
terms.Symmetric Strategy: A strategy where both players use the same approach (e.g., both wait or both search).
terms.Asymmetric Strategy: A strategy where the two players use different approaches.

Resolution_of_singularities.name: Resolution of singularities
Resolution_of_singularities.rephrased: Any algebraic variety with singularities can be transformed into a smooth variety via a specific type of map called a proper birational map.
Resolution_of_singularities.implication_form: If an algebraic variety has singularities, then there exists a non-singular variety and a proper birational map from it to the original variety.
Resolution_of_singularities.posed_by: Hironaka resolved the characteristic zero case, but the core idea originates from earlier work in algebraic geometry.
Resolution_of_singularities.solved_by: Hironaka for varieties over fields of characteristic zero; unsolved for varieties of dimension at least 4 over fields of characteristic p.
Resolution_of_singularities.explained: The resolution of singularities problem addresses whether every algebraic variety V (over a field, typically assumed algebraically closed) has a resolution. A resolution is a proper birational morphism œÄ: W ‚Üí V, where W is a non-singular (smooth) variety, and birational means that œÄ restricts to an isomorphism between dense open subsets of W and V. Hironaka's theorem proves this is possible for varieties over fields of characteristic zero, but the question remains open for varieties of dimension at least 4 over fields of positive characteristic.

Riemann_hypothesis.name: Riemann hypothesis
Riemann_hypothesis.rephrased: The non-trivial zeros of the Riemann zeta function all lie on the complex line where the real part is exactly 1/2.
Riemann_hypothesis.implication_form: If a complex number is a non-trivial zero of the Riemann zeta function, then its real part is 1/2.
Riemann_hypothesis.explained: The Riemann Hypothesis is a conjecture about the Riemann zeta function, Œ∂(s), which is defined for complex numbers s = œÉ + it. The hypothesis states that all non-trivial zeros of the Riemann zeta function have real part exactly 1/2. Non-trivial zeros are those zeros that are not the negative even integers (trivial zeros). This means that if Œ∂(s) = 0 and s is not a negative even integer, then œÉ = 1/2. This conjecture is deeply connected to the distribution of prime numbers and is considered one of the most important unsolved problems in mathematics.

Riemann_zeta_function.name: Riemann zeta function
Riemann_zeta_function.rephrased: The Riemann zeta function is defined for complex numbers s with a real part greater than 1 by a specific infinite series. The famous Riemann Hypothesis, which is the core conjecture here, states that all non-trivial zeros of this function have a real part of exactly 1/2.
Riemann_zeta_function.implication_form: If a complex number is a non-trivial zero of the Riemann zeta function, then its real part is 1/2.
Riemann_zeta_function.explained: The Riemann zeta function, denoted by Œ∂(s), is a central mathematical function in complex analysis and number theory. For complex numbers s with real part greater than 1, it is defined by the absolutely convergent Dirichlet series: Œ∂(s) = ‚àë_{n=1}^‚àû 1/n^s. This function can be analytically continued to the entire complex plane (except for a simple pole at s = 1). Its zeros are deeply connected to the distribution of prime numbers, and the famous Riemann Hypothesis, which remains unproven, conjectures that all non-trivial zeros lie on the critical line with real part 1/2.
related_conjectures: G√∂del-Escher-Bach (a meta-mathematical work, but illustrates deep connections)

Riesel_number.name: Riesel number
Riesel_number.rephrased: An odd natural number k is a Riesel number if all numbers of the form k multiplied by 2 raised to any natural number n and then subtracted 1 are composite.
Riesel_number.implication_form: It is challenging to express this as a simple 'If P, then Q' implication, as it primarily defines a property (being a Riesel number) based on a condition (all k*2^n -1 being composite). However, one could say: If k is an odd natural number and for all natural numbers n, k*2^n -1 is composite, then k is a Riesel number.
Riesel_number.explained: A Riesel number is an odd natural number k such that the expression k √ó 2^n - 1 is composite for every natural number n.

Road_coloring_conjecture.name: Road coloring conjecture
Road_coloring_conjecture.rephrased: Is there a finite sequence of labels (colors) that can be used to reach a specific node from any starting point in a finite, strongly connected directed graph where each vertex has equal in-degree and out-degree?
Road_coloring_conjecture.implication_form: If the graph is Eulerian (each vertex has equal in-degree and out-degree) and strongly connected, then there exists a finite sequence of labels (a synchronizing word) that, regardless of the starting node, leads to a specific target node.
Road_coloring_conjecture.explained: The Road Coloring Conjecture states that any strongly connected, aperiodic directed graph with a finite number of vertices possesses a universal edge-coloring (assigning colors to edges). This coloring has the property that, from any starting vertex, following a specific sequence of instructions (based on the color sequence) leads unambiguously to a designated target vertex, regardless of the initial position.
related_conjectures: Conjectures related to symbolic dynamics and shift spaces

Robertson-Seymour_theorem.name: Robertson‚ÄìSeymour theorem
Robertson-Seymour_theorem.rephrased: If a family of graphs is closed under taking minors, then it can be described by forbidding a finite number of specific graphs.
Robertson-Seymour_theorem.implication_form: If a family of graphs is closed under taking minors, then there exists a finite set of graphs such that the family consists exactly of graphs that do not contain any of these forbidden graphs as minors.
Robertson-Seymour_theorem.explained: The Robertson‚ÄìSeymour theorem (also known as the graph minors theorem) states that the set of all undirected graphs, ordered by the relation of graph minors, forms a well-quasi-ordering. This means that there are no infinite strictly decreasing sequences of graphs (antichains) and that any property of graphs that is closed under taking minors can be characterized by forbidding a finite set of specific graphs (forbidden minors). In other words, every minor-closed family of graphs can be defined by a finite list of forbidden minors.
related_conjectures: Kruskal's tree theorem (a foundational result in well-quasi-ordering theory for trees)
Four Color Theorem (historically motivated the search for forbidden minors for planar graphs)

Rota's_basis_conjecture.name: Rota's basis conjecture
Rota's_basis_conjecture.rephrased: Given a collection of n disjoint bases in a vector space (or matroid of rank n), it is possible to arrange the elements into an n by n matrix such that each row forms one of the bases and each column also forms a basis.
Rota's_basis_conjecture.implication_form: If there exists a vector space (or matroid) of rank n containing n disjoint bases, then these bases can be arranged into an n √ó n matrix where each row and each column is a basis.
Rota's_basis_conjecture.explained: Rota's basis conjecture states that for any vector space of dimension n or more generally for any matroid of rank n, if there are n disjoint bases (each containing n elements), then it is possible to arrange the elements of these bases into an n √ó n matrix such that each row forms one of the given bases, and each column also forms a basis.

Rudin's_conjecture.name: Rudin's conjecture
Rudin's_conjecture.rephrased: Rudin's conjecture states that the number of squares in a finite arithmetic progression with N terms, common difference q, and first term a is bounded by a function of N and q.
Rudin's_conjecture.implication_form: If an arithmetic progression with N terms, common difference q, and first term a contains many squares, then the parameters N and q must satisfy a specific inequality.
Rudin's_conjecture.explained: Rudin's conjecture concerns the maximum number of perfect squares that can be contained in a finite arithmetic progression. Specifically, for given positive integers N (length of the progression), q (common difference), and a (first term), the conjecture states that the number of squares in the arithmetic progression starting at a with common difference q and containing N terms is bounded above by a function that grows no faster than a constant times (log N)^4, under certain conditions on q and a.

Ryser's_conjecture.name: Ryser's conjecture
Ryser's_conjecture.rephrased: In hypergraphs, the maximum size of a matching (a set of edges with no common vertices) is always at least the minimum size of a transversal (a set of vertices that intersects every edge) minus one.
Ryser's_conjecture.implication_form: If a hypergraph has a minimum transversal size of t, then it must have a matching of size at least t - 1.
Ryser's_conjecture.explained: Ryser's conjecture pertains to r-uniform hypergraphs, which are hypergraphs where every edge contains exactly r vertices. It states that the maximum matching number (denoted ŒΩ, the size of the largest matching) is at most the transversal number (denoted œÑ, the minimum number of vertices that intersect all edges) minus r plus one. In mathematical terms, for any r-uniform hypergraph, ŒΩ ‚â§ œÑ ‚â§ r - 1 * ŒΩ + 1. This bound connects the fundamental parameters of matching and transversal in hypergraphs. The conjecture was stated by Herbert Ryser in 1969, although it first appeared in J. R. Henderson's Ph.D. thesis in 1971.

Sato-Tate_conjecture.name: Sato‚ÄìTate conjecture
Sato-Tate_conjecture.rephrased: The number of points on elliptic curves modulo primes follows a specific statistical pattern.
Sato-Tate_conjecture.implication_form: If an elliptic curve is reduced modulo a prime, then the distribution of the number of points relates to the distribution of an angle Œ∏.
Sato-Tate_conjecture.solved_by: Richard Taylor, Michael Harris, and others
Sato-Tate_conjecture.explained: The Sato‚ÄìTate conjecture pertains to elliptic curves defined over the rational numbers. For an elliptic curve E defined over the rationals, one considers its reductions modulo prime numbers p. Let Np be the number of points on this reduced curve Ep over the finite field with p elements. Hasse's theorem states that Np = p + 1 - a_p, where a_p is an integer satisfying |a_p| ‚â§ 2‚àöp. The conjecture provides a probabilistic description for the distribution of the normalized value a_p / ‚àöp as p varies over sufficiently large primes. Specifically, it posits that the sequence {Œ∏_p} defined by a_p = 2‚àöp cos(Œ∏_p) is equidistributed with respect to the Haar measure on the Sato‚ÄìTate group, which for most elliptic curves is a compact subgroup of SU(2). In other words, the fractional parts {Œ∏_p / (2œÄ)} become uniformly distributed in the interval [0,1) as p runs through primes.

Schanuel's_conjecture.name: Schanuel's conjecture
Schanuel's_conjecture.rephrased: If you take n complex numbers and their natural logarithms, arrange them in a special way (like putting the logs of some numbers and the numbers themselves together), then this set of 2n numbers is so 'independent' over the rational numbers that at most n of them can be expressed using basic arithmetic operations starting from the rational numbers.
Schanuel's_conjecture.implication_form: If there exists a set of n complex numbers and their natural logarithms arranged in a specific way, then the resulting set of 2n numbers has a high transcendence degree over the rationals (specifically, its transcendence degree is at least n).

Scheinerman's_conjecture.name: Scheinerman's conjecture
Scheinerman's_conjecture.rephrased: Any planar graph can be represented as the intersection graph of a set of line segments in the plane.
Scheinerman's_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph is planar, then it can be represented as the intersection graph of a set of line segments in the plane.
Scheinerman's_conjecture.explained: Scheinerman's conjecture, now a theorem, states that every planar graph is an intersection graph of a set of line segments in the plane. This means that for any planar graph, there exists a collection of line segments in the Euclidean plane such that two vertices of the graph are adjacent if and only if the corresponding line segments intersect. The conjecture was formulated by E. R. Scheinerman in 1984 and was proven by Jeremie Chalopin and Daniel Gon√ßalves in 2009.

Schinzel's_hypothesis_H.name: Schinzel's hypothesis H
Schinzel's_hypothesis_H.rephrased: There are infinitely many integers t such that for a set of polynomials with integer coefficients, each irreducible and positive for large t, all these polynomials evaluated at t are prime.
Schinzel's_hypothesis_H.implication_form: If there exists a set of polynomials with integer coefficients, each irreducible and positive for large t, then there are infinitely many integers t such that all these polynomials evaluated at t are prime.
Schinzel's_hypothesis_H.explained: Schinzel's hypothesis H is a profound conjecture in number theory concerning the existence of infinitely many integer solutions to systems of equations defined by polynomials. It states that if one has a finite set of irreducible (primitive) polynomials with integer coefficients, positive leading coefficients, and such that for every prime p, there does not exist a fixed residue class modulo p that all polynomials simultaneously avoid (i.e., no fixed prime p divides all values of the polynomials for some integer input), then there exists a positive integer n such that all the polynomials evaluated at n yield prime numbers. Furthermore, there should be infinitely many such integers n. This conjecture is a generalization that subsumes many other famous conjectures about prime numbers, such as the twin prime conjecture (which corresponds to the polynomial set {x, x+2}).
related_conjectures: The conjecture concerning primes of the form x¬≤ + y‚Å¥
The conjecture about primes of the form x¬≥ + y¬≥
The conjecture regarding primes of the form x¬≤ + 2y‚Å¥

Scholz_conjecture.name: Scholz conjecture
Scholz_conjecture.rephrased: The shortest addition chain for a number n has a length no more than roughly twice the logarithm base 2 of n.
Scholz_conjecture.implication_form: If n is a positive integer, then the minimal length of an addition chain for n is at most log‚ÇÇ(2n-1) + 1.

Schubert_calculus.name: Schubert calculus
Schubert_calculus.rephrased: Schubert calculus is a mathematical framework developed to solve counting problems in projective geometry by providing a systematic way to count geometric configurations under specific conditions, and it is closely related to modern concepts like characteristic classes.
Schubert_calculus.implication_form: If we use Schubert calculus methods, then we can systematically solve certain enumerative geometry problems.
Schubert_calculus.explained: Schubert calculus is a branch of algebraic geometry that focuses on solving enumerative geometry problems‚Äîproblems that ask for the number of geometric objects (such as lines, planes, or points) satisfying specific conditions. It was introduced by Hermann Schubert in the 19th century and involves the intersection of subvarieties within spaces like Grassmannians or flag varieties. The field aims to rigorously count solutions to geometric problems using algebraic methods, often employing combinatorial and topological tools. Hilbert's 15th problem, posed in 1900, specifically challenged mathematicians to provide a solid foundation for Schubert calculus. Modern formulations connect it to concepts like characteristic classes, cohomology theories, and intersection theory.

Section_conjecture.name: Section conjecture
Section_conjecture.rephrased: For a curve defined over a number field, the existence of a certain connection (section) between its fundamental group and the Galois group of the base field implies that the curve has a rational point (a point with coordinates in the base field).
Section_conjecture.implication_form: If the homomorphism from the fundamental group of the curve to the Galois group of the base field has a section, then the curve has a rational point.

Selberg's_1_4_conjecture.name: Selberg's 1/4 conjecture
Selberg's_1_4_conjecture.rephrased: Selberg's conjecture states that certain special functions called Maass wave forms, which satisfy specific symmetry conditions, must have a Laplacian eigenvalue at least 1/4.
Selberg's_1_4_conjecture.implication_form: If a function is a Maass wave form on a congruence subgroup, then its Laplacian eigenvalue is at least 1/4.
Selberg's_1_4_conjecture.explained: Selberg's 1/4 conjecture pertains to the eigenvalues of the Laplace-Beltrami operator acting on Maass wave forms (eigenfunctions with no zeros) for congruence subgroups of SL(2,‚Ñ§). It posits that all such eigenvalues Œª satisfy Œª ‚â• 1/4. Attributed to Atle Selberg, who proved the foundational bound Œª ‚â• 3/16, subsequent mathematical developments have refined this lower bound, with the current best known bound being 975/4096 ‚âà 0.238..., established by Sangchul Kim and Peter Sarnak in 2003. The conjecture is deeply connected to the theory of automorphic forms, and the generalized Ramanujan conjecture for GL(2) implies Selberg's eigenvalue conjecture.

Selberg_class.name: Selberg class
Selberg_class.rephrased: The Selberg class defines a set of Dirichlet series (complex functions) that satisfy four specific axioms (degree, Ramanujan-Paterson conjecture, self-duality, and Euler product). The goal is to classify all such functions.
Selberg_class.implication_form: If a Dirichlet series satisfies the four axioms of the Selberg class, then it belongs to this class and can be classified based on its properties.
Selberg_class.explained: The Selberg class is an axiomatic framework defining a set of Dirichlet series L-functions. An L-function is a member of this class if it satisfies four axioms: (1) It is given by a Dirichlet series with absolutely convergent right half-plane, (2) It satisfies a Ramanujan Conjecture bound on the growth of its coefficients, (3) It is self-dual (its L-function is essentially its own functional equation partner), and (4) It possesses analytic continuation and a functional equation relating its values at s and 1-s. The Selberg class includes the Riemann zeta function and Dirichlet L-functions, and is conjectured to consist entirely of L-functions associated with automorphic representations.

Sendov's_conjecture.name: Sendov's conjecture
Sendov's_conjecture.rephrased: If a polynomial with complex coefficients has a root very close to the boundary of the unit disk, then there must be a critical point (point where the derivative is zero) very close to that root.
Sendov's_conjecture.implication_form: If a polynomial f(z) = (z - r1)(z - r2)...(z - rn) (with complex coefficients) has a root at r_i that satisfies |r_i| ‚â• 1 - Œµ (i.e., very close to the unit circle |z| = 1), then there exists a critical point of f(z) within Œµ of r_i.

Serre's_modularity_conjecture.name: Serre's modularity conjecture
Serre's_modularity_conjecture.rephrased: If a two-dimensional Galois representation over a finite field is odd and irreducible, then it arises from a modular form.
Serre's_modularity_conjecture.implication_form: If a Galois representation is odd, irreducible, and two-dimensional over a finite field, then it arises from a modular form.
Serre's_modularity_conjecture.explained: Serre's modularity conjecture, proposed by Jean-Pierre Serre in the 1970s, posits a deep connection between two-dimensional Galois representations and modular forms. It states that any odd, irreducible, two-dimensional Galois representation (with certain ramification properties) over a finite field arises from a modular form. A stronger, more precise version specifies the weight and level of the modular form in terms of the representation's properties (such as its Dirichlet character and conductor). This conjecture was proven in stages: the level 1 case (where the representation is unramified outside a finite set) was established by Chandrashekhar Khare in 2005, and the full conjecture, including all levels, was completed by Khare and Jean-Pierre Wintenberger in 2008.
Serre's_modularity_conjecture.terms: Galois representation, modular form, Serre's conjecture, automorphic form, weight, level, conductor, Dirichlet character, Galois group, Serre's conjecture on weight and level, Langlands program
Serre's_modularity_conjecture.related_conjectures: Langlands program, Sato-Tate conjecture, Taniyama-Shimura-Weil conjecture (modularity theorem), conjectures on weight and level (part of Serre's work)
Serre's_modularity_conjecture.subjects: Number theory, algebraic number theory, modular forms, representation theory, automorphic forms, arithmetic geometry

Serre_spectral_sequence.name: Serre spectral sequence
Serre_spectral_sequence.rephrased: The Serre spectral sequence is a powerful tool in algebraic topology that allows the homology groups of the total space of a fibration to be computed from the homology groups of its base space and fiber.
Serre_spectral_sequence.implication_form: If there exists a Serre fibration, then the Serre spectral sequence provides a way to compute the homology of the total space from the homology of the base space and the fiber.
Serre_spectral_sequence.explained: The Serre spectral sequence is a fundamental tool in algebraic topology, not a conjecture but a theorem established by Jean-Pierre Serre. It provides a way to compute the homology or cohomology of the total space of a **Serre fibration** (a continuous map with certain homotopy lifting properties) given the homology/cohomology of the base space and the fiber. The sequence is a powerful computational device expressed in the language of spectral sequences, which are tools for computing derived functors in homological algebra. It typically starts with information about the base space and fiber and converges to the homology/cohomology of the total space. Serre's work on this sequence was a major achievement that earned him the Fields Medal.
related_conjectures: Sullivan conjecture (which relates the homotopy of a space to its rational homotopy type and can be approached using spectral sequences like the Serre spectral sequence)
Adams conjecture (which concerns the K-theory of manifolds and involves spectral sequences like the Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence)

Seshadri_constant.name: Seshadri constant
Seshadri_constant.rephrased: The Seshadri constant measures how well an ample line bundle can be approximated by its tensor powers at a specific point on an algebraic variety, relating to the existence of singular curves.
Seshadri_constant.implication_form: If the Seshadri constant at P is less than the square root of the dimension, then Nagata's conjecture holds for that variety.
Seshadri_constant.explained: The Seshadri constant conjecture concerns the existence of positive constants associated with an ample line bundle L on an algebraic variety X. Specifically, for a fixed point P on X, the conjecture states that there exist constants c and d (depending on X, L, and P) such that for sufficiently large k, the line bundle L^k is k-d-ample at P. This means that for any integer m, there exist homogeneous polynomials of degree k m that separate points and tangent vectors in a neighborhood of P, with the separation constant related to c and d. Equivalently, it asserts the nonvanishing of certain cohomology groups related to the jet bundles of sections of L^k at P. This conjecture is closely linked to the Fujita conjecture, which predicts that L^m ‚äó O_X(K_X + D) is ample for m sufficiently large, where D is an effective divisor.

Shimura_variety.name: Shimura variety
Shimura_variety.rephrased: A Shimura variety is a geometric object constructed as a quotient of a special type of space (a Hermitian symmetric domain) by a specific subgroup (a congruence subgroup of a reductive algebraic group). It's a way to organize families of algebraic varieties that are important in number theory.
Shimura_variety.implication_form: If a variety is defined as the quotient of a Hermituts symmetric domain by a congruence subgroup of a reductive algebraic group, then it is a Shimura variety.
Shimura_variety.explained: The concept known as a Shimura variety arises from the definition provided. A Shimura variety is not a single conjecture but rather a specific type of geometric object in mathematics. It is defined as a quotient variety obtained by taking a Hermitian symmetric domain (which is the base point of a reductive algebraic group G defined over Q, equipped with a conjugate-antilinear involution) and dividing it by a congruence subgroup of the associated arithmetic group. These varieties are typically not algebraic varieties themselves but rather complex analytic spaces that parametrize families of algebraic varieties (such as abelian varieties with certain additional structures or polarizations). They play a crucial role in the Langlands program and number theory.

Sidorenko's_conjecture.name: Sidorenko's conjecture
Sidorenko's_conjecture.rephrased: For any bipartite graph H, the number of copies of H as a subgraph in a large graph G with n vertices and average degree pn is asymptotically at least (pn)^{|V(H)|} (where |V(H)| is the number of vertices in H).
Sidorenko's_conjecture.implication_form: If G is a graph on n vertices with average degree pn, then the number of homomorphisms from H to G is asymptotically at least (pn)^{|V(H)|}.

Siegel_zero.name: Siegel zero
Siegel_zero.explained: The Siegel zero conjecture (or the non-existence of Siegel zeros) addresses potential counterexamples to the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis (GRH) for Dirichlet L-functions associated with real primitive characters. Specifically, it states that for a Dirichlet L-function L(s, œá) attached to a real primitive character œá modulo q, there is no zero in the complex plane located in the interval (1 - Œµ(q), 1) for any fixed Œµ(q) > 0 that depends only on q. A Siegel zero would be a zero very close to s=1, but not necessarily at s=1 itself. The conjecture asserts that no such zero exists for any real primitive character œá.

Sierpi≈Ñski_number.name: Sierpi≈Ñski number
Sierpi≈Ñski_number.rephrased: An odd natural number is a Sierpi≈Ñski number if all numbers of the form k multiplied by 2 raised to any power plus one are composite.
Sierpi≈Ñski_number.implication_form: If k is an odd natural number such that k √ó 2^n + 1 is composite for all natural numbers n, then k is a Sierpi≈Ñski number.
Sierpi≈Ñski_number.explained: The Sierpi≈Ñski number conjecture refers to the definition of a Sierpi≈Ñski number (an odd natural number k such that k √ó 2^n + 1 is composite for all natural numbers n) and the subsequent observation or conjecture (now known) that there are infinitely many such numbers. It is distinct from the 'Inverse Sierpi≈Ñski problem' which seeks to find an odd k for which k √ó 2^n + 1 is prime for some n.

Singmaster's_conjecture.name: Singmaster's conjecture
Singmaster's_conjecture.rephrased: All numbers in Pascal's triangle (except 1) appear only a limited number of times.
Singmaster's_conjecture.implication_form: If an entry appears in Pascal's triangle and is not 1, then it appears only finitely many times.
Singmaster's_conjecture.explained: Singmaster's conjecture, proposed by David Singmaster in 1971, addresses the maximum number of times any single number (except 1) appears in Pascal's triangle. Pascal's triangle is constructed by starting with a 1 at the top and adding two adjacent numbers to get the number below them. The conjecture states that despite the infinite repetition of 1 in the triangle, all other numbers occur only a finite number of times. In other words, there exists some fixed integer N such that no number greater than 1 appears more than N times in the entire triangle.

Singular_cardinal.name: Singular cardinal
Singular_cardinal.explained: The Singular Cardinal Conjecture (SCC) is a significant hypothesis in set theory concerning the behavior of singular cardinals. It states that if \( \kappa \) is a singular cardinal and \( \cf(\kappa) = \lambda \) (the cofinality of \( \kappa \) is \( \lambda \)), then the SCH (singular cardinals hypothesis) holds for \( \kappa \), i.e., \( 2^{\kappa} = \kappa^{++} \), where \( \kappa^{++} \) is the second successor cardinal after \( \kappa \). In other words, the power set of \( \kappa \) has the same cardinality as the \( \aleph \)-number immediately following the \( \aleph \)-number of \( \kappa \)'s cofinality. K√∂nig's theorem shows that regular cardinals cannot be singular, but the conjecture addresses the gap for singular cardinals.

Singular_cardinals_hypothesis.name: Singular cardinals hypothesis
Singular_cardinals_hypothesis.rephrased: If Œ∫ is a singular strong limit cardinal, then the cardinality of its power set is its successor cardinal Œ∫‚Å∫.
Singular_cardinals_hypothesis.implication_form: If Œ∫ is a singular strong, strong limit cardinal, then 2^Œ∫ = Œ∫‚Å∫.
Singular_cardinals_hypothesis.posed_by: Robert M. Solovay and Saharon Shelah (building on work by Moti Gitik and others, though the formulation is attributed to Jack H. L. Hunt and Keith A. Mitchell in 1992)
Singular_cardinals_hypothesis.explained: The Singular Cardinals Hypothesis (SCH) is a statement in set theory about cardinal exponentiation. It asserts that if Œ∫ is any singular strong limit cardinal, then the cardinality of the power set of Œ∫ (2^Œ∫) is equal to the successor cardinal of Œ∫ (Œ∫^+). In other words, SCH states that the Generalized Continuum Hypothesis (GCH) holds for singular strong limit cardinals.
related_conjectures: Forcing axioms (e.g., Martin's Axiom, Proper Forcing Axiom)

Skewes's_number.name: Skewes's number
Skewes's_number.rephrased: Skewes's number is defined as the smallest natural number x where the count of prime numbers less than or equal to x (denoted œÄ(x)) is greater than the logarithmic integral of x (li(x)).
Skewes's_number.implication_form: If x is the smallest natural number such that œÄ(x) > li(x), then x is Skewes's number.
Skewes's_number.explained: Skewes's number is not strictly a conjecture but the name given to a very large number that serves as an upper bound for the smallest natural number x where the prime-counting function œÄ(x) (which counts the number of primes less than or equal to x) first exceeds the logarithmic integral function li(x). The conjecture aspect lies in the fact that there exists such a smallest x where this crossover occurs, and the task is to find it. The number Skewes originally proposed was an upper bound for this x, based on certain assumptions (like the Riemann Hypothesis).

Skolem_problem.name: Skolem problem
Skolem_problem.rephrased: Given a linear recurrence relation with constant coefficients, is there an algorithm that can determine whether zero appears as one of the terms in the sequence?
Skolem_problem.implication_form: If there exists an algorithm that can always decide whether zero appears in any linear recurrence sequence, then the problem is solvable for all such sequences.
Skolem_problem.explained: The Skolem problem concerns the decidability of whether a zero value appears in a specific class of sequences defined by linear recurrence relations. A sequence satisfies a linear recurrence relation of order k if each term from the (k+1)-th onward can be expressed as a linear combination of the previous k terms, using constant coefficients. The Skolem problem asks: Given a linear recurrence relation with integer coefficients and integer initial conditions, does there exist an algorithm that can determine whether zero appears in the sequence for some position? This problem is also considered for sequences over rational numbers and algebraic numbers, but the integer case is the most prominent. The key question is whether such a universal algorithm exists that can solve this problem for any given recurrence relation. It is widely believed that no such algorithm exists, making the problem undecidable, although this has not been proven rigorously for all cases.
related_conjectures: Hilbert's 10th Problem (concerns the solvability of Diophantine equations)
Undecidability of the Halting Problem (a fundamental result in computability theory)
Invariant Subspace Problem (an open problem in functional analysis concerning linear operators)

Sphere_packing.name: Sphere packing
Sphere_packing.rephrased: Arranging identical spheres without overlapping in a given space.
Sphere_packing.implication_form: Cannot be rewritten as 'If P, then Q' as no specific hypothesis/conclusion is provided.
Sphere_packing.explained: The Sphere Packing Conjecture, often referred to in relation to the Kepler conjecture, addresses the problem of arranging identical spheres in three-dimensional Euclidean space to achieve the maximum possible density. It states that the maximum density achievable is approximately 74.05% (œÄ/(3‚àö2) ‚âà 0.7405), and this maximum can be attained by packing the spheres in a face-centered cubic (FCC) or hexagonal close-packed (HCP) lattice arrangement. These arrangements are known to achieve the highest packing density.

Spherical_space_form_conjecture.name: Spherical space form conjecture
Spherical_space_form_conjecture.rephrased: A finite group can be realized as a symmetry group of the 3-sphere.
Spherical_space_form_conjecture.implication_form: If a finite group acts faithfully on the 3-sphere, then it is conjugate to a subgroup of the isometry group of the 3-sphere.
Spherical_space_form_conjecture.explained: The Spherical Space Form Conjecture, now a theorem proven primarily by Ludwig Bieberbach (1933, 1935), Wu-Hsiang Hsiang (1966), and Jeff Cheeger and Michael Gromov (1987), states that if a finite group G acts effectively on the 3-sphere S¬≥ by isometries (i.e., preserving the standard Riemannian metric), then G is conjugate to a finite subgroup of the orthogonal group O(4) (or equivalently, of SO(4), since S¬≥ is the group of unit quaternions). This means G must be a finite subgroup of the isometry group of S¬≥. The theorem classifies all finite groups that can act faithfully by isometries on the 3-sphere.
related_conjectures: Geometrization Conjecture (now proven by Grigori Perel'man)
Elliptization Conjecture (a consequence of the Geometrization Conjecture for spherical 3-manifolds)
Bieberbach Conjecture (about the infinitesimal rigidity of crystallographic groups)

Square_packing_in_a_square.name: Square packing in a square
Square_packing_in_a_square.explained: The Square packing in a square conjecture concerns the problem of packing the maximum number of identical squares (congruent squares) into a larger square without overlapping. The goal is to determine this maximum number for a given ratio of the side length of the small squares to the side length of the large square, or equivalently, to find the packing density. The conjecture refers to the unresolved question of finding the exact maximum number or the optimal packing arrangement for squares of a fixed size into a larger square, particularly for specific ratios where the optimal packing is not known.
related_conjectures: Thue‚ÄìMorse sequence (related to packing arrangements in some cases)

Standard_conjectures.name: Standard conjectures
Standard_conjectures.rephrased: The standard conjectures propose that certain relationships between algebraic cycles and cohomology in algebraic geometry hold, which would imply that the category of motives is semisimple.
Standard_conjectures.implication_form: If the standard conjectures about algebraic cycles and their relationship to cohomology are true, then the Weil conjectures, particularly their Riemann hypothesis part, are also true.
Standard_conjectures.explained:
The Standard Conjectures, formulated by Alexander Grothendieck, are a set of conjectures concerning the properties of algebraic cycles in algebraic geometry, particularly in relation to Weil cohomology theories. They are stated as follows (using Grothendieck's original phrasing, though often stated slightly differently):

1.  **The Standard Lefschetz Type Conjecture (Conjecture de Lefschetz):** For a smooth projective variety X over a field of characteristic zero, the Lefschetz operator L (cap product with the class of a hyperplane section) acts on the cohomology groups H^k(X) as an isomorphism between H^k(X) and H^{n-k}(X), composed with a sign (-1)^{n-k}, where n is the dimension of X. This implies the decomposition of cohomology into primitive parts.

2.  **The Hard Lefschetz Type Conjecture (Conjecture dite "Hard Lefschetz"):** For a smooth projective variety X over a field of characteristic zero and a divisor D (or hyperplane section), the Lefschetz operator L^k (k! times the class of D^k) induces an isomorphism between the primitive cohomology groups P^k(X) and P^{n-k}(X) (or a related isomorphism).

3.  **The Hodge Type Conjecture (Conjecture de Hodge):** This states that for a smooth projective variety X over the complex numbers, the Hodge classes in its cohomology (classes that can be written as intersections of algebraic cycles) are spanned by the classes of algebraic cycles. This is actually the Hodge Conjecture itself, but Grothendieck formulated it as a Standard Conjecture in the Weil cohomology setting.

4.  **The Tate Type Conjecture (Conjecture de Tate):** For a smooth projective variety X over a field F which is finitely generated over its prime field, and for any Weil cohomology theory, the cycle map from algebraic cycles modulo rational equivalence to the cohomology groups, tensored with Q, becomes an isomorphism after tensoring with Q and extending the coefficients appropriately (e.g., Q, Q(l), Z(l), depending on the context). This conjecture also holds for numerical equivalence in many cases. It generalizes the Hodge Conjecture (over C) and the Tate Conjecture (over finite fields).

These conjectures are fundamental to the theory of motives, which Grothendieck hoped would provide a universal cohomology theory for algebraic varieties. The Standard Conjectures describe essential properties that any such universal cohomology theory (the category of motives) should satisfy.
related_conjectures: Conjectures related to the Riemann Hypothesis

Stanley-Wilf_conjecture.name: Stanley‚ÄìWilf conjecture
Stanley-Wilf_conjecture.rephrased: No proper permutation class can have a growth rate faster than exponential.
Stanley-Wilf_conjecture.implication_form: If a permutation class is proper, then its growth rate is singly exponential.
Stanley-Wilf_conjecture.explained: The Stanley‚ÄìWilf conjecture, formulated by Richard P. Stanley and Herbert Wilf in the late 1980s, stated that for any permutation pattern œÉ, the size of the largest permutation class avoiding œÉ (or any set of permutations forming a basis for a permutation class) is bounded by a constant raised to the power of n, where n is the length of the permutation. In other words, the growth rate of every proper permutation class is singly exponential. This conjecture was proven by Adam Marcus and G√°bor Tardos in 2004, and the theorem they proved (which was originally conjectured by Zolt√°n F√ºredi and P√©ter Hajnal in 1992) implies the Stanley‚ÄìWilf conjecture.

Stark_conjectures.name: Stark conjectures
Stark_conjectures.rephrased: The Stark conjectures generalize the analytic class number formula by predicting the leading coefficient of the Taylor expansion of an Artin L-function at 0 for a Galois extension, expressing it in terms of regulators and other invariants.
Stark_conjectures.implication_form: If the Stark conjecture holds for a given Galois extension and Artin character, then the leading coefficient of the L-function's Taylor expansion at 0 can be expressed in a specific form involving regulators.
Stark_conjectures.posed_by: Helmut Stark, with contributions from John Tate
Stark_conjectures.explained: The Stark conjectures, formulated by Harold Stark and expanded upon by John Tate, provide conjectural formulas for the leading coefficient of the Taylor expansion of an Artin L-function L(s, œá) associated with a Galois extension K/k of algebraic number fields at the point s = 0. This leading coefficient is predicted to be expressed as a product involving various invariants related to the extension, the base field, and the Artin character. These conjectures generalize the analytic class number formula, which gives a similar expression for the leading coefficient of the Dedekind zeta function (a special case when considering the trivial character) of a base number field k. The conjecture predicts the value of this coefficient based on the Galois group, the base field k, the extension K, and the Artin character œá.

Strong_perfect_graph_conjecture.name: Strong perfect graph conjecture
Strong_perfect_graph_conjecture.rephrased: A graph is perfect if and only if it contains no induced cycles of odd length at least 5 (odd holes) and no induced complements of cycles of odd length at least 5 (odd antiholes).
Strong_perfect_graph_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph has no odd holes and no odd antiholes, then it is a perfect graph.
Strong_perfect_graph_conjecture.explained: The Strong Perfect Graph Theorem (SPGT), originally conjectured by Claude Berge in 1961 and proven in 2006 by Maria Chudnovsky, Neil Robertson, Paul Seymour, and Robin Thomas, provides a fundamental characterization of perfect graphs. A graph is perfect if and only if it does not contain an induced subgraph that is an *odd hole* (an induced cycle of odd length at least 5) or an *odd antihole* (an induced cycle of odd length at least 5 in the complement graph). This means the graph classifies all graphs where the chromatic number equals the clique number for every induced subgraph.
terms: Perfect graph: A graph in which the chromatic number equals the clique number for every induced subgraph.
Odd hole: An induced cycle of odd length (e.g., 5, 7, 9) in the graph.
Odd antihole: An induced cycle of odd length (e.g., 5, 7, 9) in the complement graph.
Induced subgraph: A subgraph formed by selecting a subset of vertices and all edges present in the original graph between these vertices.
Complement graph: A graph where two distinct vertices are adjacent if and only if they are not adjacent in the original graph.
Chromatic number: The minimum number of colors needed to color the vertices of a graph so that no two adjacent vertices share the same color.
Clique number: The size of the largest clique (subset of vertices where every two distinct vertices are adjacent) in a graph.
related_conjectures: Gallai-Hasse-Roy-Vishver Conjecture (GHRV): Concerns the structure of perfect graphs, proposing they can be partitioned into a clique and a stable set with specific properties.
Erd≈ës‚ÄìFaber‚ÄìLov√°sz Conjecture: A conjecture about the chromatic number of intersection graphs of edges in complete graphs.
Four Color Theorem: A theorem stating that any planar map can be colored with at most four colors, related to coloring problems studied in perfect graphs.
Berge-Fulkerson Conjecture: A conjecture about edge colorings of certain classes of graphs, including perfect graphs.

Sudoku.name: Sudoku
Sudoku.rephrased: Fill a 9x9 grid with digits 1-9 such that each row, column, and 3x3 box contains all digits 1-9 exactly once, given some starting numbers.
Sudoku.implication_form: If a partially filled 9x9 grid satisfies the Sudoku rules and has exactly one solution, then it is a valid Sudoku puzzle.
Sudoku.explained: Sudoku is a combinatorial puzzle defined on a 9√ó9 grid, divided into nine 3√ó3 subgrids (boxes). The objective is to fill the grid with digits 1 through 9 such that each row, each column, and each box contains each digit exactly once. A Sudoku puzzle is presented with a partially filled grid, and the challenge is to complete it according to these rules. The term 'conjecture' may be misleading here, as Sudoku is primarily a puzzle format, but the question of whether certain configurations (like minimal clues) lead to unique solutions is an area of combinatorial study.
related_conjectures: The minimal number of clues problem (conjectured to be 17 for a unique solution)
Counting the number of Sudoku grids
Sudoku as a Latin square with additional constraints

Suita_conjecture.name: Suita conjecture
Suita_conjecture.rephrased: On a Riemann surface with a nontrivial Green function, the Bergman kernel function satisfies a specific inequality involving the derivative of the Green function.
Suita_conjecture.implication_form: If a Riemann surface admits a nontrivial Green function, then its Bergman kernel function is bounded above by a constant times the reciprocal of the derivative of the Green function.
Suita_conjecture.explained: Suita (1972): Let R be a Riemann surface, which admits a nontrivial Green function G_R. Let Œ© be a subdomain of R with piecewise smooth boundary. Let œâ be a point on the boundary of Œ©. Then, for any holomorphic function f defined in a neighborhood of œâ, the following inequality holds: |f'(œâ)| ‚â§ (œÄ / G_R(œâ)) * ‚à´‚à´_Œ© |f(z)|^2 dA(z), where dA denotes the area element.

Sumner's_conjecture.name: Sumner's conjecture
Sumner's_conjecture.rephrased: Any tree with n vertices, when oriented (each edge directed), can be found as a subgraph within a tournament of 2n-2 vertices.
Sumner's_conjecture.implication_form: If a graph is an orientation of an n-vertex tree, then it is a subgraph of every (2n-2)-vertex tournament.
Sumner's_conjecture.explained: Sumner's conjecture (also known as Sumner's universal tournament conjecture) is a conjecture in extremal graph theory. It states that for any positive integer n and any orientation of any n-vertex tree, this oriented tree is isomorphic to a subtournament of every tournament on 2n-2 vertices.
related_conjectures: Havet-Thomass√© conjecture (a generalization of Sumner's conjecture to digraphs)

Surface_subgroup_conjecture.name: Surface subgroup conjecture
Surface_subgroup_conjecture.rephrased: Every closed, irreducible 3-manifold with an infinite fundamental group must contain a subgroup isomorphic to the fundamental group of a closed surface (not a sphere).
Surface_subgroup_conjecture.implication_form: If a closed, irreducible 3-manifold has an infinite fundamental group, then it has a surface subgroup.
Surface_subgroup_conjecture.explained: The Surface Subgroup Conjecture, proposed by Friedhelm Waldhausen, states that the fundamental group of every closed, irreducible 3-manifold with an infinite fundamental group contains a surface subgroup. A surface subgroup is defined as a subgroup isomorphic to the fundamental group of a closed surface that is not the 2-sphere (i.e., a closed surface of genus at least one or the projective plane). This conjecture is significant in the study of 3-manifold topology and group theory. After the proof of the Geometrization Conjecture, the conjecture is now understood to be largely resolved, with the main remaining open case being for closed hyperbolic 3-manifolds with infinite fundamental group.

Suslin_tree.name: Suslin tree
Suslin_tree.rephrased: A special type of infinite tree where every chain and antichain is countable.
Suslin_tree.implication_form: If ZFC is consistent, then the existence of a Suslin tree is independent of ZFC.
Suslin_tree.explained: A Suslin tree is a mathematical structure defined within set theory as a tree of height œâ1 (the first uncountable ordinal) that satisfies two key properties: every chain (branch) is countable, and every antichain is countable. It is a specific type of Aronszajn tree, which is an uncountable tree with no uncountable chains or antichains, but unlike the general Aronszajn tree, the Suslin tree does not have a certain 'witnessing' property related to dense sets in the definition of a Suslin algebra.
terms: Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory with the Axiom of Choice (ZFC)

Szemer√©di's_theorem.name: Szemer√©di's theorem
Szemer√©di's_theorem.rephrased: If a subset of the integers has positive density, then it contains arithmetic progressions of arbitrary length.
Szemer√©di's_theorem.implication_form: If a subset of the integers has positive natural density, then it contains a k-term arithmetic progression for every k.
Szemer√©di's_theorem.explained: Szemer√©di's theorem states that any subset of the integers with positive upper density contains arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions. In other words, if a subset A of the integers has positive density (a concept rigorously defined in additive combinatorics), then for any integer k, A contains a k-term arithmetic progression.

Szpiro's_conjecture.name: Szpiro's conjecture
Szpiro's_conjecture.rephrased: For any elliptic curve, the conductor (a measure of the curve's arithmetic complexity) is roughly proportional to the cube root of the discriminant (a measure of the curve's singularity), with the constant of proportionality depending only on the curve's specific properties.
Szpiro's_conjecture.implication_form: If P, then Q (the exact implication isn't provided, but the conjecture is equivalent to the abc conjecture: If a, b, c are coprime positive integers with a+b=c, then c < K * (rad(abc))^Œµ for all Œµ > 0 and some constant K depending on Œµ)
Szpiro's_conjecture.explained: Szpiro's conjecture, formulated in the 1980s by Lucien Szpiro, concerns elliptic curves defined over the rational numbers. It proposes a bound on the conductor of an elliptic curve in terms of its minimal discriminant. Specifically, for any elliptic curve given by a Weierstrass model, there exists an absolute constant Œµ > 0 such that for all curves with sufficiently large conductor, the conductor is bounded by its minimal discriminant raised to the power of 1 + Œµ. A slightly modified version of Szpiro's conjecture is equivalent to the abc conjecture, which deals with the relationship between three integers a, b, c with no common divisor and the product of the distinct prime factors of a*b*c. Szpiro's conjecture has profound implications in number theory, including connections to Roth's theorem, the Mordell-Lang conjecture (now Faltings' theorem), and the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture.

Szymanski's_conjecture.name: Szymanski's conjecture
Szymanski's_conjecture.rephrased: In a bidirectional n-dimensional hypercube graph, any permutation of the vertices can be decomposed into edge-disjoint directed paths from each vertex to its image.
Szymanski's_conjecture.implication_form: If there exists a permutation on the vertices of an n-dimensional doubly directed hypercube graph, then there exist edge-disjoint directed paths from each vertex to its image.
Szymanski's_conjecture.explained: Szymanski's conjecture, named after Ted H. Szymanski and formulated in 1989, states that for the n-dimensional doubly directed hypercube graph (where vertices represent all binary strings of length n, and edges exist in both directions between vertices differing in exactly one bit), every permutation œÉ of its vertices can be realized by a set of edge-disjoint directed paths. Specifically, for each vertex v, there exists a directed path from v to œÉ(v), and no two such paths share an edge in the same direction.

Tameness_conjecture.name: Tameness conjecture
Tameness_conjecture.rephrased: A complete hyperbolic 3-manifold with a finitely generated fundamental group can be made compact by adding a boundary (it is topologically tame).
Tameness_conjecture.implication_form: If a complete hyperbolic 3-manifold has a finitely generated fundamental group, then it is topologically tame (i.e., homeomorphic to the interior of a compact 3-manifold).
Tameness_conjecture.solved_by: Ian Agol and Danny Calegari (and David Gabai)

Tammes_problem.name: Tammes problem
Tammes_problem.rephrased: Arrange a given number of points on a sphere's surface such that the minimum distance between any two points is as large as possible.
Tammes_problem.implication_form: If you wish to maximize the minimum distance between points arranged on a sphere, then arrange them in the configuration that achieves this maximum distance.
Tammes_problem.solved_by: Various configurations have been determined for small numbers of points (e.g., up to 120), but many cases remain unsolved.
Tammes_problem.explained: The Tammes problem involves determining the optimal arrangement of a given number of points on the surface of a sphere such that the minimum distance between any two points is maximized. It is a discrete sphere packing problem focusing on maximizing the smallest pairwise distance for a fixed number of points. This problem is closely related to the concept of a spherical code, where the points represent codewords and the minimum distance corresponds to the minimum separation.
related_conjectures: Thomson Problem (minimizing Coulomb energy is equivalent for equal charges)
Kepler Conjecture (concerning the densest packing of identical spheres in 3D space)
Sphere Packing Problem (in higher dimensions, e.g., the E8 lattice in 8D)
Ulam Spiral Problem (packing in the plane with excluded regions)

Tarski's_exponential_function_problem.name: Tarski's exponential function problem
Tarski's_exponential_function_problem.rephrased: Is the theory of the real numbers, including the exponential function, decidable?
